Acanthosis nigricans has Symptom: The main sign of acanthosis nigricans is dark, thick, velvety skin in body folds and creases. It often appears in the armpits, groin and back of the neck. It develops slowly. The affected skin might be itchy, have an odor and develop skin tags.
Acanthosis nigricans has Cause: Acanthosis nigricans might be related to:

Acanthosis nigricans has Risk Factor: The risk of acanthosis nigricans is higher in people who have obesity. The risk is also higher in people with a family history of the condition, especially in families where obesity and type 2 diabetes are also common.
Acanthosis nigricans has Complication: People who have acanthosis nigricans are much more likely to develop type 2 diabetes.

Achalasia has Symptom: Vomiting.

Achalasia has Cause: The exact cause of achalasia is poorly understood. Researchers suspect that it may be caused by a loss of nerve cells in the esophagus. There are theories about what causes this, but viral infection or autoimmune responses are possibilities. Very rarely, achalasia may be caused by an inherited genetic disorder or infection.
Achalasia has Risk Factor: Although achalasia can affect people of all ages, it's more common in people between 25 and 60 years of age.
Achalasia has Risk Factor: Certain medical conditions.

Achilles tendinitis has Symptom: Achilles tendinitis pain most often begins as a mild ache in the back of the leg or above the heel after running or other sports activity. More-severe burning or aching pain might occur after running a long time, stair climbing or sprinting. Over time, there might be pain even at rest.

Achilles tendinitis has Cause: Repeated or intense strain on the Achilles tendon can cause Achilles tendinitis, though sometimes the cause is not clear. The Achilles tendon is the band of tissue that joins the calf muscles to the heel bone. This tendon is used while walking, running, jumping, climbing or standing on tip toes. Achilles tendinitis can occur within the middle part of the tendon or where it attaches to the heel bone.
Achilles tendinitis has Risk Factor: Factors that can raise the risk of Achilles tendinitis include:

Achilles tendinitis has Complication: Achilles tendinitis can weaken the tendon. The weakness makes it more likely to tear, also called rupture. An Achilles rupture is a serious injury that often needs surgery to repair it.
Achilles tendinitis has Preventio: It may not be possible to prevent Achilles tendinitis. But here are some ways to reduce the risk:

Acoustic neuroma has Symptom: Hearing loss, usually gradually over months to years. In rare cases, hearing loss can be sudden. Hearing loss usually occurs on one side or is worse on one side.
Acoustic neuroma has Symptom: Ringing in the affected ear, known as tinnitus.
Acoustic neuroma has Symptom: Loss of balance or not feeling steady.
Acoustic neuroma has Symptom: Dizziness.
Acoustic neuroma has Symptom: Facial numbness and, very rarely, weakness or loss of muscle movement.

Acoustic neuroma has Cause: The cause of acoustic neuromas can sometimes be linked to a change to a gene on chromosome 22. Typically, this gene produces a tumor suppressor protein that helps regulate the growth of Schwann cells covering the nerves. Experts don't know what causes this change to the gene. Often there is no known cause. In some people, the gene change is related to a rare condition called NF2-related schwannomatosis, also known as NF2. The condition was previously known as neurofibromatosis type 2. People with NF2 usually have growth of tumors on the hearing and balance nerves on both sides of the head. These tumors are known as bilateral vestibular schwannomas.
Acoustic neuroma has Complication: Hearing loss.
Acoustic neuroma has Complication: Facial numbness and weakness.
Acoustic neuroma has Complication: Trouble with balance.
Acoustic neuroma has Complication: Ringing in the ear.
Acromegaly has Symptom: Thick ears and lips.
Acromegaly has Symptom: A broad nose.
Acromegaly has Symptom: Enlarged hands and feet.
Acromegaly has Symptom: A jutting brow or jaw.
Acromegaly has Symptom: Gaps between teeth.
Acromegaly has Symptom: An enlarged tongue.
Acromegaly has Symptom: An expanded rib cage that may cause the chest to have a round shape.

Acromegaly has Cause: The most common cause of acromegaly is a tumor in the pituitary gland. The tumor is called an adenoma. It isn't cancer. But it makes too much growth hormone over a long amount of time.
Acromegaly has Risk Factor: People who have a rare genetic condition called multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 have a higher risk of acromegaly. This condition also is called MEN 1.
Acromegaly has Complication: High blood pressure.
Acromegaly has Complication: Higher risk of narrow arteries, which may lead to a heart attack or stroke.

Actinic keratosis has Preventio: Sun safety helps prevent actinic keratoses. Take these steps to protect your skin from the sun:
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Chest pain or discomfort. It may feel like aching, pressure, tightness or burning. Chest pain also is called angina.
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Pain that starts in the chest and spreads to other parts of the body. These areas include the shoulders, arms, upper belly area, back, neck or jaw.
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Nausea or vomiting.
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Pain or burning in the upper belly, called indigestion.
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Shortness of breath, also called dyspnea.

Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Racing heartbeat.
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Feeling lightheaded or dizzy.
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Fainting.
Acute coronary syndrome has Symptom: Unusual fatigue.

Acute coronary syndrome has Cause: Acute coronary syndrome usually is caused by a buildup of fatty deposits in and on the walls of the heart's arteries. The fatty deposits also are called plaque. When a fatty deposit breaks open, a blood clot can form. This clot blocks blood flow to the heart. The heart muscle doesn't get enough oxygen.
Acute coronary syndrome has Risk Factor: Older age.
Acute coronary syndrome has Risk Factor: High blood pressure.
Acute coronary syndrome has Risk Factor: High blood cholesterol.
Acute coronary syndrome has Risk Factor: Smoking or tobacco use.

Acute coronary syndrome has Risk Factor: COVID-19 infection.

Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) has Cause: Acute flaccid myelitis might be caused by an infection with a type of virus known as an enterovirus. Respiratory illnesses and fever from enteroviruses are common — especially in children. Most people recover. It's not clear why some people with an enterovirus infection develop acute flaccid myelitis.
Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) has Risk Factor: Acute flaccid myelitis mainly affects young children.
Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) has Complication: Muscle weakness caused by acute flaccid myelitis can continue for months to years.

Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) has Preventio: There's no specific way to prevent acute flaccid myelitis. However, preventing a viral infection can help reduce the risk of developing acute flaccid myelitis.

Acute lymphocytic leukemia has Cause: Acute lymphocytic leukemia occurs when a bone marrow cell develops changes (mutations) in its genetic material or DNA. A cell's DNA contains the instructions that tell a cell what to do. Normally, the DNA tells the cell to grow at a set rate and to die at a set time. In acute lymphocytic leukemia, the mutations tell the bone marrow cell to continue growing and dividing.
Acute lymphocytic leukemia has Risk Factor: Previous cancer treatment.
Acute lymphocytic leukemia has Risk Factor: Exposure to radiation.
Acute lymphocytic leukemia has Risk Factor: Genetic disorders.

Acute myelogenous leukemia has Cause: White blood cells, which help fight infections.

Acute sinusitis has Risk Factor: A common cold
Acute sinusitis has Risk Factor: A problem inside the nose,

Addison's disease has Symptom: Extreme tiredness, also called fatigue.

Addison's disease has Complication: Addison's disease can lead to other health conditions called complications. These include adrenal crisis, also called addisonian crisis. If you have Addison's disease and haven't started treatment, you may develop this life-threatening complication.
Addison's disease has Preventio: Talk with your healthcare professional if you always feel tired or weak or are losing weight without trying. Ask if you should get tested for adrenal insufficiency.

Addison's disease has Preventio: If you have Addison's disease, ask your healthcare professional what to do when you're sick. You'll likely need to learn how to adjust the amount of medicine that you take. You also may need to take the medicine as a shot.
Addison's disease has Preventio: If you become very sick, go to an emergency room. This is crucial if you're vomiting and you can't take your medicine.

Adenomyosis has Cause: The exact cause of adenomyosis isn't known, but theories about possible causes include:
Adenomyosis has Risk Factor: Risk factors for adenomyosis include:

Adenomyosis has Complication: Heavy bleeding during periods from adenomyosis could lead to anemia. Anemia occurs when there aren't enough healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen to the body's tissues. This can make you feel tired and short of breath and cause other health problems.

Adjustment disorders has Symptom: Crying often.
Adjustment disorders has Symptom: Worrying, or feeling anxious, nervous, jittery or stressed out.

Adjustment disorders has Symptom: Not eating enough.

Adjustment disorders has Symptom: Withdrawing from family and friends who support you socially.
Adjustment disorders has Symptom: Not doing important things, such as going to work or paying bills.
Adjustment disorders has Symptom: Thinking about suicide or acting on those thoughts.

Adjustment disorders has Cause: Adjustment disorders are caused by major changes or stressors in your life. Genetics, your life experiences and your temperament may make it more likely that an adjustment disorder happens.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Major stress as a child, such as bullying or difficulties with school.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Divorce or marriage problems.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Relationship problems or trouble getting along with others.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Major changes in life, such as retirement, having a baby or moving away.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Bad experiences, such as losing a job, loss of a loved one or having money problems.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Problems in school or at work.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Life-threatening experiences, such as physical assault, combat or natural disaster.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Ongoing stressors, such as having a medical illness or living in a neighborhood that has a lot of crime.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: More than one major change or bad experience happening at the same time.
Adjustment disorders has Risk Factor: Other mental health conditions, such as major depression, intense anxiety or post-traumatic stress disorder.

Adjustment disorders has Complication: If adjustment disorders do not resolve, they eventually can lead to more-serious mental health conditions such as anxiety, major depression, or misuse of drugs or alcohol.

Adjustment disorders has Preventio: There are no guaranteed ways to prevent adjustment disorders. But social support, healthy coping skills and learning to recover quickly from hard times may help you during times of high stress.

Adult Still disease has Cause: The cause of adult Still disease is not known. Some researchers suspect it might be triggered by a viral or bacterial infection.

Adult Still disease has Risk Factor: Age is the main risk factor for adult Still disease. It is most likely to occur in adults between the ages of 15 and 25 and between the ages of 36 and 46. Males and females are equally at risk.

Age spots (liver spots) has Symptom: Age spots may affect people of all skin types, but they're more common in adults with skin that sunburns easily. Unlike freckles, which are common in children and fade with no sun exposure, age spots don't fade.

Age spots (liver spots) has Cause: Age spots are caused by overactive pigment cells. Ultraviolet (UV) light speeds up the production of melanin, a natural pigment that gives skin its color. On skin that has had years of sun exposure, age spots appear when melanin becomes clumped or is produced in high concentrations.
Age spots (liver spots) has Risk Factor: You might be more likely to develop age spots if you have a history of frequent or intense sun exposure or sunburn.
Age spots (liver spots) has Preventio: To help avoid age spots and new spots after treatment, follow these tips for limiting your sun exposure:

Agoraphobia has Symptom: Crowds or waiting in line.
Agoraphobia has Symptom: Enclosed spaces, such as movie theaters, elevators or small stores.
Agoraphobia has Symptom: Open spaces, such as parking lots, bridges or malls.
Agoraphobia has Symptom: Using public transportation, such as a bus, plane or train.
Agoraphobia has Cause: Biology — including health conditions and genetics — personality, stress and learning experiences may all play a role in the development of agoraphobia.
Agoraphobia has Risk Factor: Having panic disorder or other excessive fear reactions, called phobias.
Agoraphobia has Risk Factor: Responding to panic attacks with too much fear and avoidance.
Agoraphobia has Risk Factor: Experiencing stressful life events, such as abuse, the death of a parent or being attacked.
Agoraphobia has Risk Factor: Having an anxious or nervous personality.
Agoraphobia has Risk Factor: Having a blood relative with agoraphobia.
Agoraphobia has Complication: Depression.
Agoraphobia has Complication: Alcohol or drug misuse.
Agoraphobia has Complication: Suicidal thoughts and behavior.

Agoraphobia has Preventio: There's no sure way to prevent agoraphobia. But anxiety tends to increase the more you avoid situations that you fear. If you start to have mild fears about going places that are safe, try to practice going to those places over and over again. This can help you feel more comfortable in those places. If this is too hard to do on your own, ask a family member or friend to go with you, or seek professional help.
Airplane ear has Symptom: Airplane ear can happen in one or both ears. Common symptoms of airplane ear include:

Airplane ear has Cause: Airplane ear happens when the air pressure in the middle ear and the air pressure inside the airplane don't match. The mismatch keeps the eardrum, also called the tympanic membrane, from moving as usual.
Airplane ear has Risk Factor: Anything that blocks the eustachian tube or keeps it from working as usual can increase the risk of airplane ear. Common risk factors include:

Airplane ear has Complication: Airplane ear usually isn't serious and gets better with self-care. Rarely, complications can happen when the condition is serious or long-lasting. Also, complications can happen if there's damage to the middle or inner ear.
Airplane ear has Preventio: To prevent or avoid airplane ear, follow these tips:
Albinism has Symptom: Symptoms of albinism involve skin, hair and eye color, as well as vision.

Albinism has Cause: Several genes give instructions for making one of several proteins involved in producing melanin. Melanin is made by cells called melanocytes that are found in your skin, hair and eyes.
Albinism has Risk Factor: Risk factors depend on whether one or both parents carry an affected gene. Different types of albinism have different types of inheritance patterns.
Albinism has Complication: Albinism can include skin and eye complications. It also can include social and emotional challenges.

Albinism has Preventio: If a family member has albinism, a genetic counselor can help you understand the type of albinism and the chances of having a future child with albinism. The counselor can explain the available genetic tests.
Alcohol intolerance has Symptom: Symptoms of alcohol can include:

Alcohol intolerance has Cause: Alcohol intolerance happens when your body doesn't have the proper enzymes to break down the toxins in alcohol molecules. This is a caused by a genetic trait that is most often found in people of Asian ancestry. But anyone can have it.
Alcohol intolerance has Risk Factor: Risk factors for alcohol intolerance or other reactions to alcoholic beverages include:
Alcohol intolerance has Complication: Depending on the cause, complications of alcohol intolerance or other reactions to alcoholic beverages can include:

Alcohol intolerance has Preventio: Nothing can prevent reactions to alcohol or ingredients in alcoholic beverages. To avoid a reaction, don't drink alcohol or the particular type of alcoholic beverage that causes your reaction.

Alcohol poisoning has Symptom: Low body temperature, also known as hypothermia.

Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Spending a lot of time drinking, getting alcohol or recovering from alcohol use
Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Feeling a strong craving or urge to drink alcohol
Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Failing to fulfill major obligations at work, school or home due to repeated alcohol use
Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Continuing to drink alcohol even though you know it's causing physical, social, work or relationship problems
Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Giving up or reducing social and work activities and hobbies to use alcohol
Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Using alcohol in situations where it's not safe, such as when driving or swimming
Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Developing a tolerance to alcohol so you need more to feel its effect or you have a reduced effect from the same amount
Alcohol use disorder has Symptom: Experiencing withdrawal symptoms — such as nausea, sweating and shaking — when you don't drink, or drinking to avoid these symptoms

Alcohol use disorder has Cause: Genetic, psychological, social and environmental factors can impact how drinking alcohol affects your body and behavior. Theories suggest that for certain people drinking has a different and stronger impact that can lead to alcohol use disorder.
Alcohol use disorder has Risk Factor: Steady drinking over time.
Alcohol use disorder has Risk Factor: People who begin drinking — especially binge drinking — at an early age are at a higher risk of alcohol use disorder.
Alcohol use disorder has Risk Factor: Family history.
Alcohol use disorder has Risk Factor: Depression and other mental health problems.
Alcohol use disorder has Risk Factor: History of trauma.
Alcohol use disorder has Risk Factor: Having bariatric surgery.
Alcohol use disorder has Risk Factor: Social and cultural factors.

Alcohol use disorder has Complication: Alcohol depresses your central nervous system. In some people, the initial reaction may feel like an increase in energy. But as you continue to drink, you become drowsy and have less control over your actions.
Alcohol use disorder has Preventio: Loss of interest in activities and hobbies and in personal appearance
Alcohol use disorder has Preventio: Red eyes, slurred speech, problems with coordination and memory lapses
Alcohol use disorder has Preventio: Difficulties or changes in relationships with friends, such as joining a new crowd
Alcohol use disorder has Preventio: Declining grades and problems in school
Alcohol use disorder has Preventio: Frequent mood changes and defensive behavior

Alcoholic hepatitis (Alcohol-associated hepatitis) has Symptom: Nausea and vomiting.
Alcoholic hepatitis (Alcohol-associated hepatitis) has Symptom: Belly tenderness.

Alcoholic hepatitis (Alcohol-associated hepatitis) has Symptom: Fever. A fever caused by alcoholic hepatitis often is only a little higher than usual. This is called a low-grade fever. However, it is important to seek medical attention to rule out an infection.
Alcoholic hepatitis (Alcohol-associated hepatitis) has Symptom: Tiredness and weakness.

Alcoholic hepatitis (Alcohol-associated hepatitis) has Symptom: Pain in the upper right part of the abdomen where the liver is located. Alcoholic hepatitis (Alcohol-associated hepatitis) has Cause: Other types of liver disease.

Alcoholic hepatitis (Alcohol-associated hepatitis) has Complication: Cirrhosis.

Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency has Symptom: AATD symptoms depend on which organs are affected and how severe the condition is. Symptoms can vary within families.
Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency has Cause: AATD is caused by a change in the SERPINA1 gene. This is the gene that tells the body to make the AAT protein.

Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency has Preventio: AATD can't be prevented. But you may be able to prevent or slow COPD. The best way to prevent COPD is to never smoke. If you smoke, quit. Stopping now can slow how fast the condition gets worse.

Alpha-gal syndrome has Cause: Most people with alpha-gal syndrome in the U.S. get the condition from lone star tick bites. Other types of ticks can cause the condition too, mainly in parts of Europe, Australia, Asia, South Africa, and South and Central America.
Alpha-gal syndrome has Risk Factor: You're at higher risk if you live or spend time in areas that have ticks that carry alpha-gal. Having more than one tick bite seems to raise the risk even more.
Alpha-gal syndrome has Complication: Tight, narrow airways.
Alpha-gal syndrome has Complication: Swelling of the throat that makes it hard to breathe.
Alpha-gal syndrome has Complication: Fast pulse.
Alpha-gal syndrome has Complication: Feeling dizzy or lightheaded, or passing out.

Alpha-gal syndrome has Preventio: Use bug spray.

Alpha-gal syndrome has Preventio: Shower as soon as you come indoors.
Alpha-gal syndrome has Preventio: Remove a tick with tweezers as soon as you can.

Alzheimer's disease has Symptom: Memory loss is the key symptom of Alzheimer's disease. Early in the disease, people may have trouble remembering recent events or conversations. Over time, memory gets worse and other symptoms occur.
Alzheimer's disease has Cause: Plaques.
Alzheimer's disease has Cause: Tangles.
Alzheimer's disease has Risk Factor: Risk factors for Alzheimer's disease include age, family history, lifestyle and other factors.
Alzheimer's disease has Complication: Tell someone about being in pain.
Alzheimer's disease has Complication: Explain symptoms of another illness.
Alzheimer's disease has Complication: Follow a treatment plan.
Alzheimer's disease has Complication: Explain medicine side effects.
Alzheimer's disease has Preventio: Exercise regularly.
Alzheimer's disease has Preventio: Eat a diet of fresh produce, healthy oils and foods low in saturated fat, such as a Mediterranean diet.

Alzheimer's disease has Preventio: Work with your healthcare professional to manage high blood pressure, diabetes and high cholesterol. Pay particular attention to your levels of low-density lipoprotein, known as LDL, cholesterol. High levels of LDL cholesterol in people younger than 65 raises the risk of dementia. But taking medicines to lower LDL cholesterol doesn't raise the risk.
Alzheimer's disease has Preventio: If you smoke, ask your healthcare professional for help to quit.

Ameloblastoma has Cause: Conventional ameloblastoma.

Ameloblastoma has Cause: Metastasizing ameloblastoma.

Ameloblastoma has Complication: Rarely, ameloblastoma can become cancerous (malignant). Very rarely, ameloblastoma cells can spread to other areas of the body (metastasize), such as the lymph nodes in the neck and lungs.

Amnesia has Cause: Tumors in areas of the brain that control memory.
Amnesia has Cause: Alzheimer's disease and related diseases that involve the loss of brain cells that are important for memory.
Amnesia has Cause: Seizures.
Amnesia has Cause: Medicine such as benzodiazepines and other medicines that act as sedatives.
Amnesia has Risk Factor: Brain surgery, head injury or head trauma.
Amnesia has Risk Factor: Stroke.
Amnesia has Risk Factor: Alcohol use disorder.
Amnesia has Risk Factor: Seizures.

Amnesia has Complication: How much amnesia affects memory is different from person to person. But even mild amnesia takes a toll on daily activities and quality of life. Amnesia can make it hard to function at work, at school and in social settings.
Amnesia has Preventio: Don't drink large amounts of alcohol.
Amnesia has Preventio: Wear a helmet when bicycling and a seat belt when driving.
Amnesia has Preventio: Treat infections quickly so that they don't have a chance to spread to the brain.
Amnesia has Preventio: Get medical treatment right away if you have symptoms that suggest a stroke or brain aneurysm, including:

Amnesia has Preventio: Feeling numb on one side of the body.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has Cause: ALSaffects the nerve cells that control voluntary muscle movements such as walking and talking. These nerve cells are called motor neurons. There are two groups of motor neurons. The first group extends from the brain to the spinal cord to muscles throughout the body. They're referred to as upper motor neurons. The second group extends from the spinal cord to muscles throughout the body. They're referred to as lower motor neurons.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has Risk Factor: Genetics.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has Risk Factor: Risk increases with age up to age 75.ALSis most common between the ages of 60 and the mid-80s.

Anal cancer has Symptom: Bleeding from the anus or rectum.
Anal cancer has Symptom: Blood in the stool.
Anal cancer has Symptom: Pain in the area of the anus.
Anal cancer has Symptom: A mass or growth in the anal canal.
Anal cancer has Symptom: Anal itching.
Anal cancer has Symptom: Having to go to the bathroom more often.

Anal cancer has Cause: Anal cancer happens when cells in the anal canal develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell a cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.
Anal cancer has Risk Factor: Being exposed to human papillomavirus, also calledHPV.
Anal cancer has Risk Factor: The greater your number of sexual partners, and the greater your partner's number of sexual partners, the greater your chance of acquiringHPV.
Anal cancer has Risk Factor: People who have receptive anal sex have an increased risk of anal cancer.
Anal cancer has Risk Factor: Smoking cigarettes.
Anal cancer has Risk Factor: Having a history of cancer.
Anal cancer has Risk Factor: Having a weak immune system.

Anal cancer has Complication: Anal cancer rarely spreads to other parts of the body. Only a small percentage of cancers are found to have spread. Those that do are especially difficult to treat. Anal cancer that spreads most commonly goes to the liver and the lungs.
Anal cancer has Preventio: There is no sure way to prevent anal cancer. To reduce your risk of anal cancer:

Anal fissure has Symptom: Pain after bowel movements that can last up to several hours.
Anal fissure has Symptom: Bright red blood on the stool or toilet paper after a bowel movement.
Anal fissure has Symptom: A visible crack in the skin around the anus.

Anal fissure has Complication: Failure to heal.
Anal fissure has Complication: Recurrence.
Anal fissure has Complication: A tear that extends to surrounding muscles.

Anal fissure has Preventio: You may be able to prevent an anal fissure by taking measures to prevent constipation or diarrhea. Eat high-fiber foods, drink fluids, and exercise regularly to keep from having to strain during bowel movements.

Anal fistula has Symptom: A red, inflamed area around the tunnel opening
Anal fistula has Symptom: Oozing of pus, blood or stool from the tunnel opening

Anal fistula has Cause: Most anal fistulas are caused by an infection that starts in an anal gland. The infection results in an abscess that drains on its own or is drained surgically through the skin next to the anus. A fistula is the tunnel that forms under the skin along this drainage tract. The tunnel connects the anal gland or anal canal to a hole in the outside skin around the anus.
Anal fistula has Risk Factor: Previously drained anal abscess
Anal fistula has Risk Factor: Crohn's disease or other inflammatory bowel disease
Anal fistula has Risk Factor: Trauma to the anal area
Anal fistula has Risk Factor: Infections of the anal area
Anal fistula has Risk Factor: Surgery or radiation for treatment of anal cancer

Anal fistula has Complication: Even with effective treatment of an anal fistula, recurrence of an abscess and an anal fistula is possible. Surgical treatment may result in the inability to hold in stool (fecal incontinence).

Anal itching has Symptom: Symptoms of anal itching may include intense itching, inflammation, burning and soreness. The itching and irritation may be short lived or more persistent, depending on the cause. Anal itching often is worse at bedtime or in hot, humid weather.
Anal itching has Cause: Irritants.
Anal itching has Cause: Infections.
Anal itching has Cause: Skin conditions.
Anal itching has Cause: Other medical conditions.

Anaphylaxis has Symptom: Anaphylaxis symptoms usually occur within minutes of exposure to an allergen. Sometimes, however, anaphylaxis can occur a half-hour or longer after exposure. In rare cases, anaphylaxis may be delayed for hours. Signs and symptoms include:

Anaphylaxis has Cause: The immune system produces antibodies that defend against foreign substances. This is good when a foreign substance is harmful, such as certain bacteria or viruses. But some people's immune systems overreact to substances that don't normally cause an allergic reaction.
Anaphylaxis has Risk Factor: There aren't many known risk factors for anaphylaxis, but some things that might increase the risk include:
Anaphylaxis has Complication: An anaphylactic reaction can be life-threatening — it can stop your breathing or your heartbeat.
Anaphylaxis has Preventio: The best way to prevent anaphylaxis is to stay away from substances that cause this severe reaction. Also:

Anemia has Cause: Bleeding causes loss of red blood cells and hemoglobin faster than they can be replaced.

Anemia has Risk Factor: Problems with the small intestine.
Anemia has Risk Factor: Menstrual periods.
Anemia has Risk Factor: Pregnancy.
Anemia has Risk Factor: Ongoing, called chronic, conditions.

Anemia has Risk Factor: Other factors.

Anemia has Complication: Severe tiredness.
Anemia has Complication: Pregnancy complications.
Anemia has Complication: Heart problems.
Anemia has Complication: Death.

Angelman syndrome has Symptom: Trouble going to sleep and staying asleep.

Angelman syndrome has Cause: Angelman syndrome is caused by changes in a gene, called a genetic change. It's most often caused by changes in a gene on chromosome 15 called the ubiquitin protein ligase E3A (UBE3A) gene.

Angelman syndrome has Risk Factor: Angelman syndrome is rare. Researchers often don't know what causes the genetic changes that result in the disease. Most people with Angelman syndrome don't have a family history.

Your healthcare professional or a genetic counselor can help you plan future pregnancies.

Angina has Cause: Angina is caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. Blood carries oxygen, which the heart muscle needs to survive. When the heart muscle isn't getting enough oxygen, it causes a condition called ischemia.
Angina has Risk Factor: Angina is most common in adults age 60 and older.

Ankylosing spondylitis has Symptom: Early symptoms of ankylosing spondylitis might include back pain and stiffness in the lower back and hips, especially in the morning and after periods of inactivity. Neck pain and fatigue also are common. Over time, symptoms might worsen, improve or stop at irregular intervals.

Ankylosing spondylitis has Cause: Ankylosing spondylitis has no known specific cause, though genetic factors seem to be involved. In particular, people who have a gene calledHLA-B27are at a greatly increased risk of developing ankylosing spondylitis. However, only some people with the gene develop the condition.

Ankylosing spondylitis has Risk Factor: Onset generally occurs in late adolescence or early adulthood. Most people who have ankylosing spondylitis have theHLA-B27gene. But many people who have this gene never develop ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis has Complication: In severe ankylosing spondylitis, new bone forms as part of the body's attempt to heal. This new bone gradually bridges the gap between vertebrae and eventually fuses sections of vertebrae. Those parts of the spine become stiff and inflexible. Fusion also can stiffen the rib cage, restricting lung capacity and function.

Anorexia nervosa has Symptom: The physical and behavioral symptoms of anorexia nervosa relate to how starvation affects the brain. It may be hard to notice symptoms because what is seen as a low body weight differs for each person. Some people with anorexia may not look very thin. Also, people often hide their thinness, eating habits or physical problems.
Anorexia nervosa has Cause: Genetics.
Anorexia nervosa has Cause: Mental health.
Anorexia nervosa has Cause: Environmental.
Anorexia nervosa has Risk Factor: Family history.
Anorexia nervosa has Risk Factor: A history of weight bullying.
Anorexia nervosa has Risk Factor: A history of dieting.
Anorexia nervosa has Risk Factor: Transitions.
Anorexia nervosa has Complication: Anemia.

Anorexia nervosa has Complication: Other heart conditions, such as mitral valve prolapse or heart failure. Mitral valve prolapse happens when the valve between the heart's upper and lower left chambers doesn't close properly.
Anorexia nervosa has Complication: Bone loss, also known as osteoporosis, which can raise the risk of fractures.
Anorexia nervosa has Complication: Loss of muscle.
Anorexia nervosa has Complication: Stomach problems, such as constipation, bloating or nausea.
Anorexia nervosa has Complication: Kidney problems.

Anorexia nervosa has Preventio: There's no guaranteed way to prevent anorexia nervosa. Primary healthcare professionals, including pediatricians, family medicine professionals and internal medicine professionals, may be in a good position to see early signs that could lead to anorexia. For instance, they can ask questions about eating habits and satisfaction with appearance during routine medical appointments. This could open a discussion about how this relates to health and where to get help if needed.

Anorgasmia in women has Symptom: Absence of orgasm.
Anorgasmia in women has Symptom: Fewer orgasms.

Anterior vaginal prolapse (cystocele) has Risk Factor: Obesity.

Severe dehydration can be life-threatening. Signs and symptoms include a very dry mouth, intense thirst, little or no urination, dizziness, and weakness.

Antiphospholipid syndrome has Cause: Antiphospholipid syndrome occurs when the immune system mistakenly produces antibodies that make blood much more likely to clot. Antibodies usually protect the body against invaders, such as viruses and bacteria.

Antisocial personality disorder has Symptom: Doing dangerous things with no regard for the safety of self or others.
Antisocial personality disorder has Symptom: Being irresponsible and failing to fulfill work or financial responsibilities.

It may help to try to identify those most at risk, such as children who show signs of conduct disorder, and then offer early intervention.

Aphasia has Symptom: Aphasia is a symptom of some other condition, such as a stroke or a brain tumor.

Aphasia has Cause: The most common cause of aphasia is brain damage resulting from a stroke — the blockage or rupture of a blood vessel in the brain. Loss of blood to the brain leads to brain cell death or damage in areas that control language.
Aphasia has Complication: Aphasia can create numerous quality-of-life problems because communication is so much a part of your life. Communication difficulty may affect your:
Aplastic anemia has Symptom: Aplastic anemia can have no symptoms. When present, symptoms can include:

Aplastic anemia has Cause: Bone marrow is a red, spongy material inside your bones. Stem cells in the bone marrow make blood cells — red cells, white cells and platelets. In aplastic anemia, stem cells are damaged. As a result, the bone marrow makes fewer new blood cells.
Aplastic anemia has Risk Factor: Aplastic anemia is rare. Factors that can increase risk include:

Aplastic anemia has Preventio: There's no known prevention for most cases of aplastic anemia. Avoiding exposure to insecticides, herbicides, organic solvents, paint removers and other toxic chemicals might lower your risk of the disease.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Sudden pain that begins on the right side of the lower belly.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Sudden pain that begins around the belly button and often shifts to the lower right belly.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Pain that worsens with coughing, walking or making other jarring movements.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Nausea and vomiting.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Loss of appetite.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Low-grade fever that may rise as the illness worsens.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Constipation or diarrhea.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Belly bloating.
Appendicitis has Symptom: Gas.

Appendicitis has Cause: A blockage in the lining of the appendix, called the lumen, is the likely cause of appendicitis. This blockage can cause an infection. The bacteria then multiply quickly, causing the appendix to become inflamed, swollen and filled with pus. If not treated right away, the appendix may burst or break open.
Appendicitis has Risk Factor: Age. Anyone can develop appendicitis, but it most often happens in people between the ages of 10 and 30.
Appendicitis has Risk Factor: Your sex. Men have a slightly higher risk of appendicitis than do women.
Appendicitis has Complication: A burst appendix.
Appendicitis has Complication: A pocket of pus that forms in the abdomen.

ARDS has Cause: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
ARDS has Cause: Head, chest or other major injury.
ARDS has Cause: Breathing in harmful substances.
ARDS has Cause: Other conditions and treatments.

People are especially at risk if they have an infection, such as sepsis or pneumonia. They're also at higher risk if they have COVID-19, especially if they also have metabolic syndrome.

ARDS has Complication: Collapsed lung, also called pneumothorax.
ARDS has Complication: Infections.

Arteriovenous fistula has Symptom: Small arteriovenous fistulas in the legs, arms, lungs, kidneys or brain often won't have any signs or symptoms. Small arteriovenous fistulas usually don't need treatment other than monitoring by a health care provider. Large arteriovenous fistulas may cause signs and symptoms.
Arteriovenous fistula has Cause: Arteriovenous fistulas may be present at birth (congenital) or they may occur later in life (acquired). Causes of arteriovenous fistulas include:
Arteriovenous fistula has Risk Factor: Certain genetic or congenital conditions increase the risk of arteriovenous fistulas. Other potential risk factors for arteriovenous fistulas include:
Arteriovenous fistula has Complication: Left untreated, an arteriovenous fistula can cause complications. Some complications may be serious. These include:

Arteriovenous malformation has Symptom: Headaches.
Arteriovenous malformation has Symptom: Nausea and vomiting.
Arteriovenous malformation has Symptom: Seizures.
Arteriovenous malformation has Symptom: Loss of consciousness.

Arteriovenous malformation has Cause: An arteriovenous malformation happens when arteries and veins connect in an irregular way. Experts don't understand why this happens. Certain genetic changes might play a role, but most types are not usually passed down in families.
Arteriovenous malformation has Risk Factor: Rarely, having a family history of an arteriovenous malformation can increase your risk. But most types aren't inherited.

Arteriovenous malformation has Complication: The most common complications of an arteriovenous malformation are bleeding and seizures. Bleeding can cause brain damage and may cause death if you don't get treated.

Arthritis has Symptom: Decreased range of motion
Arthritis has Cause: The two main types of arthritis — osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis — damage joints in different ways.
Arthritis has Risk Factor: Family history.
Arthritis has Risk Factor: The risk of many types of arthritis — including osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis and gout — increases with age.
Arthritis has Risk Factor: Women are more likely than men to develop rheumatoid arthritis, while most of the people who have gout, another type of arthritis, are men.
Arthritis has Risk Factor: Previous joint injury.
Arthritis has Risk Factor: Obesity.

Arthritis has Complication: Severe arthritis, particularly if it affects your hands or arms, can make it difficult for you to do daily tasks. Arthritis of weight-bearing joints can keep you from walking comfortably or sitting up straight. In some cases, joints may gradually lose their alignment and shape.
Asbestosis has Symptom: The effects of long-term exposure to asbestos typically don't show up until 10-40 years after initial exposure. Symptoms can vary in severity.

Asbestosis has Cause: If you are exposed to high levels of asbestos dust over a long period of time, some of the airborne fibers can become lodged within your alveoli — the tiny sacs inside your lungs where oxygen is exchanged for carbon dioxide in your blood. The asbestos fibers irritate and scar lung tissue, causing the lungs to become stiff. This makes it difficult to breathe.

Asbestosis has Risk Factor: People who worked in mining, milling, manufacturing, and installation or removal of asbestos products before the late 1970s are at highest risk of asbestosis. Examples include:

Asbestosis has Complication: If you have asbestosis, you're at increased risk of developing lung cancer — especially if you smoke or have a history of smoking. Rarely, malignant mesothelioma, a cancer of the tissue around the lung, can occur many years after exposure to asbestos.

Asbestosis has Preventio: Reducing exposure to asbestos is the best prevention against asbestosis. In the United States, federal law requires employers in industries that work with asbestos products — such as construction — to take special safety measures.
Aspergillosis has Symptom: The symptoms of aspergillosis depend on the type of illness you develop:
Aspergillosis has Cause: Aspergillus mold is unavoidable. Outdoors, it's found in soil, decaying leaves and compost. It's also found on plants, trees and grain crops.

Aspergillosis has Risk Factor: Your risk of developing aspergillosis depends on your overall health and the extent of your exposure to mold. In general, these factors make you more vulnerable to infection:
Aspergillosis has Complication: Depending on the type of infection, aspergillosis can cause a variety of serious complications:

Aspergillosis has Preventio: It's nearly impossible to avoid exposure to aspergillus. If you have had a transplant or are undergoing chemotherapy, try to stay away from places where you're likely to encounter mold. Places may include construction sites, compost piles and buildings that store grain. If you have a weakened immune system, your healthcare professional may advise you to wear a face mask to avoid being exposed to aspergillus and other airborne infectious agents.

Asthma has Symptom: Coughing or wheezing attacks that are worsened by a respiratory virus, such as a cold or the flu

Athlete's foot has Cause: Athlete's foot is caused by the same type of fungi (dermatophytes) that cause ringworm and jock itch. Damp socks and shoes and warm, humid conditions favor the organisms' growth.

It's common for the infection to spread from the feet to the groin because the fungus can travel on hands or towels.

Atypical hyperplasia of the breast has Preventio: It's not clear whether there's anything that can prevent atypical hyperplasia of the breast. The same things that help lower the risk of breast cancer may help lower the risk of atypical hyperplasia. Things you can do to lower your risk of breast cancer include:

Autism spectrum disorder has Symptom: Some children show signs of autism spectrum disorder in early infancy, such as less eye contact, not responding to their names or not being interested in caregivers. Other children may not develop as expected for the first few months or years of life. Then they suddenly become withdrawn or aggressive or lose the language skills they had before. Signs usually are seen by ages 2 to 3 years old.
Autism spectrum disorder has Cause: Genetics.
Autism spectrum disorder has Cause: Environmental factors.

Autism spectrum disorder has Risk Factor: Boys are about four times more likely to be diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder than girls are. While boys may get autism spectrum disorder more often than girls, it's possible that some girls aren't diagnosed.
Autism spectrum disorder has Risk Factor: Family history.
Autism spectrum disorder has Risk Factor: Other conditions.
Autism spectrum disorder has Risk Factor: Early birth.
Autism spectrum disorder has Risk Factor: There may be a connection between children born to older parents and autism spectrum disorder. But more research is needed to show this link.
Autism spectrum disorder has Complication: School and learning.
Autism spectrum disorder has Complication: Getting a job.
Autism spectrum disorder has Complication: Not being able to live on their own.
Autism spectrum disorder has Complication: Being isolated socially.
Autism spectrum disorder has Complication: Stress within the family.
Autism spectrum disorder has Complication: Being a victim and being bullied.

Autism spectrum disorder has Preventio: There's no known way to prevent autism spectrum disorder. But many studies have been done to see if taking folic acid and other vitamins before and during pregnancy can lower the risk of having a baby with autism spectrum disorder. A review of studies on what are known as prenatal vitamins shows no clear answer. This is due to the quality of the research. More high-quality studies are needed.

Autoimmune encephalitis has Risk Factor: Having had herpes simplex virus encephalitis.
Autoimmune encephalitis has Risk Factor: Taking monoclonal antibodies or medicines to suppress the immune system after a transplant.

Autoimmune hepatitis has Cause: Autoimmune hepatitis occurs when the body's immune system, which usually attacks viruses, bacteria and other causes of disease, instead targets the liver. This attack on the liver can lead to long-lasting inflammation and serious damage to liver cells. Just why the body turns against itself is unclear, but researchers think autoimmune hepatitis could be caused by the interaction of genes controlling immune system function and exposure to viruses or medicines.

Autoimmune pancreatitis has Symptom: Loss of appetite or feelings of fullness.

Bacterial vaginosis has Cause: Bacterial vaginosis happens when the vagina's natural bacteria levels are out of balance. The bacteria in the vagina are called the vaginal flora. Balanced vaginal flora help keep the vagina healthy. Usually "good" bacteria outnumber "bad" bacteria. The good bacteria are called lactobacilli; the bad bacteria are anaerobes. When there are too many anaerobes, they upset the balance of the flora, causing bacterial vaginosis.

Bartholin's cyst has Preventio: There's no way to prevent a Bartholin's cyst. However, safer sex practices — in particular, using condoms — and good hygiene habits may help to prevent infection of a cyst and the formation of an abscess.

Basal cell carcinoma has Symptom: Basal cell carcinoma usually occurs on parts of the body that get a lot of sun, especially the head and neck. Less often, basal cell carcinoma can develop on parts of the body usually protected from the sun, such as the genitals.

Basal cell carcinoma has Cause: Basal cell carcinoma starts in basal cells in the skin. Basal cells are found at the bottom of the outermost layer of skin, which is called the epidermis. Basal cells create new skin cells. As new skin cells form, they push older cells toward the skin's surface, where the old cells die and are sloughed off.

B-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Fatigue.

B-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Loss of appetite.

B-cell lymphoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes B-cell lymphomas. Cancer happens when cells develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the DNA changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.
B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: A family history of lymphoma.
B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: A weakened immune system or an autoimmune condition.
B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: Some infections.
B-cell lymphoma has Complication: Relapse.
B-cell lymphoma has Complication: Transformation.

Bladder cancer has Cause: Bladder cancer begins when cells in the bladder develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. A cell's DNA contains instructions that tell the cell what to do. The changes tell the cell to multiply rapidly and to go on living when healthy cells would die. The abnormal cells form a tumor that can invade and destroy normal body tissue. In time, the abnormal cells can break away and spread (metastasize) through the body.

Like many other mental health conditions, body dysmorphic disorder may result from a combination of issues, such as a family history of the disorder, negative evaluations or experiences about your body or self-image, and abnormal brain function or abnormal levels of the brain chemical called serotonin.

Body lice has Symptom: Body lice bites can cause intense itching, and you may notice small areas of blood and crust on your skin at the site of the bite marks.

Body lice has Cause: Body lice are similar to head lice but have different habits. While head lice live in your hair and feed on your scalp, body lice usually live in your clothes and bedding. They travel to your skin several times a day to feed on blood.
Body lice has Risk Factor: People who are at higher risk of body lice tend to live in crowded, unclean conditions. They include:
Body lice has Complication: Body lice infestations usually cause minimal problems. However, a body lice infestation sometimes leads to complications such as:

Body lice has Preventio: To prevent body lice infestation, avoid having close physical contact or sharing bedding or clothing with anyone who has an infestation. Regular bathing and changing into clean clothing at least once a week also may help prevent and control the spread of body lice.

Boils and carbuncles has Cause: Most boils are caused by Staphylococcus aureus, a type of bacterium commonly found on the skin and inside the nose. A bump forms as pus collects under the skin. Boils sometimes develop at sites where the skin has been broken by a small injury or an insect bite, which gives the bacteria easy entry.

The spreading infection, commonly known as blood poisoning (sepsis), can lead to infections deep within your body, such as your heart (endocarditis) and bone (osteomyelitis).
Boils and carbuncles has Preventio: It's not always possible to prevent boils, especially if you have a weakened immune system. But the following measures may help you avoid staph infections:
Bone cancer has Symptom: Bone pain.

Bone cancer has Cause: The cause of most bone cancers isn't known. Bone cancer starts when cells in or near a bone develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the DNA changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.
Bone cancer has Risk Factor: Inherited genetic syndromes.
Bone cancer has Risk Factor: Other bone conditions.
Bone cancer has Risk Factor: Cancer treatment.

Bone metastasis has Risk Factor: Some types of cancer have a higher risk of causing bone metastasis than others do. Cancers more likely to spread to the bones include:
Bone spurs has Symptom: Knee.
Bone spurs has Symptom: Spine.
Bone spurs has Symptom: Hip.

Bone spurs has Cause: Joint damage from osteoarthritis is the most common cause of bone spurs. Osteoarthritis breaks down connective tissue called cartilage that cushions the ends of bones. While this happens, the body tries to repair the loss by creating bone spurs near the damaged area.
Bone spurs has Risk Factor: The risk of bone spurs is higher in people who have arthritis.

Borderline personality disorder has Symptom: Threats of suicide or self-injury, often in response to fears of separation or rejection.

Borderline personality disorder has Symptom: Wide mood swings that last from a few hours to a few days. These mood swings can include periods of being very happy, irritable or anxious, or feeling shame.

Borderline personality disorder has Symptom: Inappropriate, strong anger, such as losing your temper often, being sarcastic or bitter, or physically fighting.

Botulism has Symptom: Symptoms of foodborne botulism typically begin 12 to 36 hours after the toxin gets into your body. But depending on how much toxin you consumed, the start of symptoms may range from a few hours to a few days.

Botulism has Cause: The typical source of foodborne botulism is homemade food that is improperly canned or preserved. These foods are typically fruits, vegetables, and fish. Other foods, such as spicy peppers (chiles), foil-wrapped baked potatoes and oil infused with garlic, may also be sources of botulism.
Botulism has Complication: Difficulty speaking
Botulism has Complication: Trouble swallowing
Botulism has Complication: Long-lasting weakness
Botulism has Complication: Shortness of breath

Brain aneurysm has Symptom: Most brain aneurysms that haven't ruptured don't cause symptoms, especially if they're small. Brain aneurysms may be found during imaging tests that are done for other conditions.

Brain aneurysm has Cause: Brain aneurysms are caused by thinning artery walls. Aneurysms often form at forks or branches in arteries because those areas of the vessels are weaker. Although aneurysms can happen anywhere in the brain, they're most common in arteries at the base of the brain.
Brain aneurysm has Risk Factor: Brain aneurysms can happen at any age. However, they're more common in adults between ages 30 and 60.
Brain aneurysm has Risk Factor: Being female.
Brain aneurysm has Risk Factor: Cigarette smoking.
Brain aneurysm has Risk Factor: High blood pressure.

Brain aneurysm has Risk Factor: Inherited connective tissue conditions,

Brain aneurysm has Complication: Re-bleeding.
Brain aneurysm has Complication: Narrowed blood vessels in the brain.
Brain aneurysm has Complication: A buildup of fluid within the brain, known as hydrocephalus.
Brain aneurysm has Complication: Change in sodium level.

Brain aneurysm has Preventio: In many cases, brain aneurysms can't be prevented. But there are some changes you can make to lower your risk. They include quitting smoking if you smoke. Brain tumor has Symptom: Trouble with balance.

Brain tumor has Symptom: Having trouble following simple commands.

Brain tumor has Symptom: Seizures, especially if there is no history of seizures.
Brain tumor has Symptom: Hearing problems.
Brain tumor has Symptom: Dizziness or a sense that the world is spinning, also called vertigo.
Brain tumor has Symptom: Feeling very hungry and gaining weight.

Brain tumor has Cause: Brain tumors that start as a growth of cells in the brain are called primary brain tumors. They might start right in the brain or in the tissue nearby. Nearby tissue includes the membranes that cover the brain, called meninges. Brain tumors also can happen in nerves, the pituitary gland and the pineal gland.
Brain tumor has Risk Factor: Brain tumors can happen at any age, but they happen most often in older adults. Some brain tumors mostly affect adults. Some brain tumors happen most often in children.
Brain tumor has Risk Factor: Race.
Brain tumor has Risk Factor: Exposure to radiation.
Brain tumor has Risk Factor: Inherited syndromes that increase the risk of brain tumor.

Breast cancer has Symptom: A breast lump or thickened area of skin that feels different from the surrounding tissue.
Breast cancer has Symptom: A nipple that looks flattened or turns inward.

Breast cancer has Symptom: Changes in the color of the breast skin. In people with white skin, the breast skin may look pink or red. In people with brown and Black skin, the breast skin may look darker than the other skin on the chest or it may look red or purple.
Breast cancer has Symptom: Change in the size, shape or appearance of a breast.
Breast cancer has Symptom: Changes to the skin over the breast, such as skin that looks dimpled or looks like an orange peel.
Breast cancer has Symptom: Peeling, scaling, crusting or flaking of the skin on the breast.

Breast cancer has Cause: The exact cause of most breast cancers isn't known. Researchers have found things that increase the risk of breast cancer. These include hormones, lifestyle choices and things in the environment. But it's not clear why some people who don't have any factors get cancer, yet others with risk factors never do. It's likely that breast cancer happens through a complex interaction of your genetic makeup and the world around you.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: A family history of breast cancer.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: A personal history of breast cancer.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: A personal history of breast conditions.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Beginning your period before age 12 increases your risk of breast cancer.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Beginning menopause after age 55 increases the risk of breast cancer.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Being female.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Dense breast tissue.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Drinking alcohol.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Giving birth to your first child after age 30 may increase the risk of breast cancer.

Breast cancer has Risk Factor: The risk of breast cancer goes up as you get older.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Inherited DNA changes that increase cancer risk.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Menopausal hormone therapy.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Obesity.
Breast cancer has Risk Factor: Radiation exposure.

Breast pain has Symptom: Breast pain can be cyclic or noncyclic. Cyclic means that the pain occurs on a regular pattern. Noncyclic means that the pain is constant, or that there's not a regular pattern. Each type of breast pain has distinct characteristics.

Breast pain has Cause: Changing hormone levels can cause changes in the milk ducts or milk glands. These changes in the ducts and glands can cause breast cysts, which can be painful and are a common cause of cyclic breast pain. Noncyclic breast pain may be caused by trauma, prior breast surgery or other factors.
Breast pain has Risk Factor: Breast size.
Breast pain has Risk Factor: Breast surgery.
Breast pain has Risk Factor: Fatty acid imbalance.

Bronchiolitis has Symptom: Runny nose.
Bronchiolitis has Symptom: Stuffy nose.
Bronchiolitis has Symptom: Cough.
Bronchiolitis has Symptom: Sometimes a slight fever.

Bronchiolitis has Cause: Bronchiolitis happens when a virus infects the bronchioles, which are the smallest airways in the lungs. The infection makes the bronchioles swollen and irritated. Mucus collects in these airways, which makes it difficult for air to flow freely in and out of the lungs.
Bronchiolitis has Risk Factor: Being born too early.
Bronchiolitis has Risk Factor: Having a heart or lung condition.
Bronchiolitis has Risk Factor: Having a weakened immune system. This makes it hard to fight infections.
Bronchiolitis has Risk Factor: Being around tobacco smoke.
Bronchiolitis has Risk Factor: Contact with lots of other children, such as in a child care setting.
Bronchiolitis has Risk Factor: Spending time in crowded places.
Bronchiolitis has Risk Factor: Having siblings who go to school or get child care services and bring home the infection.
Bronchiolitis has Complication: Low oxygen in the body.
Bronchiolitis has Complication: Pauses in breathing, which is most likely to happen in babies born too early and in babies under 2 months old.
Bronchiolitis has Complication: Not being able to drink enough liquids. This can cause dehydration, when too much body fluid is lost.
Bronchiolitis has Complication: Not being able to get the amount of oxygen needed. This is called respiratory failure.
Bronchiolitis has Preventio: Limit contact with people who have a fever or cold.
Bronchiolitis has Preventio: Clean and disinfect surfaces.
Bronchiolitis has Preventio: Wash hands often.
Bronchiolitis has Preventio: Cover coughs and sneezes.
Bronchiolitis has Preventio: Use your own drinking glass.
Bronchiolitis has Preventio: Breastfeed, when possible.

Bronchitis has Symptom: Production of mucus (sputum), which can be clear, white, yellowish-gray or green in color — rarely, it may be streaked with blood
Bronchitis has Symptom: Sore throat
Bronchitis has Symptom: Mild headache and body aches
Bronchitis has Symptom: Slight fever and chills
Bronchitis has Symptom: Fatigue
Bronchitis has Symptom: Chest discomfort
Bronchitis has Symptom: Shortness of breath and wheezing

Bronchitis has Cause: Acute bronchitis is usually caused by viruses, typically the same viruses that cause colds and flu (influenza). Many different viruses — all of which are very contagious — can cause acute bronchitis. Antibiotics don't kill viruses, so this type of medication isn't useful in most cases of bronchitis.
Bronchitis has Risk Factor: Cigarette smoke.
Bronchitis has Risk Factor: Low resistance.
Bronchitis has Risk Factor: Exposure to irritants on the job.
Bronchitis has Risk Factor: Gastric reflux.

Bronchitis has Complication: Although a single episode of bronchitis usually isn't cause for concern, it can lead to pneumonia in some people. Repeated bouts of bronchitis, however, may mean that you have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
Bronchitis has Preventio: Get an annual flu shot.
Bronchitis has Preventio: Wash your hands.
Bronchitis has Preventio: Avoid close contact with people who have a viral infection.
Bronchitis has Preventio: Avoid cigarette smoke.
Bronchitis has Preventio: Wear appropriate face covering.
