Brucellosis has Cause: Brucellosis bacteria are carried by many animals. The bacteria may or may not cause animals to be sick. Some that carry bacteria that can infect humans, include:
Brucellosis has Risk Factor: Brucellosis is rare in the United States. But it's more common in other parts of the world, especially:

Brucellosis has Complication: Brucellosis can affect almost any part of the body, including the reproductive system, liver, heart and central nervous system. Long-term, called chronic, brucellosis may cause complications in just one organ or through the body. Possible complications include:
Brucellosis has Preventio: To reduce the risk of getting brucellosis, take these precautions:
Brugada syndrome has Symptom: Brugada syndrome often doesn't cause any noticeable symptoms. Many people with Brugada syndrome don't know they have it.

Brugada syndrome has Cause: Brugada syndrome is a heart rhythm disorder. Each beat of the heart is triggered by an electrical signal made by special cells in the right upper chamber of the heart. Tiny pores, called channels, on each of these cells direct this electrical activity, which makes the heart beat.
Brugada syndrome has Risk Factor: Risk factors for Brugada syndrome include:
Brugada syndrome has Complication: Complications of Brugada syndrome require emergency medical care. Brugada syndrome complications include:
Brugada syndrome has Preventio: If someone in your family has Brugada syndrome, genetic testing can be done to determine if you have, or are at risk of, the condition.
Buerger disease has Symptom: Tingling or numbness in the fingers or toes.
Buerger disease has Symptom: Changes in skin color in the hands and feet. The skin may look pale gray, red or blue. Depending on your skin color, these color changes may be harder or easier to see.

Buerger disease has Symptom: Fingers and toes that turn white then blue when exposed to cold, known as Raynaud's disease. Depending on your skin color, these color changes may be harder or easier to see.
Buerger disease has Symptom: Pain in the feet that occurs with walking. The pain may make it difficult to walk long distances.
Buerger disease has Symptom: Painful open sores on fingers and toes. Pain in the fingers and toes may become severe and occur at rest.
Buerger disease has Symptom: Inflammation of a vein just below the skin's surface, due to a blood clot in the vein.

Buerger disease has Cause: The exact cause of Buerger disease is unknown. The condition is strongly linked to tobacco use. It's thought that chemicals in tobacco may hurt the lining of the blood vessels.

Buerger disease has Risk Factor: The biggest risk factor for Buerger disease is smoking or using any type of tobacco. The disease can occur in people who smoke cigarettes, use cigars and chew tobacco. The rates of Buerger disease are highest in areas of the Mediterranean, Middle East and Asia where heavy smoking is most common.

Buerger disease has Complication: Buerger disease decreases blood flow to the hands and feet. As the disease gets worse, the skin and tissue in the affected areas do not get enough blood. This can cause painful open sores that do not heal. The sores may lead to a complication called gangrene.
Buerger disease has Preventio: Nearly everyone who has Buerger disease has smoked or used some form of tobacco. To prevent Buerger disease, it's important to not use tobacco.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Living in fear of gaining weight and trying to lose weight in unhealthy ways.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Repeatedly eating unusually large amounts of food in one sitting.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Feeling a loss of control during binge eating. You may feel like you can't stop eating or can't control what you eat.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Vomiting on purpose or exercising to extremes after binge eating so that you don't gain weight.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Using medicines that make you urinate, called water pills or diuretics, or laxatives or enemas to pass stool when they're not needed.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Fasting, limiting calories or not eating certain foods between binges.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Using dietary supplements or herbal products for weight loss. These products can be dangerous.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Being very unhappy with your body shape and weight.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Letting your body shape and weight guide how you feel about yourself and your worth.
Bulimia nervosa has Symptom: Having extreme mood swings.

Bulimia nervosa has Cause: The exact cause of bulimia is not known. Genes may play a role in the development of bulimia and other eating disorders. Emotional health and family history may play a role. Also, pressures from society to be thin may play a role.
Bulimia nervosa has Risk Factor: Family history and genes.
Bulimia nervosa has Risk Factor: Mental health and emotional issues.
Bulimia nervosa has Risk Factor: Dieting.
Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Not seeing yourself as worthy and feeling hopeless or even suicidal.
Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Problems getting along with others or being socially isolated.
Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Poor nutrition.
Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Not drinking enough fluids, which can lead to major medical problems, such as kidney failure.
Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Heart problems, such as an irregular heartbeat or heart failure.
Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Severe tooth decay and gum disease.
Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Not having a period or not having a period on a regular schedule.

Bulimia nervosa has Complication: Gastrointestinal problems, including tears in the tube that carries food, or a hole in your stomach or small intestine. You also could have rectal prolapse, which is when part of the large intestine slips outside the anus.

Bulimia nervosa has Preventio: Promote and support a healthy body image in your children, no matter what their size or shape. Help them become more confident in many parts of their personality, not just how they look.
Bulimia nervosa has Preventio: Have regular, enjoyable family meals.
Bulimia nervosa has Preventio: Don't talk about weight or shape at home.

Bulimia nervosa has Preventio: Discourage dieting. This is especially important when it involves unhealthy weight-control behaviors, such as fasting, labeling foods as good or bad, using weight-loss supplements or laxatives, or vomiting.
Bulimia nervosa has Preventio: Talk with your primary healthcare professional to look for early signs of an eating problem.

Bulimia nervosa has Preventio: If you notice a loved one or friend who seems to have food issues that could lead to or suggest an eating disorder, think about talking to the person about these issues and ask how you can help. If you do so, be supportive.
Bullous pemphigoid has Symptom: Itching, which can start weeks or months before blisters form.

Bullous pemphigoid has Symptom: Large blisters that don't break easily, often found along skin folds. On brown and Black skin the blisters may be dark pink, brown or black. On white skin they may be yellow, pink or red.
Bullous pemphigoid has Symptom: Pain.
Bullous pemphigoid has Symptom: A rash.
Bullous pemphigoid has Symptom: Small blisters or sores in the mouth or other mucous membranes. This is a symptom of a rare type of the disease called mucous membrane pemphigoid.
Bullous pemphigoid has Cause: Medicines.
Bullous pemphigoid has Cause: Light and radiation treatments.
Bullous pemphigoid has Cause: Medical conditions.

Bullous pemphigoid has Risk Factor: Bullous pemphigoid is most common in people over age 60, and the risk increases with age. The condition can be life-threatening for older people who have other conditions at the same time.
Bullous pemphigoid has Complication: Infection.

Bullous pemphigoid has Complication: Changes in skin color after the affected skin heals. This change in skin color is called post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation when the skin darkens and post-inflammatory hypopigmentation when the skin loses color. People with brown or Black skin have a higher risk of long-term skin color changes.
Bullous pemphigoid has Complication: Side effects from the medicine used to treat bullous pemphigoid.
Bundle branch block has Symptom: In most people, bundle branch block doesn't cause symptoms. Some people with the condition don't know they have bundle branch block.

Bundle branch block has Cause: Electrical impulses within the heart muscle cause it to beat (contract). These impulses travel along a pathway, including two branches called the right and the left bundles. If one or both of these branch bundles are damaged — due to a heart attack, for example — the electrical impulses can become blocked. As a result, the heart beats irregularly.
Bundle branch block has Risk Factor: Risk factors for bundle branch block include:

Bundle branch block has Complication: If both the right and the left bundles are blocked, the main complication is a complete blockage of the electric signaling from the upper to the lower chambers of the heart. The lack of signaling can slow the heart rate. A slowed heart rate may lead to fainting, irregular heart rhythms and other serious complications.
Bunions has Symptom: The symptoms of a bunion include:
Bunions has Cause: Many theories exist about how bunions form. But the exact cause isn't clear. Factors likely include:
Bunions has Risk Factor: These factors might raise the risk of bunions:
Bunions has Complication: Bunions can lead to health problems that include:

Bunions has Preventio: To help prevent bunions, choose shoes carefully. They should be supportive and have a wide toe box — no pointy toes. There also should be space between the tip of your longest toe and the end of the shoe.
Burkitt lymphoma has Symptom: A fast-growing tumor in the lymph nodes or other parts of the body, such as the jaw.
Burkitt lymphoma has Symptom: Painless swelling in the neck, armpit or groin.
Burkitt lymphoma has Symptom: Fatigue.
Burkitt lymphoma has Symptom: Fever.
Burkitt lymphoma has Symptom: Night sweats.
Burkitt lymphoma has Symptom: Losing weight without trying.
Burkitt lymphoma has Symptom: Feeling full quickly.

Burkitt lymphoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes Burkitt lymphoma. This cancer starts in a type of white blood cell that fights infections, called a B cell, also known as a B lymphocyte. In Burkitt lymphoma, gene changes cause the cell's DNA to rearrange. This is known as translocation. Translocation causes the B lymphocytes to turn into cancer cells. The cancer cells can build up in different areas of the body and cause tumors.
Burkitt lymphoma has Risk Factor: Endemic and sporadic Burkitt lymphomas are more common in children.
Burkitt lymphoma has Risk Factor: Certain infections.
Burkitt lymphoma has Risk Factor: A weakened immune system.
Burkitt lymphoma has Risk Factor: A family history of lymphoma.

Burkitt lymphoma has Complication: A complication of Burkitt lymphoma is the risk of the cancer coming back. Even after successful treatment, Burkitt lymphoma may come back. This is called a relapse. The risk of relapse is higher in people with cancer of the central nervous system. For people who have relapsed, the prognosis is much worse.
Burning mouth syndrome has Symptom: A burning or scalding feeling that most commonly affects your tongue, but also may affect your lips, gums, roof of your mouth, throat or whole mouth.
Burning mouth syndrome has Symptom: A feeling of dry mouth with increased thirst.
Burning mouth syndrome has Symptom: Taste changes in your mouth, such as a bitter or metallic taste.
Burning mouth syndrome has Symptom: Loss of taste.
Burning mouth syndrome has Symptom: Tingling, stinging or numbness in your mouth.
Burning mouth syndrome has Cause: The cause of burning mouth syndrome may be primary or secondary.
Burning mouth syndrome has Risk Factor: Female.
Burning mouth syndrome has Risk Factor: In perimenopause or you're postmenopausal.
Burning mouth syndrome has Risk Factor: Over the age of 50.
Burning mouth syndrome has Risk Factor: A smoker.

Burning mouth syndrome has Complication: Complications that burning mouth syndrome may cause are mainly related to discomfort, such as problems falling asleep or difficulty eating. Long-term cases involving a lot of discomfort also could lead to anxiety or depression.

Burning mouth syndrome has Preventio: There's no known way to prevent burning mouth syndrome. But you may be able to reduce your discomfort by not using tobacco, limiting acidic or spicy foods, not drinking carbonated beverages, and using stress management methods. Or these measures may prevent your discomfort from feeling worse.
Burns has Symptom: First-degree burn, also called superficial burn.
Burns has Symptom: Second-degree burn, also called partial-thickness burn.
Burns has Symptom: Third-degree burn, also called full-thickness burn.
Burns has Cause: Fire.
Burns has Cause: Hot liquid or steam.
Burns has Cause: Hot metal, glass or other objects.
Burns has Cause: Electrical currents.
Burns has Cause: Nonsolar radiation, such as that from X-rays.
Burns has Cause: Sunlight or other sources of ultraviolet radiation, such as tanning beds.
Burns has Cause: Chemicals such as strong acids, lye, paint thinner or gasoline.
Burns has Cause: Abuse.
Burns has Risk Factor: Workplace factors.
Burns has Risk Factor: Dementia.
Burns has Risk Factor: Being young.
Burns has Risk Factor: Alcohol.
Burns has Complication: Infection. Examples include bacterial infection, tetanus, and pneumonia.
Burns has Complication: Fluid loss. This includes low blood volume, which is also known as hypovolemia.
Burns has Complication: Dangerously low body temperature. This is known as hypothermia.
Burns has Complication: Breathing problems. These can occur after taking in hot air or smoke.
Burns has Complication: Irregular heartbeats. Also called arrythmias, irregular heartbeats can occur after electrical burns.

Burns has Complication: Scars and changes in skin color. Scars or ridged areas can be caused by an overgrowth of scar tissue. These types of scars are called hypertrophic scars or keloids. Black people have an increased risk of this type of scarring and may benefit from seeing a burn specialist or surgeon. Other people may develop skin color changes after burns if healed skin is lighter or darker than skin that wasn't burned.
Burns has Complication: Pain. Burn scars can be painful. Some people may experience itching or discomfort related to damaged nerves, causing numbness or tingling.
Burns has Complication: Bone and joint problems. Scar tissue can shorten and tighten skin, muscles or tendons. This condition is also known as a contracture.
Burns has Complication: Depression and anxiety disorders.
Burns has Complication: Skin cancer. Skin cancer can sometimes happen in scars from previous burns. Contact your healthcare professional if you notice a sore that isn't healing within a burn scar.

Burns has Preventio: Burns are very common, and most of them are preventable. Kitchen-related injuries from hot drinks, soups and microwaved foods are especially common among children. You can take steps to reduce the risk of household burns.
Bursitis has Symptom: Feel achy or stiff
Bursitis has Symptom: Hurt more when you move it or press on it
Bursitis has Symptom: Look swollen and red
Bursitis has Cause: Throwing a baseball or lifting something over your head repeatedly
Bursitis has Cause: Leaning on your elbows for long periods
Bursitis has Cause: Extensive kneeling for tasks such as laying carpet or scrubbing floors
Bursitis has Risk Factor: Bursitis becomes more common with aging.
Bursitis has Risk Factor: Occupations or hobbies.
Bursitis has Risk Factor: Other medical conditions.
Bursitis has Preventio: Using kneeling pads.
Bursitis has Preventio: Lifting properly.
Bursitis has Preventio: Wheeling heavy loads.
Bursitis has Preventio: Taking frequent breaks.
Bursitis has Preventio: Maintaining a healthy weight.
Bursitis has Preventio: Exercising.
Bursitis has Preventio: Warming up and stretching
C. difficile infection has Symptom: Symptoms often begin within 5 to 10 days after starting an antibiotic. But symptoms can occur as soon as the first day or up to three months later.
C. difficile infection has Cause: Human or animal feces.
C. difficile infection has Cause: Surfaces in a room.
C. difficile infection has Cause: Unwashed hands.
C. difficile infection has Cause: Soil.
C. difficile infection has Cause: Water.
C. difficile infection has Cause: Food, including meat.
C. difficile infection has Risk Factor: People who have no known risk factors have gotten sick from C. difficile. But certain factors increase the risk.
C. difficile infection has Complication: Loss of fluids, called dehydration.
C. difficile infection has Complication: Kidney failure.
C. difficile infection has Complication: Toxic megacolon.
C. difficile infection has Complication: A hole in the large intestine, called bowel perforation.
C. difficile infection has Complication: Death.
C. difficile infection has Preventio: Hand-washing.
C. difficile infection has Preventio: Contact precautions.
C. difficile infection has Preventio: Thorough cleaning.
Calciphylaxis has Symptom: Large netlike patterns on the skin that may look purple-pink in color.

Calciphylaxis has Symptom: Deep, painful lumps in the skin that can become ulcers. The ulcers often have a black-brown crust that doesn't heal on its own. Ulcers tend to appear in areas with high fat content, such as the stomach, thighs, buttocks and breasts. But they can form anywhere.
Calciphylaxis has Symptom: Infections from ulcers that don't heal.
Calciphylaxis has Cause: A greater tendency for blood to clot. Blood clots can deprive fat tissues and skin of oxygen and nourishment.
Calciphylaxis has Cause: Reduced blood flow in small arteries, which can lead to skin lumps and ulcers.
Calciphylaxis has Cause: Thickening or scarring of tissue, also called fibrosis.
Calciphylaxis has Cause: Ongoing damage to the thin layer of cells that lines blood vessels. This also is called vascular endothelial injury.
Calciphylaxis has Cause: Swelling, called inflammation, in the body.
Calciphylaxis has Risk Factor: Being born female.

Cancer has Cause: Cancer is caused by changes (mutations) to the DNA within cells. The DNA inside a cell is packaged into a large number of individual genes, each of which contains a set of instructions telling the cell what functions to perform, as well as how to grow and divide. Errors in the instructions can cause the cell to stop its normal function and may allow a cell to become cancerous.

Cancer has Risk Factor: While doctors have an idea of what may increase your risk of cancer, the majority of cancers occur in people who don't have any known risk factors. Factors known to increase your risk of cancer include:

But if they're used in a partly closed or closed space, the carbon monoxide level can be a danger. Examples are using a charcoal grill indoors or leaving a running car inside a garage.

Castleman disease has Symptom: Many people with unicentric Castleman disease don't notice any signs or symptoms. The enlarged lymph node may be found during a physical exam or an imaging test for a different problem.

Castleman disease has Cause: It's not clear what causes unicentric Castleman disease or idiopathic multicentric Castleman disease (MCD). However, HHV-8-positive MCD is known to occur in people who don't have typical function in their immune systems because of HIV or other causes.

Castleman disease has Risk Factor: Castleman disease can affect people of any age or gender. People usually are diagnosed with Castleman disease during midlife, but it can happen at any age, including during childhood.

Castleman disease has Complication: People with unicentric Castleman disease (UCD) usually do well once the affected lymph node is removed, and life expectancy is usually not changed. But they are at increased risk of developing a rare autoimmune condition called paraneoplastic pemphigus. This condition can be life-threatening. Paraneoplastic pemphigus causes blisters in the mouth and on the skin that are often misdiagnosed. Though the risk of developing paraneoplastic pemphigus is low, being checked for this condition is important if you have UCD.

Cellulite has Symptom: Cellulite looks like dimpled or bumpy skin. It's sometimes described as having a cottage cheese or orange peel texture.

Cellulite has Cause: Little is known about what causes cellulite. It involves fibrous connective cords that tether the skin to the underlying muscle, with the fat lying between. As fat cells accumulate, they push up against the skin, while the long, tough cords pull down. This creates an uneven surface or dimpling.

Cellulite has Risk Factor: Cellulite is much more common in women than in men. In fact, most women develop some cellulite after puberty. This is because women's fat is typically distributed in the thighs, hips and buttocks — common areas for cellulite. Cellulite is also more common with aging, when the skin loses elasticity. Weight gain can make cellulite more noticeable, but some lean people have cellulite, as well. It tends to run in families, so genetics might play the biggest role in whether you develop cellulite. An inactive lifestyle also can increase your chances of having cellulite, as can pregnancy.
Cellulitis has Symptom: Cellulitis is a common condition that can occur anywhere on the body, but it often involves the lower leg and usually just one side of the body.

Cellulitis has Cause: Cellulitis happens when bacteria enter the body through a crack or break in the skin. Bacteria are most likely to enter broken, dry, flaky or swollen skin. Examples of entry points for bacteria are a recent surgical site, a cut, a puncture wound, a sore, and skin affected by athlete's foot or dermatitis. Cellulitis usually isn't spread from person to person.
Cellulitis has Risk Factor: Several factors put you at increased risk of cellulitis:

Cellulitis has Complication: Untreated cellulitis might lead to serious conditions such as bacteremia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis, toxic shock syndrome or sepsis. Rarely, the infection can spread to the deep layer of tissue called the fascial lining. Necrotizing fasciitis is an example of a deep-layer infection. It's an extreme emergency.
Cellulitis has Preventio: If you tend to have repeated episodes of cellulitis, your healthcare professional may recommend taking antibiotic medicine to prevent it from coming back.

Rare congenital factors, such as blood vessels not developing as they should before birth, increase risk for the condition. Nervous system injuries also may increase risk.

Cervical cancer has Cause: Cervical cancer begins when healthy cells in the cervix develop changes in theirDNA. A cell'sDNAcontains the instructions that tell a cell what to do. The changes tell the cells to multiply quickly. The cells continue living when healthy cells would die as part of their natural life cycle. This causes too many cells. The cells might form a mass called a tumor. The cells can invade and destroy healthy body tissue. In time, the cells can break away and spread to other parts of the body.

This medicine was used in the 1950s to prevent miscarriage. It's linked to a type of cervical cancer called clear cell adenocarcinoma.

Cervical cancer has Preventio: Practice safe sex.
Cervical cancer has Preventio: Don't smoke.

Cervical dystonia has Cause: In most people with cervical dystonia, the cause is unknown. Some people who have cervical dystonia have a family history of the disorder. Researchers have found gene mutations associated with cervical dystonia. Cervical dystonia is also sometimes linked to head, neck or shoulder injuries.
Cervical dystonia has Risk Factor: Risk factors for cervical dystonia include:

Cervical dystonia has Complication: In some cases, the involuntary muscle contractions associated with cervical dystonia can spread to nearby areas of your body. The most common locations include the face, jaw, arms and trunk.
Cervical spondylosis has Symptom: Most people with cervical spondylosis experience no symptoms. When symptoms do happen, they typically include pain and stiffness in the neck.

Cervical spondylosis has Cause: Cervical spondylosis is caused by changes to the structures that make up the backbone and neck. As people age, the backbone and neck gradually develop wear and tear. These changes can include:
Cervical spondylosis has Risk Factor: Risk factors for cervical spondylosis include:
Cervical spondylosis has Complication: If cervical spondylosis seriously compresses your spinal cord or nerve roots, the damage can be permanent.
Cervicitis has Symptom: Large amounts of unusual vaginal discharge
Cervicitis has Symptom: Frequent, painful urination
Cervicitis has Symptom: Pain during sex
Cervicitis has Symptom: Bleeding between menstrual periods
Cervicitis has Symptom: Vaginal bleeding after sex, not associated with a menstrual period

Cervicitis has Risk Factor: Have a history of sexually transmitted infections

Cervicitis has Complication: Your cervix acts as a barrier to keep bacteria and viruses from entering your uterus. When the cervix is infected, there's an increased risk that the infection will travel into your uterus.

Cervicitis has Preventio: To reduce your risk of cervicitis from sexually transmitted infections, use condoms consistently and correctly each time you have sex. Condoms are very effective against the spread of STIs, such as gonorrhea and chlamydia, which can lead to cervicitis. Being in a long-term relationship in which both you and your uninfected partner are committed to having sex with each other exclusively can lower your odds of an STI.

Chagas disease has Symptom: Chagas disease can cause a sudden, brief illness. This type of illness is known as acute. Or it can become a long-lasting, chronic condition. Both stages can be free of symptoms. Or there can be life-threatening symptoms in either phase.

Chagas disease has Cause: The cause of Chagas disease is the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. The parasite spreads from an insect known as the triatomine bug, also called the "kissing bug." The parasite can infect these insects when they swallow blood from an animal that is infected with the parasite.
Chagas disease has Risk Factor: The following can increase the risk of getting Chagas disease:
Chagas disease has Complication: If Chagas disease moves to the long-lasting, called chronic, phase, there can be serious heart or digestive complications. These may include:
Chagas disease has Preventio: If you live in a high-risk area for Chagas disease, these steps can help prevent infection:
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has Symptom: Symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease may include:

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has Cause: Gene changes that affect the nerves in the feet, legs, hands and arms cause Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. These gene changes most often pass down through families. But new gene changes can happen when there's no family history of changed genes.

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has Risk Factor: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a hereditary disease. That means it passes from parents to children through genes. The risk of getting the condition is higher for people who have parents or brothers or sisters with the condition.

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has Complication: Complications of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease vary from person to person in how bad they are. Foot issues and trouble walking are often the most serious concerns. And it's possible to harm areas of the body that have less feeling because of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease has Preventio: Because Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a hereditary disease, there's no way to prevent it. Hereditary means it's passed through families. If you have the condition, genetic testing may help you with family planning.
Chemo brain has Symptom: Trouble recalling what you've said to others.
Chemo brain has Symptom: Trouble recalling what you've seen, such as images or lists of words.
Chemo brain has Symptom: Trouble recalling what's happened recently, called short-term memory issues.

Chemo brain has Cause: There are many causes of changes in memory and thinking in people with cancer. These chemo brain symptoms can be caused by the cancer, treatment for the cancer, complications of cancer treatment and other things.
Chemo brain has Risk Factor: Brain cancer.
Chemo brain has Risk Factor: Cancer that spreads to the brain.
Chemo brain has Risk Factor: Higher doses of chemotherapy or radiation.
Chemo brain has Risk Factor: Radiation therapy to the brain.
Chemo brain has Risk Factor: Younger age at time of cancer diagnosis and treatment.
Chemo brain has Risk Factor: Older age.

Chemo brain has Complication: Some people with chemo brain have thinking and memory changes that affect their ability to work. Most people with cancer can return to work at least part-time. But some may find that tasks now take extra focus or time. Others may not be able to return to work.
Chest pain has Symptom: Chest pain symptoms depend on the cause.
Chest pain has Cause: Chest pain has many possible causes.
Chiari malformation has Symptom: Type 1
Chiari malformation has Symptom: Type 2

Chiari malformation has Cause: Chiari malformation type 1 occurs when part of the skull is too small or is misshapen. This part of the skull contains the area of the brain called the cerebellum. The skull puts pressure on and crowds the brain. As a result, the lower part of the cerebellum known as the tonsils are pushed into the upper spinal canal.
Chiari malformation has Risk Factor: There's evidence that Chiari malformation runs in some families. However, research into a possible hereditary component is still in its early phase.
Chiari malformation has Complication: Hydrocephalus.
Chiari malformation has Complication: Spina bifida.
Chiari malformation has Complication: Syringomyelia.
Chiari malformation has Complication: Tethered cord syndrome.
Chickenpox has Symptom: Fever.
Chickenpox has Symptom: Loss of appetite.
Chickenpox has Symptom: Headache.
Chickenpox has Symptom: Tiredness and a general feeling of being unwell.

Chickenpox has Cause: A virus called varicella-zoster causes chickenpox. It can spread through direct contact with the rash. It also can spread when a person with chickenpox coughs or sneezes and you breathe in the air droplets.

Chickenpox has Risk Factor: Your risk of getting infected with the virus that causes chickenpox is higher if you haven't already had chickenpox or if you haven't had the chickenpox vaccine. It's extra important for people who work in child care or school settings to be vaccinated.
Chickenpox has Complication: Infected skin, soft tissues, bones, joints or bloodstream caused by bacteria.
Chickenpox has Complication: Dehydration, when the body runs too low on water and other fluids.
Chickenpox has Complication: Pneumonia, an illness in one or both lungs.
Chickenpox has Complication: Swelling of the brain called encephalitis.
Chickenpox has Complication: Toxic shock syndrome, a dangerous complication of some illnesses caused by bacteria.
Chickenpox has Complication: Reye's syndrome, a disease that causes swelling in the brain and liver. This can happen in children and teens who take aspirin during chickenpox.
Chickenpox has Preventio: Have a weaker immune system. This includes people who haveHIVor take medicines that have an effect on the immune system.
Chickenpox has Preventio: Are allergic to gelatin or the antibiotic neomycin.
Chickenpox has Preventio: Have any kind of cancer or are getting cancer treatment with radiation or medicines.
Chickenpox has Preventio: Recently received blood from a donor or other blood products.
Chilblains has Symptom: Small, itchy areas on your skin, often on your feet or hands.
Chilblains has Symptom: Sores or blistering.
Chilblains has Symptom: Swelling.
Chilblains has Symptom: Pain or stinging.
Chilblains has Symptom: Changes in skin color.

Chilblains has Cause: The exact cause of chilblains is unknown. They may be an unusual reaction of your body to cold followed by rewarming. Rewarming of cold skin can cause small blood vessels under the skin to expand more quickly than nearby larger blood vessels can handle.
Chilblains has Risk Factor: Wearing clothing and shoes that are tight or expose skin to the cold.
Chilblains has Risk Factor: Being a young woman.
Chilblains has Risk Factor: Being underweight.
Chilblains has Risk Factor: Living in cold, humid areas.
Chilblains has Risk Factor: Having certain medical conditions.
Chilblains has Complication: Chilblains symptoms that are long-lasting and develop after repeated exposure to cold and damp conditions can cause scarring and thin skin.
Chilblains has Preventio: Avoid or limit your exposure to the cold.
Chilblains has Preventio: When you come in from the cold, rewarm the skin gradually.
Chilblains has Preventio: Dress in layers of loose clothing and wear mittens, a scarf and a hat, and warm, water-resistant footwear.
Chilblains has Preventio: Cover all exposed skin as completely as possible when going outside in cold weather.
Chilblains has Preventio: Keep your hands, feet and face dry and warm.
Chilblains has Preventio: Keep your home and workplace comfortably warm.
Chilblains has Preventio: Don't smoke.

Child abuse has Symptom: A child who's being abused may feel guilty, ashamed or confused. The child may be afraid to tell anyone about the abuse, especially if the abuser is a parent, other relative or family friend. That's why it's vital to watch for red flags, such as:
Child abuse has Risk Factor: Factors that may increase a person's risk of becoming abusive include:

Child abuse has Complication: Some children overcome the physical and psychological effects of child abuse, particularly those with strong social support and resiliency skills who can adapt and cope with bad experiences. For many others, however, child abuse may result in physical, behavioral, emotional or mental health issues — even years later.

Child abuse has Preventio: You can take important steps to protect your child from exploitation and child abuse, as well as prevent child abuse in your neighborhood or community. The goal is to provide safe, stable, nurturing relationships for children.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Symptom: Babbling less or making fewer vocal sounds than is typical between the ages of 7 to 12 months.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Symptom: Speaking first words late, typically after ages 12 to 18 months old.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Symptom: Using a limited number of consonants and vowels.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Symptom: Often leaving out sounds when speaking.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Symptom: Using speech that is hard to understand.

Childhood apraxia of speech has Cause: Childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) has a number of possible causes. But often a cause can't be determined. There usually isn't an observable problem in the brain of a child withCAS.

Childhood apraxia of speech has Risk Factor: Changes in theFOXP2gene appear to increase the risk of childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) and other speech and language disorders. TheFOXP2gene may be involved in how certain nerves and pathways in the brain develop. Researchers continue to study how changes in theFOXP2gene may affect motor coordination and speech and language processing in the brain. Other genes also may impact motor speech development.

Childhood apraxia of speech has Complication: Delayed language. This may include trouble understanding speech, reduced vocabulary, or not using correct grammar when putting words together in a phrase or sentence.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Complication: Delays in intellectual and motor development and problems with reading, spelling and writing.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Complication: Trouble with gross and fine motor movement skills or coordination.
Childhood apraxia of speech has Complication: Trouble using communication in social interactions.

Childhood apraxia of speech has Preventio: Diagnosing and treating childhood apraxia of speech at an early stage may reduce the risk of long-term persistence of the problem. If your child experiences speech problems, have a speech-language pathologist evaluate your child as soon as you notice any speech problems.

Childhood asthma has Cause: Childhood asthma causes aren't fully understood. Increased immune system sensitivity causes the lungs and airways to swell and produce mucus when exposed to certain triggers. Reaction to a trigger can be delayed, making it more difficult to identify the trigger. Triggers vary from child to child and can include:
Childhood asthma has Risk Factor: Factors that might increase a child's chance of developing asthma include:
Childhood asthma has Complication: Asthma can cause a number of complications, including:
Childhood asthma has Preventio: Careful planning and avoiding asthma triggers are the best ways to prevent asthma attacks.

Childhood obesity has Symptom: The symptoms of childhood obesity aren't clear-cut. Not all children who carry extra pounds are overweight. Some children have larger than average body frames. And it's typical for children to carry different amounts of body fat at the various stages of development. So you might not know if weight is a concern based on how your child looks.
Childhood obesity has Cause: Genetic and hormonal factors.
Childhood obesity has Cause: Food access.
Childhood obesity has Cause: Stress.
Childhood obesity has Cause: Sleep.
Childhood obesity has Cause: Social and economic factors.
Childhood obesity has Cause: Eating and physical activity habits.
Childhood obesity has Risk Factor: Eating habits.
Childhood obesity has Risk Factor: Not enough movement.
Childhood obesity has Risk Factor: Mental health factors.
Childhood obesity has Risk Factor: Certain medicines.
Childhood obesity has Complication: Childhood obesity often causes health concerns and conditions known as complications. These can affect a child's physical, social and mental well-being.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Set a good example.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Offer balanced meals and snacks each day.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Keep offering new foods.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Support a healthy relationship with junk food.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Limit screen time.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Choose rewards that aren't food.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Be sure your child gets enough sleep.
Childhood obesity has Preventio: Breastfeed your baby.

Childhood schizophrenia has Symptom: Schizophrenia involves a range of problems with thinking, behavior or emotions. Signs and symptoms may vary, but usually involve delusions, hallucinations or disorganized speech, and reflect an impaired ability to function. The effect can be disabling.

Childhood schizophrenia has Cause: It's not known what causes childhood schizophrenia, but it's thought that it develops in the same way as adult schizophrenia does. Researchers believe that a combination of genetics, brain chemistry and environment contributes to development of the disorder. It's not clear why schizophrenia starts so early in life for some and not for others.
Childhood schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Having a family history of schizophrenia
Childhood schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Increased immune system activation, such as from inflammation
Childhood schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Older age of the father
Childhood schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Some pregnancy and birth complications, such as malnutrition or exposure to toxins or viruses that may impact brain development
Childhood schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Taking mind-altering (psychoactive) drugs during teen years
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Suicide, suicide attempts and thoughts of suicide
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Self-injury
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Anxiety disorders, panic disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Depression
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Abuse of alcohol or other drugs, including nicotine
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Family conflicts
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Inability to live independently, attend school or work
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Social isolation
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Health and medical problems
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Being victimized
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Legal and financial problems, and homelessness
Childhood schizophrenia has Complication: Aggressive behavior, although uncommon

Childhood schizophrenia has Preventio: Early identification and treatment may help get symptoms of childhood schizophrenia under control before serious complications develop. Early treatment is also crucial in helping limit psychotic episodes, which can be extremely frightening to a child and his or her parents. Ongoing treatment can help improve your child's long-term outlook.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Symptom: Painful urination.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Symptom: Vaginal discharge.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Symptom: Discharge from the penis.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Symptom: Painful vaginal sex.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Symptom: Vaginal bleeding between periods and after sex.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Symptom: Testicular pain.

Chlamydia trachomatis has Cause: The Chlamydia trachomatis bacterium is most commonly spread through vaginal, oral and anal sex. It also is possible for the bacterium to spread in pregnancy, during delivery of the baby. Chlamydia can cause pneumonia or a serious eye infection in the newborn.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Risk Factor: Not using a condom or incorrect condom use.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Risk Factor: Less use of health services to prevent and treat sexually transmitted infections.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Risk Factor: New or multiple sex partners.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Risk Factor: Changing sex partners before learning about a chlamydia infection.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Complication: Pelvic inflammatory disease, also called PID.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Complication: Infection near the testicles.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Complication: Prostate gland infection.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Complication: Infections in newborns.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Complication: Ectopic pregnancy.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Complication: Infertility.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Complication: Reactive arthritis.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Preventio: Use condoms.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Preventio: Limit your number of sex partners.
Chlamydia trachomatis has Preventio: Get regular screenings.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Yellowing of your skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice)
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Intensely itchy skin
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: White-colored stools
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Fatigue
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Abdominal pain on the right side, just below the ribs
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Losing weight without trying
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Fever
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Night sweats
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Symptom: Dark urine

Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Cause: Cholangiocarcinoma happens when cells in the bile ducts develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA contains the instructions that tell a cell what to do. The changes tell the cells to multiply out of control and form a mass of cells (tumor) that can invade and destroy healthy body tissue. It's not clear what causes the changes that lead to cholangiocarcinoma.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: Primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: Chronic liver disease.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: Bile duct problems present at birth.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: A liver parasite.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: Cholangiocarcinoma occurs most often in adults over age 50.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: Diabetes.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Risk Factor: Certain inherited conditions.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Preventio: Stop smoking.
Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) has Preventio: Reduce your risk of liver disease.
Cholecystitis has Symptom: Severe pain in the upper right or center belly area.
Cholecystitis has Symptom: Pain that spreads to the right shoulder or back.
Cholecystitis has Symptom: Tenderness over the belly area when it's touched.
Cholecystitis has Symptom: Nausea.
Cholecystitis has Symptom: Vomiting.
Cholecystitis has Symptom: Fever.

Cholecystitis has Cause: Bile duct blockage.

Cholecystitis has Complication: Death of gallbladder tissue.

Cholecystitis has Preventio: Choose a healthy-eating plan.

Cholera has Symptom: Most people exposed to the bacteria that cause cholera don't become ill and don't know they've been infected. But they can still infect others if their stool contaminates water or food.

Cholera has Cause: A type of bacteria called Vibrio cholerae causes cholera infection. The deadly effects of the disease are the result of a toxin the bacteria make in the small intestine. The toxin causes the body to purge huge amounts of water. This leads to diarrhea and a rapid loss of fluids and salts.

Cholera has Risk Factor: Everyone is prone to cholera. But illness is not common before the age of 2. Babies might get protection from the disease when they breastfeed from mothers who've had cholera in the past.

Cholera has Complication: Cholera can quickly become fatal. Sometimes, the rapid loss of large amounts of fluids and electrolytes can lead to death within hours. Even in less extreme situations, the illness can be life-threatening without treatment. People who don't receive treatment can die of dehydration and shock hours to days after cholera symptoms first appear.

Cholera has Preventio: Cholera is rare in the United States and other developed countries. In these places, the disease is sometimes linked with travel abroad. Or it can be linked with seafood from waters that harbor cholera bacteria, such as those off the Gulf Coast.
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Symptom: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes, called jaundice
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Symptom: Nausea
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Symptom: Loss of appetite
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Symptom: Oily, foul-smelling stools
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Cause: Hormones.
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Cause: Genes.
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Cause: Environment.
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Risk Factor: Personal or family history of cholestasis of pregnancy
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Risk Factor: History of liver damage or disease, including hepatitis C and gallbladder stones
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Risk Factor: Being pregnant with multiple babies
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Risk Factor: Pregnancy at an older age, such as 35 years or older

Cholestasis of pregnancy has Complication: Lung problems from breathing in meconium. Meconium is the sticky, green substance that typically collects in the developing baby's intestines. Meconium may pass into the amniotic fluid if a mom has cholestasis.
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Complication: Death of the baby late in pregnancy before delivery, also called stillbirth.
Cholestasis of pregnancy has Preventio: There is no known way to prevent cholestasis of pregnancy.
Chondrosarcoma has Symptom: Increasing pain
Chondrosarcoma has Symptom: A growing lump or area of swelling
Chondrosarcoma has Symptom: Weakness or bowel and bladder control problems, if the cancer presses on the spinal cord

Chondrosarcoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes chondrosarcoma. Doctors know that cancer begins when a cell develops changes (mutations) in its DNA. A cell's DNA contains the instructions that tell it what to do. The instructions tell the cell to multiply quickly and to continue living when healthy cells would die. The accumulating cells form a tumor that can grow to invade and destroy normal body tissue. In time, cells can break away and spread (metastasize) to other areas of the body.
Chondrosarcoma has Risk Factor: Chondrosarcoma occurs most often in middle-aged and older adults, though it can occur at any age.
Chondrosarcoma has Risk Factor: Other bone diseases.
Chordoma has Symptom: Pain near the location of the tumor.
Chordoma has Symptom: New nerve problems, such as numbness or weakness.
Chordoma has Symptom: New changes to how and when you pass stool or urine.

Chordoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes most chordomas. They usually happen randomly. Rarely, they can be hereditary, meaning chordomas can run in families. This cancer most often starts in the bones in the skull or spine.
Chordoma has Risk Factor: Chordoma can happen at any age. Most often, this cancer happens in people ages 40 to 60.
Chordoma has Risk Factor: Family history.

Chordoma has Risk Factor: In adults, people assigned male at birth are somewhat more likely to be diagnosed with chordoma. About 60% of chordomas are found in people assigned male at birth. About 40% of chordomas are found in people assigned female at birth. In children, those assigned female at birth are slightly more likely to be diagnosed with chordoma than are those assigned male at birth.
Chordoma has Complication: Cerebrospinal fluid leaks, though this is rare.
Chordoma has Complication: Headaches.
Chordoma has Complication: Hearing loss.
Chordoma has Complication: Problems with balance, coordination and walking.
Chordoma has Complication: Trouble swallowing or speaking.
Chordoma has Complication: Trouble breathing.
Chordoma has Complication: Vision problems.
Chordoma has Complication: Water buildup on the brain, which can increase pressure inside the skull and cause headaches, nausea and vomiting.
Chordoma has Complication: Weakness or numbness in the face, arms or legs.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Symptom: Blurred or double vision.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Symptom: Headaches.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Symptom: Increased tiredness.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Symptom: Irritability.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Symptom: Nausea.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Symptom: Seizures.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Symptom: Vomiting.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes most choroid plexus carcinomas. This cancer starts as a growth of cells in the brain.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Risk Factor: Choroid plexus carcinoma can happen at any age. This brain cancer happens most often in children under 2 years old.
Choroid plexus carcinoma has Risk Factor: Inherited syndromes.
Chronic cough has Symptom: A runny or stuffy nose.
Chronic cough has Symptom: A feeling of liquid running down the back of your throat, also known as postnasal drip.
Chronic cough has Symptom: Clearing your throat a lot.
Chronic cough has Symptom: Sore throat.
Chronic cough has Symptom: Hoarseness.
Chronic cough has Symptom: Wheezing and shortness of breath.

Chronic cough has Complication: Sleep disruption.

Chronic cough has Complication: Dizziness.

Chronic daily headaches has Symptom: Chronic migraine
Chronic daily headaches has Symptom: Chronic tension-type headache
Chronic daily headaches has Symptom: New daily persistent headache
Chronic daily headaches has Symptom: Hemicrania continua

Chronic daily headaches has Cause: Infections, such as meningitis
Chronic daily headaches has Cause: Intracranial pressure that's either too high or too low
Chronic daily headaches has Cause: Brain tumor
Chronic daily headaches has Cause: Traumatic brain injury

Chronic daily headaches has Risk Factor: Anxiety
Chronic daily headaches has Risk Factor: Depression
Chronic daily headaches has Risk Factor: Sleep disturbances

Chronic exertional compartment syndrome has Symptom: Your limbs have specific areas of muscle (compartments). Your lower leg, for example, has four compartments. Chronic exertional compartment syndrome often occurs in the same compartment of an affected limb on both sides of the body, usually the lower leg.

Chronic exertional compartment syndrome has Cause: The cause of chronic exertional compartment syndrome isn't completely understood. When you exercise, your muscles expand in volume. If you have chronic exertional compartment syndrome, the tissue that encases the affected muscle (fascia) doesn't expand with the muscle, causing pressure and pain in a compartment of the affected limb.

Chronic traumatic encephalopathy has Symptom: There are no specific symptoms that have been clearly linked to chronic traumatic encephalopathy, also known as CTE. Some of the possible symptoms can occur in many other conditions. In people who were confirmed to have CTE at autopsy, symptoms have included cognitive, behavioral, mood and movement changes.

Chronic traumatic encephalopathy has Cause: Repeated head trauma is likely the cause of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, also known as CTE. Football players in the United States, ice hockey players and military members serving in war zones have been the focus of most CTE studies. However, other sports and factors such as physical abuse can lead to repeated head injuries. Research also has found that CTE can affect people who played both amateur and professional sports. This was discovered when autopsies were done of the brains of young people who had died and had repeated head injuries during their lives.

Chronic traumatic encephalopathy has Risk Factor: Repeated traumatic brain injuries are thought to increase the risk of chronic traumatic encephalopathy. Experts are still learning about the risk factors.

Chronic traumatic encephalopathy has Preventio: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy, also known as CTE, can be prevented by lowering the risk of getting a concussion. People who have had one concussion are more likely to have another head injury. The current recommendation to prevent CTE is to reduce mild traumatic brain injuries and to prevent additional injury after a concussion.

Churg-Strauss syndrome has Symptom: EGPA symptoms are different for each person. Some people have mild symptoms, while others may develop serious or even life-threatening symptoms. Without treatment, symptoms typically get worse over time. The condition often progresses through three stages:

Churg-Strauss syndrome has Cause: The exact cause of EGPA isn't fully known. It's likely a combination of genetic and environmental factors. For some people, things such as allergens or certain medicines may trigger an overreaction in the immune system. And instead of protecting the body from bacteria and viruses, the immune system starts attacking healthy tissues. Over time this can lead to inflammation in the blood vessels and damage to organs and tissues.
Churg-Strauss syndrome has Risk Factor: Anyone can develop EGPA, but it most often is diagnosed in people around age 50. You may be at risk if you have:

Churg-Strauss syndrome has Complication: EGPA can affect many parts of the body, including the lungs, sinuses, skin, digestive system, kidneys, muscles, joints and heart. If not treated, the condition can lead to permanent damage and may be life-threatening.

Cleft lip and cleft palate has Cause: Cleft lip and cleft palate occur when tissues in the baby's face and mouth don't come together properly before birth. Usually, the tissues that make up the lip and palate come together in the first few weeks of pregnancy. But in babies with cleft lip and cleft palate, they never come together or only come together partway, leaving an opening.

Cold urticaria has Cause: No one knows what causes cold urticaria. You could have sensitive skin cells due to a virus or an illness or from a trait passed down in your genes. In the most common forms of this condition, cold causes the release of histamine and other chemicals into the blood. These chemicals cause itching, and they sometimes affect the whole body.

Colic has Symptom: Babies have been known to fuss and cry, especially during the first three months of life. The range for what's considered typical crying is difficult to pin down. In general, colic is defined as crying for three or more hours a day, three or more days a week, for three or more weeks.

Colic has Cause: The cause of colic is unknown. It may result from numerous contributing factors. While a number of causes have been explored, it's difficult for researchers to account for all the important features, such as why it usually begins late in the first month of life, how it varies among infants, why it happens at certain times of day and why it resolves on its own in time.
Colic has Risk Factor: Risk factors for colic are not well-understood. Research has not shown differences in risk when the following factors were considered:
Colic has Complication: Colic does not cause short-term or long-term medical problems for a child.

Colon polyps has Cause: Experts haven't found a single cause for colon polyps. They form when the usual process of cell growth and repair in the colon goes off track. Instead of replacing old cells in an orderly way, the body makes extra cells, which build up and form a polyp on the smooth lining of the intestine. Polyps can grow anywhere in the large intestine, including in the colon and rectum.

Common cold in babies has Cause: The common cold is an infection of the nose and throat, called an upper respiratory tract infection. More than 200 viruses can cause the common cold. Rhinoviruses are the most common.
Common cold in babies has Risk Factor: A few factors put babies at higher risk of a common cold.

Common variable immunodeficiency has Symptom: How bad symptoms are varies greatly between people withCVID. Symptoms of common variable immunodeficiency may appear during childhood or the teen years. But many people don't get symptoms until they're adults.

Common variable immunodeficiency has Cause: In mostCVIDcases, the cause is unknown. In around 10% of people withCVID, a gene change has been found. Researchers believe that the condition is caused by a mix of factors in the environment and in genes. As of now, the environmental factors are unclear.
Common warts has Symptom: Small, fleshy, grainy bumps on the fingers or hands.
Common warts has Symptom: Feeling rough to the touch.
Common warts has Symptom: A sprinkling of black dots, which are clotted blood vessels.

Common warts has Cause: Common warts are caused by the human papillomavirus, also called HPV. There are more than 100 types of this common virus, but only a few cause warts on the hands. Some strains ofHPVare spread through sexual contact. But most are spread by casual skin contact or shared objects, such as towels or washcloths. The virus usually spreads through breaks in the skin, such as hangnails or scrapes. Biting your nails also can cause warts to spread on your fingertips and around your nails.
Common warts has Risk Factor: Children and young adults.
Common warts has Risk Factor: People with weakened immune systems, such as those withHIV/AIDSor those who have had organ transplants.
Common warts has Risk Factor: People with the habit of nail biting or picking at hangnails.
Common warts has Preventio: Don't touch or pick at warts, including your own.
Common warts has Preventio: Don't use the same emery board, pumice stone or nail clipper on your warts as you use on healthy skin and nails. Use a disposable emery board.
Common warts has Preventio: Don't bite your fingernails or pick at hangnails.
Common warts has Preventio: Groom with care. And avoid brushing, clipping or shaving areas that have warts.
Common warts has Preventio: Avoid shared hot tubs, showers and warm baths. And don't share washcloths or towels.
Common warts has Preventio: Use hand moisturizer daily. This helps prevent dry, cracked skin.

Concussion has Cause: During a concussion, the brain slides back and forth against the inner walls of the skull. This forceful movement can be caused by a violent blow to the head and neck or upper body. It also may be caused by the sudden acceleration or deceleration of the head. This may happen during a car crash, a fall from a bike or from a collision with another player in sports.

Concussion has Risk Factor: High-risk sports such as American football, hockey, soccer, rugby, boxing or other contact sports.

Concussion has Preventio: Wear protective gear during sports and other recreational activities.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Symptom: Symptoms ofCAHvary. The symptoms depend on which gene is affected. They also depend on how greatly the adrenal glands lack one of the enzymes needed to make hormones. WithCAH, the hormones that the body needs to work properly are thrown out of balance. That may lead to too little cortisol, too little aldosterone, too many androgens or a mix of these issues.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Cause: The most common cause ofCAHis the lack of the enzyme protein known as 21-hydroxylase. Sometimes,CAHis called 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The body needs this enzyme to make proper amounts of hormones. Very rarely, a lack of other much rarer enzymes also can causeCAH.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Risk Factor: Parents who both haveCAH.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Risk Factor: Parents who are both carriers of the changed gene that causesCAH.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Risk Factor: Being of Ashkenazi Jewish, Latino, Mediterranean, Yugoslav or Yup'ik descent.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Complication: Diarrhea.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Complication: Coma.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia has Preventio: There is no known way to preventCAH. If you're thinking of starting a family and you're at risk of having a child withCAH, talk with your healthcare professional. You may be told to see a genetic counselor.

Congenital myasthenic syndromes has Cause: Space between your nerve and muscle cells (synaptic).
Congenital myasthenic syndromes has Cause: Muscle cells where the impulse is received (postsynaptic), the most common location.

Congenital myasthenic syndromes has Risk Factor: A child is at risk of a congenital myasthenic syndrome if both parents are carriers of a gene known to cause the syndrome. The child then inherits two copies of the gene. Children who inherit only one copy of the gene from one parent typically won't develop the syndrome but will be carriers.

Conjoined twins has Symptom: There are no specific symptoms that indicate a conjoined twin pregnancy. As with other twin pregnancies, the uterus may grow faster than it does with a single baby. And there may be more tiredness, nausea and vomiting early in the pregnancy. Conjoined twins can be diagnosed early in the pregnancy using an ultrasound.

Conjoined twins has Cause: Identical twins (monozygotic twins) occur when a single fertilized egg splits and develops into two individuals. Eight to 12 days after conception, the embryonic layers that split to form monozygotic twins begin to develop into specific organs and structures.
Conjoined twins has Risk Factor: Because conjoined twins are so rare, and the cause isn't clear, it's unknown what might make some couples more likely to have conjoined twins.

Conjoined twins has Complication: Pregnancy with conjoined twins is complex and greatly increases the risk of serious complications. Conjoined babies require surgical delivery by cesarean section (C-section).

COPD has Cause: The main cause of COPD in developed countries is tobacco smoking. In the developing world, COPD often occurs in people exposed to fumes from burning fuel for cooking and heating in homes that don't have good airflow. Long-term exposure to chemical fumes, vapors and dusts in the workplace is another cause of COPD.

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has Cause: As a virus infects a group of people, the virus copies itself. During this process, the genetic code can randomly change in each copy. The changes are called mutations. If the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 changes in ways that make previous infections or vaccination less effective at preventing infection, people can get sick again.

Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Trouble moving on one or both sides of the body, which gets worse over time.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Poor coordination.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Trouble with balance.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Stiffness.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Postures of the hands or feet that can't be controlled. For example, the hand may form a clenched fist.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Muscle jerks.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Trouble swallowing.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Changes in eye movements.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Trouble with thinking and language skills.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Symptom: Speech changes, such as slow and halting speech.

Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Cause: Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) can have several causes. Most commonly, the disease results from a buildup of a protein called tau in brain cells. The buildup of tau may lead to the breakdown of the cells. This can cause symptoms of corticobasal degeneration.
Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Risk Factor: There are no known risk factors for corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome).

Corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) has Complication: People with corticobasal degeneration (corticobasal syndrome) may develop serious complications. People with the disease may develop pneumonia, blood clots in the lungs or a dangerous response to an infection, known as sepsis. Complications often lead to death.

Costochondritis has Cause: Costochondritis often has no clear cause. However, it might be associated with trauma, illness or physical strain, such as severe coughing.
Costochondritis has Risk Factor: Costochondritis happens most often in women over age 40.
Cough headaches has Symptom: Symptoms of cough headaches:
Cough headaches has Cause: The cause of primary cough headaches is unknown.
Cough headaches has Risk Factor: Risk factors for cough headaches vary widely based on the type and cause of the headache.

Cough headaches has Preventio: After talking with your provider, here are some tips to prevent actions that trigger your cough headaches — whether that's coughing, sneezing or straining while using the toilet. This may help reduce the number of headaches you experience. Some preventive measures may include:
Cradle cap has Symptom: Patchy scaling or thick crusts on the scalp.
Cradle cap has Symptom: Oily or dry skin covered with flaky white or yellow scales.
Cradle cap has Symptom: Skin flakes.
Cradle cap has Symptom: Mild inflammation.

Cradle cap has Cause: The cause of cradle cap isn't known. One factor may be hormones that pass from the mother to the baby before birth. These hormones can cause oil glands and hair follicles to make too much oil. This oil is called sebum.
Cradle cap has Risk Factor: Cradle cap is very common in babies. There are no known risk factors for it.

Cradle cap has Preventio: Shampooing your baby's hair every few days can help prevent cradle cap. Use a baby shampoo unless your baby's doctor or other health care professional suggests a stronger product.
Craniopharyngioma has Symptom: Headaches.
Craniopharyngioma has Symptom: Vision changes.
Craniopharyngioma has Symptom: Nausea and vomiting.
Craniopharyngioma has Symptom: Increased urination.

Craniopharyngioma has Symptom: Trouble walking.
Craniopharyngioma has Symptom: Changes in personality or behavior.
Craniopharyngioma has Symptom: Weight gain and slowed growth in children.

Craniopharyngioma has Cause: It's not clear what causes craniopharyngioma. Craniopharyngioma begins as a growth of cells near the brain's pituitary gland. The pituitary gland makes hormones that control many body functions.
Craniopharyngioma has Risk Factor: Healthcare professionals haven't found many risk factors for craniopharyngioma. This tumor can happen at any age. But it's more common in children and older adults.
Craniosynostosis has Symptom: A skull with a shape that's not typical.
Craniosynostosis has Symptom: Change in the balance of facial features and ears.
Craniosynostosis has Symptom: A raised, hard ridge along the closed cranial suture.
Craniosynostosis has Cause: Nonsyndromic craniosynostosis
Craniosynostosis has Cause: Syndromic craniosynostosis
Craniosynostosis has Risk Factor: Genetic syndromes that affect a baby's skull development, such as Apert syndrome, Pfeiffer syndrome and Crouzon syndrome, are risk factors for craniosynostosis.
Craniosynostosis has Complication: Lasting changes in the shape of the head and face.
Craniosynostosis has Complication: A feeling of not being worthy and of wanting to stay away from others.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease has Symptom: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is marked by changes in mental abilities. Symptoms get worse quickly, usually within several weeks to a few months. Early symptoms include:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease has Cause: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and related conditions appear to be caused by changes to a type of protein called a prion. These proteins are typically produced in the body. But when they encounter infectious prions, they fold and become another shape that's not typical. They can spread and affect processes in the body.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease has Risk Factor: Most cases of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease occur for unknown reasons. So risk factors can't be identified. But a few factors seem to be associated with different kinds ofCJD.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease has Complication: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease has serious effects on the brain and body. The disease usually progresses quickly. Over time, people withCJDwithdraw from friends and family. They also lose the ability to care for themselves. Many slip into a coma. The disease is always fatal.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease has Preventio: There's no known way to prevent sporadicCJD. If you have a family history of neurological disease, you may benefit from talking with a genetics counselor. A counselor can help you sort through your risks.

Crohn's disease has Symptom: Fatigue.
Crohn's disease has Symptom: Belly pain and cramping.
Crohn's disease has Symptom: Blood in the stool.
Crohn's disease has Symptom: Mouth sores.
Crohn's disease has Symptom: Reduced appetite and weight loss.
Crohn's disease has Symptom: Pain or drainage near or around the anus due to inflammation from a tunnel into the skin, called a fistula.
Crohn's disease has Cause: Genes.
Crohn's disease has Cause: Immune system.
Crohn's disease has Risk Factor: Family history.

Crohn's disease has Risk Factor: Crohn's disease can happen at any age, but it's more common to develop the condition when you're young. Most people who develop Crohn's disease are diagnosed before they're around 30 years old.
Crohn's disease has Risk Factor: Ethnicity.
Crohn's disease has Risk Factor: Cigarette smoking.
Crohn's disease has Risk Factor: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicines.
