Crohn's disease has Complication: Medicine risks.
Crohn's disease has Complication: Blood clots.
Croup has Symptom: Croup often begins as an ordinary cold. If there's enough swelling, irritation and coughing, a child can develop:
Croup has Cause: Croup is usually caused by a viral infection, most often a parainfluenza virus.

Croup has Risk Factor: Children between 6 months and 3 years of age have the highest risk of getting croup. Because children have small airways, they're likely to have more symptoms with croup. Croup rarely occurs in children older than 6 years of age.

Croup has Complication: Most cases of croup are mild. In a small number of children, the airway swells enough to cause problems with breathing. Rarely, a bacterial infection of the windpipe can occur in addition to the viral infection. This can result in trouble breathing and requires emergency medical care.
Croup has Preventio: To prevent croup, take the same steps you use to prevent colds and flu.
Cryoglobulinemia has Symptom: Skin spots.
Cryoglobulinemia has Symptom: Joint pain.
Cryoglobulinemia has Symptom: Peripheral neuropathy.
Cryoglobulinemia has Cause: Infections.
Cryoglobulinemia has Cause: Certain cancers.
Cryoglobulinemia has Cause: Autoimmune diseases.
Cryoglobulinemia has Risk Factor: Cryoglobulinemia happens more often in women than in men.
Cryoglobulinemia has Risk Factor: Symptoms of cryoglobulinemia most often begin in middle age.
Cryoglobulinemia has Risk Factor: Other diseases.

Cryoglobulinemia has Complication: Cryoglobulinemia can affect the kidneys. The main symptoms are protein or blood in the urine. High blood pressure most often goes with the kidney symptoms. In time, kidney failure might happen.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Symptom: Symptoms vary between spinal and cranialCSFleaks.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Cause: A spinal tap, also called a lumbar puncture.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Cause: An epidural in the spine for pain relief, such as during labor and delivery.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Cause: An injury to the head or spine.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Cause: Bone spurs along the spine.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Cause: Irregularities of the dura mater around the nerve roots in the spine.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Cause: Irregular connections between dura mater and veins. These are referred to asCSF-venous fistulas.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Cause: Prior surgery on the spine.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Risk Factor: Having a previous surgery or procedure on or around the spine.
CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Risk Factor: Connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which often also cause joint hypermobility and dislocations.

CSF leak (Cerebrospinal fluid leak) has Complication: If a cranialCSFleak is left untreated, complications may occur. Possible complications include meningitis and tension pneumocephalus, which is when air enters the spaces surrounding the brain. Untreated spinalCSFleaks may lead to subdural hematomas, or bleeding on the surface of the brain.
Cushing syndrome has Symptom: Symptoms of Cushing syndrome can vary depending on the level of extra cortisol.
Cushing syndrome has Cause: Controlling blood pressure.
Cushing syndrome has Cause: Reducing inflammation.
Cushing syndrome has Cause: Helping the heart and blood vessels work correctly.
Cushing syndrome has Cause: Controlling blood sugar.
Cushing syndrome has Cause: Helping the body use food for energy.
Cushing syndrome has Complication: Bone loss, also called osteoporosis, which can lead to broken bones.
Cushing syndrome has Complication: High blood pressure, also called hypertension.
Cushing syndrome has Complication: Type 2 diabetes.
Cushing syndrome has Complication: Serious or multiple infections.
Cushing syndrome has Complication: Loss of muscle mass and strength.
Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma has Symptom: A single lump or group of lumps on the skin.
Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma has Symptom: A lump or lumps on the skin that may look pink, purple or red-brown.
Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Redness around the skin lumps.
Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Skin lumps that grow slowly.

Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma has Cause: The cause of cutaneous B-cell lymphoma often isn't known. This cancer causes a growth of cells in the skin. It starts in germ-fighting white blood cells called lymphocytes. Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma affects specific lymphocytes called B lymphocytes.
Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: Weakened immune system.
Cutaneous B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: Bacteria transmitted by ticks.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Patches of raised or scaly skin that might itch. The patches happen most often on skin that doesn't get much sun.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Patches of skin that look pink, red, brown or gray. The color may be harder to see on Black and brown skin.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Patches of skin that look lighter in color than the skin around them. This may be easier to see on Black and brown skin.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Lumps that form on the skin and may break open.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Lymph nodes that get bigger.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Hair loss.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Thickened skin on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Symptom: A rash over all the skin that is scaly and itchy.

Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Cause: The cause of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma often isn't known. This cancer causes a growth of cells in the skin. It starts in germ-fighting white blood cells called lymphocytes. Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma affects specific lymphocytes called T lymphocytes.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: Older adults.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: People assigned male at birth.
Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: Black people.
Cyclic vomiting syndrome has Symptom: The symptoms of cyclic vomiting syndrome often begin in the morning. Symptoms include:

Cyclic vomiting syndrome has Cause: The underlying cause of cyclic vomiting syndrome is unknown. Some possible causes include genes, digestive difficulties, nervous system conditions and hormones that are not balanced. Specific bouts of vomiting may be triggered by:

Cyclic vomiting syndrome has Risk Factor: The relationship between migraines and cyclic vomiting syndrome isn't clear. But many children with cyclic vomiting syndrome have a family history of migraines or have migraines themselves when they get older. In adults, cyclic vomiting syndrome also is associated with a personal or family history of migraines.
Cyclic vomiting syndrome has Complication: Cyclic vomiting syndrome can cause these complications:

Cyclic vomiting syndrome has Preventio: Many people know what triggers their cyclic vomiting episodes. Avoiding those triggers can reduce the frequency of episodes. You may feel well between episodes, but it's very important to take medicines as prescribed by your healthcare professional.

Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Symptom: Cyclothymia symptoms alternate between emotional highs and lows. The highs of cyclothymia include symptoms of an elevated mood (hypomanic symptoms). The lows consist of mild or moderate depressive symptoms.
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Cause: Genetics,
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Cause: Differences in the way the brain works,
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Cause: Environmental issues,

Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Risk Factor: Cyclothymia is thought to be relatively rare. But true estimates are hard to make because people may be undiagnosed or misdiagnosed as having other mood disorders, such as depression.
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Complication: Not treating it can result in significant emotional problems that affect every area of your life
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Complication: There is a high risk of later developing bipolar I or II disorder
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Complication: Substance misuse is common
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Complication: You may also have an anxiety disorder
Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Complication: You may be at increased risk of suicidal thoughts and suicide

Cyclothymia (cyclothymic disorder) has Preventio: There's no sure way to prevent cyclothymia. However, treatment at the earliest indication of a mental health disorder can help prevent cyclothymia from worsening. Long-term preventive treatment also can help prevent minor symptoms from becoming full-blown episodes of hypomania, mania or major depression.

Cystic fibrosis has Symptom: In the U.S., because of newborn screening, cystic fibrosis can be diagnosed within the first month of life, before symptoms develop. But people born before newborn screening became available may not be diagnosed until the symptoms of CF show up.

Cystic fibrosis has Cause: In cystic fibrosis, a change in a gene causes problems with the protein that controls the movement of salt and water in and out of cells. This gene is the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. It affects the cells that make mucus, sweat and digestive juices. When the CFTR protein doesn't work as it should, the result is thick, sticky mucus in the respiratory, digestive and reproductive systems, as well as extra salt in sweat.
Cystic fibrosis has Risk Factor: Because cystic fibrosis is a condition passed down in families, family history is a risk factor.
Cystic fibrosis has Complication: Complications of cystic fibrosis can affect the respiratory, digestive and reproductive systems, as well as other organs.

Cystic fibrosis has Preventio: If you or your partner have close relatives with cystic fibrosis, you both may choose to have genetic testing before having children. Testing done in a lab on a sample of blood can help find out your risk of having a child with CF.
Cystitis has Symptom: A strong, persistent urge to urinate
Cystitis has Symptom: Pain or a burning feeling when urinating
Cystitis has Symptom: Passing frequent, small amounts of urine
Cystitis has Symptom: Blood in the urine (hematuria)
Cystitis has Symptom: Passing cloudy or strong-smelling urine
Cystitis has Symptom: Pelvic discomfort
Cystitis has Symptom: A feeling of pressure in the area below your belly button (abdomen)
Cystitis has Symptom: Low-grade fever
Cystitis has Cause: Your urinary system includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra. All play a role in removing waste from your body.
Cystitis has Risk Factor: During sex, bacteria can be pushed into the urethra.
Cystitis has Risk Factor: Use certain types of birth control.
Cystitis has Risk Factor: Are pregnant.
Cystitis has Risk Factor: Have gone through menopause.
Cystitis has Complication: Kidney infection.
Cystitis has Complication: Blood in the urine.
Cystitis has Preventio: Drink plenty of liquids, especially water.
Cystitis has Preventio: Urinate frequently.
Cystitis has Preventio: Wipe from front to back after a bowel movement.
Cystitis has Preventio: Take showers rather than tub baths.
Cystitis has Preventio: Gently wash the skin around the genitals.
Cystitis has Preventio: Empty your bladder as soon as possible after sex.
Cystitis has Preventio: Avoid using deodorant sprays or hygiene products in the genital area.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection has Symptom: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections can cause symptoms such as fever, tiredness and a sore throat. But most healthy people who are infected with CMV have no symptoms.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection has Cause: A cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is caused by a virus of the same name. When CMV is active in your body, you can pass the virus to other people. The virus is spread through body fluids. These include blood, urine, saliva, breast milk, tears, semen and vaginal fluids. Casual contact doesn't spread CMV.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection has Risk Factor: There are no key risk factors for cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. CMV is a widespread and common virus that can infect almost anyone. For instance, 1 in 3 children in the United States get the infection by age 5. More than half of adults become infected by age 40.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection has Complication: Medical conditions called complications that are linked with cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection vary. The possible complications depend on your overall health and when in life you were infected.
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection has Preventio: Careful hygiene is the best way to help prevent cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections in people who haven't already been infected. You can take these steps:
Dandruff has Symptom: Skin flakes on your scalp, hair, eyebrows or shoulders.
Dandruff has Symptom: Itchy scalp.
Dandruff has Symptom: Scaly, crusty scalp in infants. This also is called cradle cap.
Dandruff has Cause: Irritated, oily skin.
Dandruff has Cause: Dry skin.
Dandruff has Cause: A type of fungus called malassezia that lives on the scalps of most adults and feeds on natural oils.
Dandruff has Cause: Sensitivity to hair care products. This is called contact dermatitis.
Dandruff has Cause: Other skin conditions, such as psoriasis and eczema.
Dandruff has Risk Factor: Dandruff often starts in young adulthood and lasts through middle age. But older adults can have it too. For some people, it never goes away.
Dandruff has Risk Factor: Dandruff is more common in males.
Dandruff has Risk Factor: Certain illnesses.
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Symptom: Pain near the base of the thumb

De Quervain tenosynovitis has Symptom: A "sticking" or "stop-and-go" sensation in the thumb when moving it
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Cause: Inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis.
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Cause: Direct injury to the wrist or tendon, which may cause scar tissue that restricts movement of the tendons
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Cause: Fluid retention, such as from changes in hormones during pregnancy
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Risk Factor: People between the ages of 30 and 50 have a higher risk of developing de Quervain tenosynovitis than do people in other age groups, including children.
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Risk Factor: The condition is more common in women.
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Risk Factor: Being pregnant.
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Risk Factor: Baby care.
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Risk Factor: Jobs or hobbies that involve repetitive hand and wrist motions.
De Quervain tenosynovitis has Complication: When de Quervain tenosynovitis goes untreated, it can become difficult to use the hand and wrist properly. The wrist may lose some range of motion.
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has Symptom: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) symptoms can include:
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has Cause: Anything that prevents the blood from flowing or properly clotting can cause a blood clot.
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has Risk Factor: Many things can increase the risk of developing DVT. The more risk factors you have, the greater your risk of DVT. Risk factors for DVT include:
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has Complication: Complications of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can include:
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has Preventio: Lifestyle changes may help prevent deep vein thrombosis. Try these strategies:

Dehydration has Symptom: Thirst isn't always a good way to tell if the body needs water. Many people, mainly older adults, don't feel thirsty until they're dehydrated. That's why it's important to increase water intake during hot weather or while ill.

Dehydration has Cause: Sometimes dehydration occurs for simple reasons. These include not drinking enough water. This can happen when you're sick or too busy to remember to drink enough. Or there might be no safe water to drink when traveling, hiking or camping.
Dehydration has Risk Factor: Anyone can get dehydrated. But certain people are at greater risk. They include:
Dehydration has Complication: Dehydration can lead to serious complications, including:

Dehydration has Preventio: To keep from getting dehydrated, drink fluids and eat foods that hold a lot of water, such as fruits and vegetables. Don't drink fluids that have caffeine or a lot of sugar, such as sodas and some energy drinks. They can be dehydrating.

Delayed ejaculation has Symptom: Generalized versus situational.
Delayed ejaculation has Cause: Depression, anxiety or other mental health conditions.
Delayed ejaculation has Cause: Relationship problems due to stress, not communicating well or other concerns.
Delayed ejaculation has Cause: Anxiety about performance.
Delayed ejaculation has Cause: Poor body image.
Delayed ejaculation has Cause: Cultural or religious taboos.
Delayed ejaculation has Cause: Differences between the reality of sex with a partner and sexual fantasies.
Delayed ejaculation has Risk Factor: Older age. With aging, ejaculation takes longer.
Delayed ejaculation has Risk Factor: Psychological conditions, such as depression or anxiety.
Delayed ejaculation has Risk Factor: Medical conditions, such as diabetes or multiple sclerosis.
Delayed ejaculation has Risk Factor: Certain medical treatments, such as prostate surgery.
Delayed ejaculation has Risk Factor: Medicines, such as certain antidepressants, high blood pressure medicines or water pills, called diuretics.
Delayed ejaculation has Risk Factor: Relationship problems, such as not being able to talk to your partner.
Delayed ejaculation has Risk Factor: Excessive alcohol use, especially long-term heavy drinking.
Delayed ejaculation has Complication: Less sexual pleasure for you and your partner.
Delayed ejaculation has Complication: Stress or anxiety about having sex.
Delayed ejaculation has Complication: Marital or relationship problems due to a poor sex life.
Delayed ejaculation has Complication: Not being able to get your partner pregnant, called infertility.
Delayed sleep phase has Symptom: Not being able to fall asleep at a typical bedtime, known as insomnia.
Delayed sleep phase has Symptom: Trouble waking up in the morning in time to go to work or school.
Delayed sleep phase has Symptom: Extreme daytime drowsiness.
Delayed sleep phase has Symptom: Trouble staying alert during the day.

Delayed sleep phase has Cause: Delayed sleep phase is caused by a person's internal clock being out of sync with the environment. Your internal clock lets you know when it's time to sleep and when it's time to wake. Known as circadian rhythm, your internal clock is on a 24-hour cycle. Cues in the environment influence the sleep-wake cycle. These cues include light, darkness, eating and physical activity.
Delayed sleep phase has Risk Factor: Delayed sleep phase can affect children and adults of any age. However, delayed sleep phase is more common among teenagers and young adults.

Delirium has Symptom: Symptoms of delirium usually begin over a few hours or a few days. They typically occur with a medical problem. Symptoms often come and go during the day. There may be periods of no symptoms. Symptoms tend to be worse at night when it's dark and things look less familiar. They also tend to be worse in settings that aren't familiar, such as in a hospital.
Delirium has Cause: Certain medicines or medicine side effects
Delirium has Cause: Alcohol or drug use or withdrawal
Delirium has Cause: A medical condition such as a stroke, heart attack, worsening lung or liver disease, or an injury from a fall
Delirium has Cause: An imbalance in the body, such as low sodium or low calcium
Delirium has Cause: Severe, long-lasting illness or an illness that will lead to death
Delirium has Cause: Fever and a new infection, particularly in children
Delirium has Cause: Urinary tract infection, pneumonia, the flu orCOVID-19, especially in older adults
Delirium has Cause: Exposure to a toxin, such as carbon monoxide, cyanide or other poisons
Delirium has Cause: Poor nutrition or a loss of too much body fluid
Delirium has Cause: Lack of sleep or severe emotional distress
Delirium has Cause: Pain
Delirium has Cause: Surgery or another medical procedure that requires being put in a sleep-like state
Delirium has Risk Factor: Brain disorders such as dementia, stroke or Parkinson's disease
Delirium has Risk Factor: Past delirium episodes
Delirium has Risk Factor: Vision or hearing loss
Delirium has Risk Factor: Multiple medical problems
Delirium has Complication: A general decline in health
Delirium has Complication: Poor recovery from surgery
Delirium has Complication: The need for long-term care
Delirium has Complication: An increased risk of death

Delirium has Preventio: The best way to prevent delirium is to target risk factors that might trigger an episode. Hospital settings present a special challenge. Hospital stays often involve room changes, invasive procedures, loud noises and poor lighting. Lack of natural light and lack of sleep can make confusion worse.
Dementia has Symptom: Dementia symptoms vary depending on the cause. Common symptoms include:

Dementia has Cause: Dementia is caused by damage to or loss of nerve cells and their connections in the brain. The symptoms depend on the area of the brain that's affected. Dementia can affect people differently.
Dementia has Risk Factor: Many factors can eventually contribute to dementia. Some factors, such as age, can't be changed, but you can address other factors to reduce your risk.
Dementia has Complication: Poor nutrition.
Dementia has Complication: Pneumonia.
Dementia has Complication: Inability to perform self-care tasks.
Dementia has Complication: Personal safety challenges.
Dementia has Complication: Death.
Dementia has Preventio: Keep your mind active.
Dementia has Preventio: Be physically and socially active.
Dementia has Preventio: Quit smoking.
Dementia has Preventio: Get enough vitamins.
Dementia has Preventio: Manage cardiovascular risk factors.
Dementia has Preventio: Take care of your mental health.
Dementia has Preventio: Maintain a healthy diet.
Dementia has Preventio: Get good-quality sleep.
Dementia has Preventio: Treat hearing loss.
Dementia has Preventio: Get regular eye exams and treat vision loss.
Dengue fever has Symptom: Headache
Dengue fever has Symptom: Muscle, bone or joint pain
Dengue fever has Symptom: Nausea
Dengue fever has Symptom: Vomiting
Dengue fever has Symptom: Pain behind the eyes
Dengue fever has Symptom: Swollen glands
Dengue fever has Symptom: Rash

Dengue fever has Cause: Dengue fever is caused by any one of four types of dengue viruses. You can't get dengue fever from being around an infected person. Instead, dengue fever is spread through mosquito bites.
Dengue fever has Risk Factor: You live or travel in tropical areas.
Dengue fever has Risk Factor: You have had dengue fever in the past.

Dengue fever has Complication: Severe dengue fever can cause internal bleeding and organ damage. Blood pressure can drop to dangerous levels, causing shock. In some cases, severe dengue fever can lead to death.

Dengue fever has Preventio: Dengue fever vaccines may be available for people ages 6 to 60. Dengue vaccination is a series of two or three doses, depending on the vaccine you get, over the course of months. These vaccines are for use by people who live where the viruses that cause dengue are common, and who have already had dengue fever at least once.

Depersonalization-derealization disorder has Symptom: Short experiences of depersonalization or derealization are fairly common. But lasting and returning bouts of these symptoms can cause problems at work or school, or in other important areas of your life. During these bouts, you know that your sense of not being connected to your body or your surroundings are only feelings and not reality.

Diabetic ketoacidosis has Cause: The cause of ketoacidosis is not having enough insulin in the body. Glucose is a main source of energy for the cells that make up muscles and other tissues. Insulin helps glucose enter the cells.

Diabetic retinopathy has Cause: Over time, too much sugar in your blood causes damage to the tiny blood vessels that nourish the retina, cutting off its blood supply. In advanced stages of diabetic retinopathy, the eye tries to grow new blood vessels. These new blood vessels don't develop correctly and can leak or bleed easily.
Diabetic retinopathy has Risk Factor: Anyone who has diabetes can develop diabetic retinopathy. However, the risk may increase as a result of:

Diabetic retinopathy has Preventio: You can't always prevent diabetic retinopathy. However, regular eye exams, good management of your blood sugar and blood pressure, and early treatment of vision problems can help stop vision loss.

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has Symptom: Fast-growing mass in the neck or belly.

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Cancer happens when cells develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the DNA changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: DLBCL can happen at any age. But it's most common in people 60 or older.
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: A family history of lymphoma.

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has Risk Factor: Some infections.
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has Complication: Complications of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma can include side effects of treatment and risk of relapse.

Diffuse midline glioma (DMG) has Cause: The cause of diffuse midline glioma (DMG) isn't completely understood. It's thought to be caused by a gene change that is not expected, such as a random mistake. Genes provide a set of instructions for every cell that tell it how to grow and function. Gene changes, also called mutations, happen when there is an error in these instructions.
Diffuse midline glioma (DMG) has Risk Factor: There are no known risk factors for diffuse midline glioma and no known way to prevent these tumors.

DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) has Symptom: Heart issues, such as problems with the structure of the heart and vessels, or a heart murmur and bluish skin because of poor circulation of blood, also known as cyanosis.

Asymmetric crying facies also may be present. This is when muscles on one side of the mouth don't develop fully, causing that side of the mouth to droop when crying, though the face looks balanced at rest.

DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) has Cause: Each person has two copies of chromosome 22 — one inherited from each parent. If a person has DiGeorge syndrome, one copy of chromosome 22 is missing a segment that includes an estimated 30 to 40 genes. Many of these genes haven't been clearly identified and aren't well understood. The region of chromosome 22 that's deleted is known as 22q11.2.

DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) has Risk Factor: Babies who are missing a portion of chromosome 22, specifically a region known as 22q11.2, are most at risk of DiGeorge syndrome. This missing portion causes several body systems to develop poorly.

DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) has Preventio: In some cases, an affected parent may pass DiGeorge syndrome to a child. If you're worried about a family history of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome or if you already have a child with the syndrome, you may want to see a doctor who specializes in genetic conditions. This doctor is called a geneticist. Or you may want to see a genetic counselor to help plan future pregnancies.
