Factor V Leiden has Symptom: The factor V Leiden mutation does not itself cause any symptoms. Since factor V Leiden is a risk for developing blood clots in the leg or lungs, the first indication that you have the disorder may be the development of an abnormal blood clot.

Factor V Leiden has Cause: If you have factor V Leiden, you inherited either one copy or, rarely, two copies of the defective gene. Inheriting one copy slightly increases your risk of developing blood clots. Inheriting two copies — one from each parent — significantly increases your risk of developing blood clots.
Factor V Leiden has Risk Factor: Two faulty genes.
Factor V Leiden has Risk Factor: Immobility.
Factor V Leiden has Risk Factor: Estrogens.
Factor V Leiden has Risk Factor: Surgeries or injuries.
Factor V Leiden has Risk Factor: Non-O blood type.
Factor V Leiden has Complication: Factor V Leiden can cause blood clots in the legs (deep vein thrombosis) and lungs (pulmonary embolism). These blood clots can be life-threatening.

Familial adenomatous polyposis has Symptom: The main sign of FAP is hundreds or even thousands of polyps growing in your colon and rectum, usually starting by your mid-teens. The polyps are nearly 100 percent certain to develop into colon cancer or rectal cancer by the time you're in your 40s.

Familial adenomatous polyposis has Cause: Familial adenomatous polyposis is caused by a defect in a gene that's usually inherited from a parent. But some people develop the abnormal gene that causes the condition.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Risk Factor: Your risk of familial adenomatous polyposis is higher if you have a parent, child, brother, or sister with the condition.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Duodenal polyps.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Periampullary polyps.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Gastric fundic polyps.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Desmoids.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Other cancers.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Noncancerous (benign) skin tumors.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Benign bone growths (osteomas).
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE).
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Dental abnormalities.
Familial adenomatous polyposis has Complication: Low numbers of red blood cells (anemia).

Familial adenomatous polyposis has Preventio: Preventing FAP is not possible, since it is an inherited genetic condition. However, if you or your child is at risk of FAP because of a family member with the condition, you will need genetic testing and counseling.

Familial hypercholesterolemia has Symptom: Adults and children who have familial hypercholesterolemia have very high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in their blood. LDL cholesterol is known as "bad" cholesterol because it can build up in the walls of the arteries, making them hard and narrow.

Familial hypercholesterolemia has Cause: A gene alteration that's passed down from one or both parents causes familial hypercholesterolemia. People who have this condition are born with it. This gene alteration prevents the body from ridding itself of the type of cholesterol that can build up in the arteries and cause heart disease.

Familial hypercholesterolemia has Risk Factor: The risk of familial hypercholesterolemia is higher if one or both parents have the gene alteration that causes it. Most people who have the condition receive one affected gene. But in rare cases, a child can get the affected gene from both parents. This can cause a more serious form of the condition.

Familial hypercholesterolemia has Complication: People who have familial hypercholesterolemia have a higher risk of heart disease and death at a younger age. Heart attacks may occur before age 50 in men and age 60 in women. The rare and more serious form of the condition, if not diagnosed or treated, can cause death before age 20.

Familial Mediterranean fever has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) usually begin during childhood. They occur in bouts called attacks that last 1-3 days. Arthritic attacks may last for weeks or months.

Familial Mediterranean fever has Cause: Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is caused by a gene change (mutation) that's passed from parents to children. The gene change affects the function of an immune system protein called pyrin, causing problems in regulating inflammation in the body.
Familial Mediterranean fever has Risk Factor: Factors that may increase the risk of familial Mediterranean fever include:
Familial Mediterranean fever has Complication: Complications can occur if familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) isn't treated. Inflammation can lead to complications such as:
Farsightedness has Symptom: Nearby objects appear blurry.
Farsightedness has Symptom: You need to squint to see clearly.
Farsightedness has Symptom: You have eyestrain, including burning eyes and aching in or around the eyes.
Farsightedness has Symptom: You have general eye discomfort or a headache after doing close tasks, such as reading, writing, computer work or drawing, for a time.
Farsightedness has Cause: The cornea
Farsightedness has Cause: The lens
Farsightedness has Risk Factor: Farsightedness can run in families. You're more likely to be farsighted if other family members have the condition.
Farsightedness has Complication: Crossed eyes.
Farsightedness has Complication: Reduced quality of life.
Farsightedness has Complication: Eyestrain.
Farsightedness has Complication: Compromised safety.
Febrile seizure has Symptom: Usually, a child having a febrile seizure shakes all over and loses consciousness. Sometimes, the child may get very stiff or twitch in just one area of the body.
Febrile seizure has Cause: Usually, a higher than normal body temperature causes febrile seizures. Even a low-grade fever can trigger a febrile seizure.
Febrile seizure has Risk Factor: Factors that increase the risk of having a febrile seizure include:

Febrile seizure has Complication: Most febrile seizures produce no lasting effects. Simple febrile seizures don't cause brain damage, intellectual disability or learning disabilities, and they don't mean your child has a more serious underlying disorder.
Febrile seizure has Preventio: Most febrile seizures occur in the first few hours of a fever, during the initial rise in body temperature.
Fecal incontinence has Symptom: Urge incontinence
Fecal incontinence has Symptom: Passive incontinence
Fecal incontinence has Cause: Loose or watery stool that quickly fills the rectum and is difficult to hold.
Fecal incontinence has Cause: Large, hard stool that blocks the rectum and results in leakage of softer stool around it.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Fecal incontinence is more likely in adults over 65.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Fecal incontinence is more common in women, likely because of possible injuries during delivery. Hormone treatments for menopause also may increase the risk.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Diseases of the digestive system.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Inflammatory bowel disease, such as Crohn's disease.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Irritable bowel syndrome.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Celiac disease.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Mental disability.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Physical disability.
Fecal incontinence has Risk Factor: Lifestyle factors.
Fecal incontinence has Complication: Emotional distress.
Fecal incontinence has Complication: Tissue irritation.
Fecal incontinence has Preventio: Reduce constipation.
Fecal incontinence has Preventio: Control diarrhea.
Fecal incontinence has Preventio: Do not strain.

Female infertility has Symptom: The main symptom of infertility is the inability to get pregnant. A menstrual cycle that's too long (35 days or more), too short (less than 21 days), irregular or absent can mean that you're not ovulating. There might be no other signs or symptoms.
Female infertility has Cause: For pregnancy to occur, every step of the human reproduction process has to happen correctly. The steps in this process are:
Female infertility has Risk Factor: Certain factors may put you at higher risk of infertility, including:
Female infertility has Preventio: For women thinking about getting pregnant soon or in the future, these tips might help:
Female sexual dysfunction has Symptom: Low sexual desire.
Female sexual dysfunction has Symptom: Sexual arousal disorder.
Female sexual dysfunction has Symptom: Orgasmic disorder.
Female sexual dysfunction has Symptom: Sexual pain disorder.
Female sexual dysfunction has Cause: Physical.
Female sexual dysfunction has Cause: Hormonal.
Female sexual dysfunction has Cause: Psychological and social.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: Depression, anxiety and other mental health conditions.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: Heart disease, diabetes, cancer.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: Conditions of the spine and brain, called neurological. Examples are spinal cord injury or multiple sclerosis.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: Gynecological conditions, including infections.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: Certain medicines, such as those taken for depression or high blood pressure.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: Emotional or psychological stress, especially stress in your relationship with your partner.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: A history of sexual abuse.
Female sexual dysfunction has Risk Factor: Lack of privacy.

Fetal alcohol syndrome has Symptom: The severity of fetal alcohol syndrome symptoms varies. Some children have far greater problems than others do. Symptoms of fetal alcohol syndrome may include any mix of issues with how the body develops; thinking, learning and behavior; and functioning and coping in daily life.

Fetal alcohol syndrome has Cause: Alcohol goes into your bloodstream. Inside the womb, the placenta provides oxygen and nutrients to a developing baby. The alcohol reaches your baby by passing through the placenta.

Fetal alcohol syndrome has Cause: Alcohol causes a higher blood alcohol level in your developing baby than in your body. That's because a baby breaks down and gets rid of alcohol slower than an adult does.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Cause: Alcohol is toxic to the baby's cells. Exposure to alcohol before birth can harm how the body develops and cause permanent brain damage in the developing baby.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Risk Factor: You're pregnant.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Risk Factor: You think you might be pregnant.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Risk Factor: You're trying to become pregnant.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Aggression, improper social behavior, and breaking rules and laws.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Alcohol or recreational drug misuse.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Mental health conditions, such as depression, anxiety or eating disorders.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Challenges staying in or completing school.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Not being able to get along with others.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Challenges with independent living and getting and keeping jobs.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Sexual behaviors that are not proper.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Complication: Early death by accident, homicide or suicide.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Preventio: Don't drink alcohol if you're trying to get pregnant.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Preventio: Don't drink alcohol at any time during your pregnancy.
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Preventio: Consider giving up alcohol during your childbearing years
Fetal alcohol syndrome has Preventio: If you have an alcohol problem, get help before you get pregnant.
Fetal macrosomia has Symptom: Fetal macrosomia can be hard to find and identify during pregnancy. Symptoms include the following.

Fetal macrosomia has Cause: Genetic factors and health conditions that affect a pregnant person, such as obesity or diabetes, can cause fetal macrosomia. Rarely, a medical condition in a fetus might make the fetus grow faster and larger than is typical. Sometimes the cause of fetal macrosomia is not known.
Fetal macrosomia has Risk Factor: Many factors can raise the risk of fetal macrosomia. Examples include:

Fetal macrosomia has Complication: Fetal macrosomia poses a number of health risks, called complications, for the pregnant person and the fetus. Some of these issues also can affect a baby's health after birth.
Fetal macrosomia has Preventio: It may not be possible to prevent fetal macrosomia. But taking the following steps to promote a healthy pregnancy could lower the risk of macrosomia.

Fever has Symptom: Body temperatures vary slightly from person to person and at different times of day. The average temperature has traditionally been defined as 98.6 F (37 C). A temperature taken using a mouth thermometer (oral temperature) that's 100 F (37.8 C) or higher is generally considered to be a fever.

Fever has Cause: Typical body temperature is a balance of heat production and heat loss. An area in the brain called the hypothalamus (hi-poe-THAL-uh-muhs) — also known as your body's "thermostat" — monitors this balance. Even when you're healthy, your body temperature varies slightly throughout the day. It can be lower in the morning and higher in the late afternoon and evening.

Fever has Complication: Children between the ages of 6 months and 5 years are at increased risk of a seizure that occurs during a fever (febrile seizure). About a third of the children who have one febrile seizure will have another one, most commonly within the next 12 months.
Fever has Preventio: You may be able to prevent fevers by reducing exposure to infectious diseases. Here are some tips that can help:
Fibroadenoma has Symptom: Round with distinct, smooth borders
Fibroadenoma has Symptom: Easily moved
Fibroadenoma has Symptom: Firm or rubbery
Fibroadenoma has Cause: Complex fibroadenomas.
Fibroadenoma has Cause: Giant fibroadenomas.
Fibroadenoma has Cause: Phyllodes tumors.
Fibroadenoma has Complication: Common fibroadenomas do not affect your risk of breast cancer. But your risk might go up a bit if you have a complex fibroadenoma or a phyllodes tumor.
Fibrocystic breasts has Symptom: Breast lumps or areas of thickening that tend to blend into the surrounding breast tissue
Fibrocystic breasts has Symptom: Generalized breast pain or tenderness or discomfort that involves the upper outer part of the breast
Fibrocystic breasts has Symptom: Breast nodules or lumpy tissue change in size with the menstrual cycle
Fibrocystic breasts has Symptom: Green or dark brown nonbloody nipple discharge that tends to leak without pressure or squeezing
Fibrocystic breasts has Symptom: Breast changes that are similar in both breasts
Fibrocystic breasts has Symptom: Monthly increase in breast pain or lumpiness from midcycle (ovulation) to just before your period and then gets better once your period starts
Fibrocystic breasts has Cause: Fluid-filled round or oval sacs (cysts)
Fibrocystic breasts has Cause: A prominence of scar-like fibrous tissue (fibrosis)
Fibrocystic breasts has Cause: Overgrowth of cells (hyperplasia) lining the milk ducts or milk-producing tissues (lobules) of the breast
Fibrocystic breasts has Cause: Enlarged breast lobules (adenosis)
Fibrocystic breasts has Complication: Having fibrocystic breasts doesn't increase your risk of breast cancer.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Symptom: High blood pressure.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Symptom: Problems with how the kidneys work.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Cause: The cause of fibromuscular dysplasia is not known. Changes in genes might cause the condition.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Risk Factor: The condition is more common in women than it is in men.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Risk Factor: Fibromuscular dysplasia tends to be diagnosed in people in their 50s. But it can affect anyone of any age.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Complication: High blood pressure.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Complication: Tears in the artery walls.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Complication: Bulge or ballooning of an artery.
Fibromuscular dysplasia has Complication: Stroke.
Fibromyalgia has Symptom: The main symptoms of fibromyalgia include:

Fibromyalgia has Cause: With fibromyalgia, many researchers think nerves are affected in a way that causes the brain and spinal cord to change. This change involves an irregular rise in levels of certain chemicals in the brain that signal pain.
Fibromyalgia has Risk Factor: Risk factors for fibromyalgia include:

Fibromyalgia has Complication: The pain, fatigue, and poor sleep linked with fibromyalgia can affect your personal life and career. It also can be stressful to live with a condition that's often misunderstood by others. That can lead to mental health conditions such as depression and anxiety.

Flatfeet has Symptom: Most people have no symptoms associated with flatfeet. But some people with flatfeet experience foot pain, particularly in the heel or arch area. Pain may worsen with activity. Swelling may occur along the inside of the ankle.

Flatfeet has Cause: Flatfeet is not unusual in infants and toddlers, because the foot's arch hasn't yet developed. Most people's arches develop throughout childhood, but some people never develop arches. People without arches may or may not have problems.
Flatfeet has Risk Factor: Obesity
Flatfeet has Risk Factor: Injury to the foot or ankle
Flatfeet has Risk Factor: Rheumatoid arthritis
Flatfeet has Risk Factor: Aging
Flatfeet has Risk Factor: Diabetes
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Mouth pain.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Sores in the mouth that won't heal.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Trouble moving the tongue.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Loose teeth.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Pain with swallowing.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Weight loss.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Ear pain.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: Swelling in the neck that may hurt.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Symptom: White patches in the mouth that won't go away.

Floor of the mouth cancer has Cause: Floor of the mouth cancer happens when cells under the tongue develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell a cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions also tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the DNA changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Risk Factor: Using tobacco.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Risk Factor: Drinking alcohol.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Risk Factor: Being exposed to human papillomavirus.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Risk Factor: Having a weak immune system.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Preventio: Don't use tobacco.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Preventio: Limit alcohol intake.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Preventio: Ask about theHPVvaccine.
Floor of the mouth cancer has Preventio: Have regular health and dental exams.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Symptom: Swelling, called edema, in the legs and ankles, around the eyes and in other body parts.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Symptom: Weight gain from fluid buildup.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Symptom: Foamy urine from protein buildup, called proteinuria.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Cause: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can be caused by a variety of conditions, such as diabetes, sickle cell disease, other kidney diseases and obesity. Infections and damage from illicit drugs, medicines or toxins also can cause it. Gene changes passed through families, called inherited gene changes, can cause a rare form ofFSGS. Sometimes there's no known cause.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Risk Factor: Certain diseases and conditions increase the risk of gettingFSGS. These include diabetes, lupus, obesity and other kidney diseases.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Risk Factor: Certain infections.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Risk Factor: Gene changes.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Complication: Nephrotic syndrome.
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) has Complication: Kidney failure.
Follicular lymphoma has Symptom: Painless swelling in the neck, armpit or groin.
Follicular lymphoma has Symptom: Fatigue.
Follicular lymphoma has Symptom: Fever.
Follicular lymphoma has Symptom: Night sweats.
Follicular lymphoma has Symptom: Losing weight without trying.
Follicular lymphoma has Symptom: Feeling full quickly.
Follicular lymphoma has Cause: Lymph nodes.
Follicular lymphoma has Cause: Bone marrow.
Follicular lymphoma has Cause: Spleen.
Follicular lymphoma has Cause: Liver.
Follicular lymphoma has Cause: Digestive tract.
Follicular lymphoma has Cause: Skin.
Follicular lymphoma has Risk Factor: Follicular lymphoma can happen at any age. But it's most common in people 60 or older.
Follicular lymphoma has Risk Factor: Race.
Follicular lymphoma has Risk Factor: Having a family history of lymphoma.
Follicular lymphoma has Complication: Complications of follicular lymphoma can include transformation into a fast-growing lymphoma and complications from treatment.
Folliculitis has Symptom: Folliculitis signs and symptoms include:

Folliculitis has Cause: Folliculitis is often caused when hair follicles are infected with bacteria, commonly Staphylococcus aureus (staph). It may also be caused by viruses, fungi, parasites, medications or physical injury. Sometimes the cause isn't known.
Folliculitis has Risk Factor: Anyone can develop folliculitis. Certain factors increase the risk of getting it, including:
Folliculitis has Complication: Possible complications of folliculitis include:
Folliculitis has Preventio: You can try to prevent folliculitis by using these tips:
Food allergy has Symptom: Tingling or itching in the mouth.
Food allergy has Symptom: Hives, itching or eczema.
Food allergy has Symptom: Swelling of the lips, face, tongue, and throat or other parts of the body.
Food allergy has Symptom: Belly pain, diarrhea, nausea or vomiting.
Food allergy has Symptom: Wheezing, nasal congestion or trouble breathing.
Food allergy has Symptom: Dizziness, lightheadedness or fainting.
Food allergy has Cause: Crustacean shellfish, such as shrimp, lobster and crab.
Food allergy has Cause: Peanuts.
Food allergy has Cause: Tree nuts, such as walnuts and pecans.
Food allergy has Cause: Fish.
Food allergy has Cause: Chicken eggs.
Food allergy has Cause: Cow's milk.
Food allergy has Cause: Wheat.
Food allergy has Cause: Soy.
Food allergy has Risk Factor: Family history.
Food allergy has Risk Factor: Other allergies.

Food allergy has Risk Factor: Food allergies are more common in children, especially toddlers and infants. As children grow older, their digestive systems mature and their bodies are less likely to react to food components that trigger allergies.Fortunately, children typically outgrow allergies to milk, soy, wheat and eggs. Severe allergies and allergies to nuts and shellfish are more likely to be lifelong.
Food allergy has Risk Factor: Asthma.
Food allergy has Complication: Anaphylaxis.
Food allergy has Complication: Atopic dermatitis, known as eczema.

Food allergy has Preventio: Early introduction of peanut products has been associated with a lower risk of peanut allergy. In an important study, high-risk infants — such as those with atopic dermatitis or egg allergy or both — were selected to either ingest or avoid peanut products from 4 to 6 months of age until 5 years of age.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Symptom: Upset stomach.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Symptom: Vomiting.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Symptom: Loose stools, sometimes bloody.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Symptom: Stomach pain and cramps.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Symptom: Fever.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Cause: Bacteria.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Cause: Viruses.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Cause: Parasites that can live in the intestines.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Cause: Harmful chemicals, also called toxins.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Cause: Bacteria that carry or make toxins.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Cause: Molds that make toxins.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Risk Factor: Infants and children.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Risk Factor: People who are pregnant and their unborn babies, called fetuses.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Risk Factor: Older adults.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Risk Factor: People with weakened immune systems due to another disease or treatments.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Complication: Complications of food poisoning, a type of foodborne illness, are not common for most healthy adults. Complications may include the following.
Food poisoning (foodborne illness) has Preventio: The following can help prevent food poisoning, a type of foodborne illness, at home.

Foot drop has Symptom: Foot drop makes it difficult to lift the front part of the foot, so it might drag on the floor when you walk. To help the foot clear the floor, a person with foot drop may raise the thigh more than usual when walking, as though climbing stairs. This unusual kind of walking, called steppage gait, might cause the foot to slap down onto the floor with each step. In some cases, the skin on the top of the foot and toes feels numb.
Foot drop has Cause: Nerve injury.
Foot drop has Cause: Muscle or nerve disorders.
Foot drop has Cause: Brain and spinal cord disorders.
Foot drop has Risk Factor: Leg crossing.
Foot drop has Risk Factor: Prolonged kneeling.
Foot drop has Risk Factor: Wearing a leg cast.
Frontal lobe seizures has Symptom: Head and eye movement to one side.
Frontal lobe seizures has Symptom: Not responding to others or having trouble speaking.
Frontal lobe seizures has Symptom: Explosive screams, including profanities or laughter.
Frontal lobe seizures has Symptom: Body posturing. A common posture is extending one arm while the other flexes, as if the person is posing like a fencer.
Frontal lobe seizures has Symptom: Repetitive movements. These may include rocking, bicycle pedaling or pelvic thrusting.
Frontal lobe seizures has Cause: Frontal lobe seizures can be caused by tumors, stroke, infection or traumatic injuries in the brain's frontal lobes.
Frontal lobe seizures has Risk Factor: Family history of seizures or brain disorders.
Frontal lobe seizures has Risk Factor: Head trauma.
Frontal lobe seizures has Risk Factor: Brain infection.
Frontal lobe seizures has Risk Factor: Brain tumors.
Frontal lobe seizures has Risk Factor: Blood vessels or brain tissues that form in an irregular way.
Frontal lobe seizures has Risk Factor: Stroke.
Frontal lobe seizures has Complication: Seizures that last dangerously long.
Frontal lobe seizures has Complication: Injury.
Frontal lobe seizures has Complication: Sudden unexplained death in epilepsy (SUDEP).
Frontal lobe seizures has Complication: Depression and anxiety.
Frontotemporal dementia has Symptom: Symptoms of frontotemporal dementia differ from one person to the next. Symptoms get worse over time, usually over years.

Frontotemporal dementia has Cause: In frontotemporal dementia, the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain shrink and certain substances build up in the brain. What causes these changes is usually not known.
Frontotemporal dementia has Risk Factor: Your risk of getting frontotemporal dementia is higher if you have a family history of dementia. There are no other known risk factors.
Frostbite has Symptom: Numbness.
Frostbite has Symptom: Tingling.
Frostbite has Symptom: Patches of skin in shades of red, white, blue, gray, purple or brown. The color of affected skin depends on how serious the frostbite is and the usual skin color.
Frostbite has Symptom: Cold, hard, waxy-looking skin.
Frostbite has Symptom: Clumsiness due to joint stiffness.
Frostbite has Symptom: Pain.
Frostbite has Symptom: Blistering after rewarming.

Frostbite has Cause: The most common cause of frostbite is exposure to freezing cold. The risk rises if the weather also is wet and windy. Frostbite also can be caused by direct contact with ice, freezing metals or very cold liquids.
Frostbite has Risk Factor: Being in freezing conditions without protective clothing.
Frostbite has Risk Factor: Having certain medical conditions, such as diabetes, exhaustion, poor blood flow or congestive heart failure.
Frostbite has Risk Factor: Regularly smoking tobacco.
Frostbite has Risk Factor: Having impaired judgment while in very cold conditions.
Frostbite has Risk Factor: Having had frostbite or another cold injury in the past.
Frostbite has Risk Factor: Being an infant or older adult in cold conditions. People in these age groups have a harder time producing and retaining body heat.
Frostbite has Risk Factor: Being in cold conditions at high altitude.
Frostbite has Complication: Hypothermia.
Frostbite has Complication: Increased sensitivity to cold and a higher risk of frostbite in the future.
Frostbite has Complication: Long-term numbness in the affected area.
Frostbite has Complication: Excessive sweating, also called hyperhidrosis.
Frostbite has Complication: Changes in or loss of nails.
Frostbite has Complication: Growth problems in children if frostbite damages a bone's growth plate.
Frostbite has Complication: Infection.
Frostbite has Complication: Tetanus.
Frostbite has Complication: Gangrene, which can result in having the affected area removed. This procedure is called amputation.
Frostbite has Preventio: Limit time outdoors when it's freezing cold and wet or windy.
Frostbite has Preventio: Dress in loose layers.
Frostbite has Preventio: Wear a hat or headband made for cold weather.
Frostbite has Preventio: Wear mittens.
Frostbite has Preventio: Wear socks and sock liners.
Frostbite has Preventio: Watch for symptoms of frostbite.
Frostbite has Preventio: Plan to protect yourself.
Frostbite has Preventio: Don't drink alcohol if you plan to be outdoors in cold weather.
Frostbite has Preventio: Eat well-balanced meals and stay hydrated.
Frostbite has Preventio: Keep moving.
Frozen shoulder has Symptom: Freezing stage.
Frozen shoulder has Symptom: Frozen stage.
Frozen shoulder has Symptom: Thawing stage.

Frozen shoulder has Cause: The shoulder joint is enclosed in a capsule of connective tissue. Frozen shoulder occurs when this capsule thickens and tightens around the shoulder joint, restricting its movement.
Frozen shoulder has Risk Factor: Certain factors may increase the risk of developing frozen shoulder.

Frozen shoulder has Preventio: One of the most common causes of frozen shoulder is not moving a shoulder while recovering from a shoulder injury, broken arm or stroke. If you've had an injury that makes it difficult to move your shoulder, talk to your health care provider about exercises that can help you maintain your ability to move your shoulder joint.
Fuchs dystrophy has Symptom: Blurred or cloudy vision, sometimes described as a lack of clear vision.

Fuchs dystrophy has Symptom: Changes in vision throughout the day. Symptoms are worse in the morning when you wake up and slowly get better during the day. As the disease gets worse, blurred vision may take longer to get better or does not get better at all.
Fuchs dystrophy has Symptom: Glare, which can decrease your vision in dim and bright light.
Fuchs dystrophy has Symptom: Seeing halos around lights.
Fuchs dystrophy has Symptom: Pain or grittiness from tiny blisters on the surface of your cornea.

Fuchs dystrophy has Cause: The cells lining the inside of the cornea are called endothelial cells. Those cells help maintain a healthy balance of fluid within the cornea and keep the cornea from swelling. In Fuchs dystrophy, the endothelial cells slowly die or do not work well, causing fluid buildup within the cornea. The fluid buildup, called edema, causes thickening of the cornea and blurred vision.
Fuchs dystrophy has Risk Factor: Fuchs dystrophy is more common in women than in men.
Fuchs dystrophy has Risk Factor: Genetics.

Fuchs dystrophy has Risk Factor: There is a rare early-onset type of Fuchs dystrophy that starts in childhood. Most cases start in the 30s and 40s, but many people with Fuchs dystrophy don't develop symptoms until their 50s or 60s.
Functional dyspepsia has Symptom: Pain or burning in the stomach, bloating, excessive belching or nausea after eating.
Functional dyspepsia has Symptom: An early feeling of fullness when eating. The feeling of fullness also is called satiety.
Functional dyspepsia has Symptom: Stomach pain that happens unrelated to meals or goes away when eating.

Functional dyspepsia has Cause: No one knows what causes functional dyspepsia. Medical professionals consider it a functional disorder. That means it can't be explained by a medical condition, so routine testing may not show any problems or causes. As a result, the diagnosis is based on symptoms.
Functional dyspepsia has Risk Factor: Being female.

Functional dyspepsia has Risk Factor: Using certain pain relievers that are available without a prescription. These include aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), which can cause stomach problems.

Functional dyspepsia has Risk Factor: Anxiety or depression.
Functional dyspepsia has Risk Factor: History of childhood physical or sexual abuse.

Functional neurologic disorder/conversion disorder has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of functional neurologic disorder may vary, depending on the type of functional neurological symptoms, and they're significant enough to cause impairment and warrant medical evaluation. Symptoms can affect body movement and function and the senses.

Functional neurologic disorder/conversion disorder has Cause: The exact cause of functional neurologic disorder is unknown. Theories regarding what happens in the brain to result in symptoms are complex and involve multiple mechanisms that may differ, depending on the type of functional neurological symptoms.
Functional neurologic disorder/conversion disorder has Risk Factor: Factors that may increase your risk of functional neurologic disorder include:

Functional neurologic disorder/conversion disorder has Complication: Some symptoms of functional neurologic disorder, particularly if not treated, can result in substantial disability and poor quality of life, similar to problems caused by medical conditions or disease.

Gastritis has Symptom: Gnawing or burning ache or pain, called indigestion, in your upper belly. This feeling may become either worse or better after eating.
Gastritis has Symptom: Nausea.
Gastritis has Symptom: Vomiting.
Gastritis has Symptom: A feeling of fullness in your upper abdomen after eating.

Gastritis has Cause: Gastritis is an inflammation of the stomach lining. The stomach lining is a mucus-lined barrier that protects the stomach wall. Weaknesses or injury to the barrier allows digestive juices to damage and inflame the stomach lining. Several diseases and conditions can increase the risk of gastritis. These include inflammatory conditions, such as Crohn's disease.
Gastritis has Risk Factor: Bacterial infection.
Gastritis has Risk Factor: Regular use of pain relievers.

Gastritis has Risk Factor: Older adults have an increased risk of gastritis because the stomach lining tends to thin with age. Older adults also have an increased risk because they are more likely to have H. pylori infection or autoimmune disorders than younger people are.
Gastritis has Risk Factor: Excessive alcohol use.
Gastritis has Risk Factor: Stress.
Gastritis has Risk Factor: Cancer treatment.
Gastritis has Risk Factor: Your own body attacking cells in your stomach.
Gastritis has Risk Factor: Other diseases and conditions

Gastritis has Complication: Left untreated, gastritis may lead to stomach ulcers and stomach bleeding. Rarely, some forms of chronic gastritis may increase your risk of stomach cancer. This risk is increased if you have extensive thinning of the stomach lining and changes in the lining's cells.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) has Symptom: A burning sensation in the chest, often called heartburn. Heartburn usually happens after eating and might be worse at night or while lying down.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) has Symptom: Backwash of food or sour liquid in the throat.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) has Symptom: Upper belly or chest pain.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) has Symptom: Sensation of a lump in the throat.

Gastrointestinal bleeding has Symptom: Black, tarry stool.

Gastrointestinal bleeding has Cause: Gastrointestinal bleeding can happen either in the upper or lower gastrointestinal tract.
Gastrointestinal bleeding has Complication: Anemia.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Symptom: A growth in the belly area.
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Symptom: Belly pain.
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Symptom: Fatigue.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Symptom: Feeling full if you eat only a small amount of food.
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Symptom: Dark-colored stools caused by bleeding in the digestive system.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Cause: The cause of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor often isn't known. This cancer, which also is called a GIST, happens in the digestive system. It most often affects the stomach and small intestine. GISTs are thought to begin in nerve cells in the walls of the digestive organs. These nerve cells play a part in the process that moves food through the body.
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Risk Factor: Family history.
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Risk Factor: Hereditary syndromes.
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) has Risk Factor: A GIST can happen at any age. This cancer happens most often in adults. It's rare in children.

Gastroparesis has Symptom: Vomiting undigested food eaten a few hours earlier.
Gastroparesis has Symptom: Acid reflux.
Gastroparesis has Symptom: Changes in blood sugar levels.
Gastroparesis has Symptom: Not wanting to eat.
Gastroparesis has Symptom: Weight loss and not getting enough nutrients, called malnutrition.
Gastroparesis has Cause: It's not always clear what leads to gastroparesis. But sometimes damage to a nerve that controls the stomach muscles can cause it. This nerve is called the vagus nerve.
Gastroparesis has Risk Factor: Diabetes.
Gastroparesis has Risk Factor: Surgery on the stomach area or on the tube that connects the throat to the stomach, called the esophagus.
Gastroparesis has Risk Factor: Infection with a virus.
Gastroparesis has Risk Factor: Certain cancers and cancer treatments, such as radiation therapy to the chest or stomach.

Gastroparesis has Complication: Lower quality of life.
Gaucher disease has Symptom: Some symptoms are shared by all types of Gaucher disease, but each type varies in important ways.

Gaucher disease has Cause: A fatty substance, called glucocerebroside, is a part of a cell's wall and plays an important role in cell activity. When a cell dies, a particular enzyme breaks down this fatty substance.
Gaucher disease has Risk Factor: People of Eastern and Central European Jewish ancestry, called Ashkenazi Jews, are at a higher risk than the general population of developing type 1 Gaucher disease.
Gaucher disease has Complication: Parkinson's disease risk.

Gender dysphoria has Symptom: Gender identity is having the internal sense of being male or female or being somewhere along the gender spectrum, or having an internal sense of gender that is beyond male and female. People who have gender dysphoria feel a big difference between their gender identity and their sex assigned at birth. Gender dysphoria is different from simply not following stereotypical gender behaviors. It involves feelings of distress due to a strong, lasting desire to be another gender.

Gender dysphoria has Complication: Gender dysphoria can affect many parts of life, including daily activities. For example, school might be hard for people with gender dysphoria. That may be due to pressure to dress or act in a way that's linked to their sex assigned at birth. Being harassed, teased or bullied due to gender identity also can make it very challenging to do well in school.
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Persistent worrying or anxiety about a number of areas that are out of proportion to the impact of the events
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Overthinking plans and solutions to all possible worst-case outcomes
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Perceiving situations and events as threatening, even when they aren't
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Difficulty handling uncertainty
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Indecisiveness and fear of making the wrong decision
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Inability to set aside or let go of a worry
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Inability to relax, feeling restless, and feeling keyed up or on edge
Generalized anxiety disorder has Symptom: Difficulty concentrating, or the feeling that your mind "goes blank"
Generalized anxiety disorder has Cause: Differences in brain chemistry and function

Generalized anxiety disorder has Cause: Differences in the way threats are perceived
Generalized anxiety disorder has Cause: Development and personality

Generalized anxiety disorder has Complication: Take your time and focus from other activities
Generalized anxiety disorder has Complication: Sap your energy

Genital herpes has Symptom: Small bumps or blisters around the genitals, anus or mouth
Genital herpes has Symptom: Painful ulcers that form when blisters rupture and ooze or bleed
Genital herpes has Symptom: Scabs that form as the ulcers heal

Genital herpes has Symptom: Discharge from the urethra, the tube that releases urine from the body

Genital herpes has Cause: Genital herpes is caused by two types of herpes simplex virus. These types include herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) and herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). People withHSVinfections can pass along the virus even when they have no visible symptoms.

Genital herpes has Risk Factor: Having sexual contact without using a barrier increases your risk of genital herpes. Barriers include condoms and condom-like protectors called dental dams used during oral sex. Women are at higher risk of getting genital herpes. The virus can spread more easily from men to women than from women to men.

Genital herpes has Risk Factor: The number of people you have sex with is a strong risk factor. Contact with genitals through sex or sexual activity puts you at higher risk. Most people with genital herpes do not know they have it.
Genital herpes has Risk Factor: Having a partner who has the disease but is not taking medicine to treat it.
Genital herpes has Risk Factor: Certain groups within the population.
Genital herpes has Complication: Other sexually transmitted infections.
Genital herpes has Complication: Newborn infection.
Genital herpes has Complication: Internal inflammatory disease.
Genital herpes has Complication: Finger infection.
Genital herpes has Complication: Eye infection.
Genital herpes has Complication: Swelling of the brain.
Genital herpes has Complication: Infection of internal organs.
Genital herpes has Preventio: Have one long-term sexual partner who has been tested forSTIs and isn't infected.
Genital herpes has Preventio: Use a condom or dental dam during sexual activity. These reduce the risk of disease, but they don't prevent all skin-to-skin contact during sex.
Genital herpes has Preventio: Don't have sex when a partner with genital herpes has symptoms.
Genital warts has Symptom: Vulva.
Genital warts has Symptom: Walls of the vagina.
Genital warts has Symptom: Area between the outer part of the genitals and the anus.
Genital warts has Symptom: Anal canal.
Genital warts has Symptom: Cervix.
Genital warts has Symptom: Tip or shaft of the penis.
Genital warts has Symptom: Scrotum.
Genital warts has Symptom: Anus.
Genital warts has Cause: The human papillomavirus (HPV) causes warts. There are more than 40 strains ofHPVthat affect the genital area.
Genital warts has Risk Factor: Not getting theHPVvaccine.
Genital warts has Risk Factor: Having sex without a condom or with more than one partner.
Genital warts has Risk Factor: Having had another sexually transmitted infection.
Genital warts has Risk Factor: Having sex with a partner whose sexual history you don't know.
Genital warts has Risk Factor: Becoming sexually active at a young age.
Genital warts has Risk Factor: Having a weakened immune system, such as fromHIVor medicines from an organ transplant.
Genital warts has Complication: Cancer.
Genital warts has Complication: Problems during pregnancy.

Genital warts has Preventio: Get theHPVvaccine to help prevent genital warts. And if you have sex, limit your number of partners. It's safest to have sex with just one partner who only has sex with you. It's also a good idea to use a condom every time you have sex. But this won't fully protect you from genital warts. That's becauseHPVcan infect parts of the body that the condom doesn't cover.

Geographic atrophy has Symptom: People with geographic atrophy may notice changes in vision that start slowly and get worse over time. Geographic atrophy often starts just outside the center of the retina and slowly moves inward. As it grows, you can lose central vision or have blurred or blind spots.

Geographic atrophy has Cause: Geographic atrophy is an eye condition that can occur in people with another eye condition called dry age-related macular degeneration. It causes gradual loss of vision in people, usually as they age. It affects parts of the retina, the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye.

Geographic tongue has Symptom: Smooth, red, irregularly shaped patches on the top or side of your tongue. These patches may look like sores.
Geographic tongue has Symptom: Frequent changes in the location, size and shape of the patches.
Geographic tongue has Symptom: Pain or burning feeling in some cases, most often related to eating spicy or acidic foods.

Geographic tongue has Cause: The cause of geographic tongue is not known, and there's no way to prevent it. There may be a link between geographic tongue and other conditions, such as psoriasis. This is a skin disease that causes a rash with itchy, scaly patches. But more research is needed to learn about possible connections to other health conditions.
Geographic tongue has Risk Factor: Family history.
Geographic tongue has Risk Factor: Fissured tongue.

Geographic tongue has Complication: Geographic tongue is harmless, but it can sometimes be uncomfortable. It does not pose a threat to your health, cause long-term complications or raise your risk of major health problems.

Germ cell tumors has Symptom: Symptoms of germ cell tumors depend on where they happen. Symptoms often happen because a growing tumor puts pressure on nearby tissue or organs. For example, a germ cell tumor in an ovary may lead to pelvic pain, back pain, bloating or swelling in the belly. A germ cell tumor in a testicle may cause swelling or pain in the testicle or scrotum. A lump in the testicle is a common symptom of a testicular germ cell tumor.

Germ cell tumors has Cause: It's not clear what causes germ cell tumors. Germ cell tumors form in the cells that turn into eggs in the ovaries and into sperm in the testicles. Germ cell tumors happen when germ cells develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA tells the cells to grow and multiply at a set rate. The DNA also tells the cells to die at a set time.

Germ cell tumors has Risk Factor: Germ cell tumors tend to happen at a young age. For example, germ cell tumors that form in the ovaries are more common before age 20. Germ cell tumors that form in the testicles are most common between the ages of 15 and 35.
Germ cell tumors has Risk Factor: Undescended testicle.
Gestational diabetes has Symptom: Most of the time, gestational diabetes doesn't cause symptoms that are easy to notice. Being thirsty and urinating more often are possible symptoms.
Gestational diabetes has Cause: Experts don't yet know why some people get gestational diabetes and others don't. Extra weight before pregnancy often plays a role.
Gestational diabetes has Risk Factor: Risk factors for gestational diabetes include:

Gestational diabetes has Complication: If high blood sugar isn't controlled, it can cause health problems for you and your baby. This includes an increased risk of needing surgery to deliver the baby. That surgery is called a C-section.

Gestational diabetes has Preventio: There is no sure way to prevent gestational diabetes. But having healthy habits before pregnancy can help. If you've had gestational diabetes, these healthy choices also might lower your risk of getting diabetes again. That includes developing gestational diabetes during another pregnancy and developing type 2 diabetes in the future.
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Persistent, severe head pain, usually in your temple area
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Scalp tenderness
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Jaw pain when you chew or open your mouth wide
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Fever
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Fatigue
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Unintended weight loss
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Vision loss or double vision, particularly in people who also have jaw pain
Giant cell arteritis has Symptom: Sudden, permanent loss of vision in one eye

Giant cell arteritis has Cause: With giant cell arteritis, the lining of arteries becomes inflamed, causing them to swell. This swelling narrows your blood vessels, reducing the amount of blood — and, therefore, oxygen and vital nutrients — that reaches your body's tissues.
Giant cell arteritis has Risk Factor: Giant cell arteritis affects adults only, and rarely those under 50. Most people with this condition develop signs and symptoms between the ages of 70 and 80.
Giant cell arteritis has Risk Factor: Women are about two times more likely to develop the condition than men are.
Giant cell arteritis has Risk Factor: Race and geographic region.
Giant cell arteritis has Risk Factor: Polymyalgia rheumatica.
Giant cell arteritis has Risk Factor: Family history.
Giant cell arteritis has Complication: Blindness.
Giant cell arteritis has Complication: Aortic aneurysm.
Giant cell arteritis has Complication: Stroke.

Giardia infection (giardiasis) has Symptom: Some people with giardia infection don't have symptoms. But they still carry the parasite and can spread it to others through their stool. For those who do get sick, symptoms most often appear 1 to 3 weeks after getting the parasite. Symptoms may include:

Giardia infection (giardiasis) has Cause: Giardia parasites can live in the small intestine. Before the tiny parasites pass in stool, they form hard shells called cysts. The cysts let the parasites live outside the intestines for months. Once inside a person or animal, the cysts break down, letting the parasites out.
Giardia infection (giardiasis) has Risk Factor: The giardia parasite is common. Anyone can pick up giardia parasites, but some people are at higher risk, including:

Giardia infection (giardiasis) has Complication: Giardia infection almost never leads to death in developed countries. But it can cause symptoms that last and serious complications, mainly in infants and children. The most common complications include:

Giardia infection (giardiasis) has Preventio: No medicine or vaccine can prevent giardia infection. But the following can go a long way toward cutting the chances that you'll become infected or spread the infection to others.

Gilbert syndrome has Symptom: The most common sign of Gilbert syndrome is an occasional yellowish tinge of the skin and the whites of the eyes, called jaundice. Jaundice is a result of slightly higher levels of bilirubin in the blood.

Gilbert syndrome has Cause: Gilbert syndrome is caused by a modified gene someone inherits from their parents. This gene usually controls an enzyme that helps break down bilirubin in the liver. When someone has this ineffective gene, their blood contains too much bilirubin. This is because the body isn't producing enough of the enzyme.

Gilbert syndrome has Risk Factor: Although it's present from birth, Gilbert syndrome usually isn't noticed until puberty or later. This is because bilirubin production increases during puberty. Risk factors for Gilbert syndrome include:

Gilbert syndrome has Complication: The low level of the bilirubin-processing enzyme that causes Gilbert syndrome also may increase the side effects of certain medicines, since this enzyme plays a role in helping clear these medicines from the body.
Gingivitis has Symptom: Swollen or puffy gums.
Gingivitis has Symptom: Bright red or dark red gums, or gums that are darker than usual.
Gingivitis has Symptom: Gums that bleed easily when you brush or floss.
Gingivitis has Symptom: Tender gums.
Gingivitis has Symptom: Bad breath.
Gingivitis has Cause: Plaque forms on your teeth.
Gingivitis has Cause: Plaque turns into tartar.
Gingivitis has Cause: Gingiva becomes irritated and swells.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Poor oral care habits.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Smoking or chewing tobacco.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Older age.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Dry mouth.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Poor nutrition, including not getting enough vitamin C.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Repairs to teeth that don't fit properly or are in poor condition, such as fillings, bridges, dental implants or veneers.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Crooked teeth that are hard to clean.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Conditions that lower immunity, such as leukemia,HIV/AIDSor cancer treatment.

Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Certain drugs, such as phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek, others) for epileptic seizures and some calcium channel blockers used for angina, high blood pressure and other conditions.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Hormonal changes, such as those related to pregnancy, the menstrual cycle or use of birth control pills.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Certain genes.
Gingivitis has Risk Factor: Medical conditions, such as certain viral and fungal infections.

Gingivitis has Complication: Untreated gingivitis can lead to gum disease that spreads to underlying tissue and bone, called periodontitis. This is a much more serious condition that can lead to tooth loss.
Gingivitis has Preventio: Practice good oral care.
Gingivitis has Preventio: Go to the dentist regularly.
Gingivitis has Preventio: Take steps to lead a healthy lifestyle.
Glaucoma has Symptom: The symptoms of glaucoma depend on the type and stage of the condition.

Glaucoma has Cause: Glaucoma develops when the optic nerve becomes damaged. As this nerve gradually gets worse, blind spots develop in your vision. For reasons that eye doctors don't fully understand, this nerve damage is usually related to increased pressure in the eye.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: High internal eye pressure, also known as intraocular pressure.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Age over 55.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Black, Asian or Hispanic heritage.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Family history of glaucoma.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Certain medical conditions, such as diabetes, migraine, high blood pressure and sickle cell anemia.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Corneas that are thin in the center.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Extreme nearsightedness or farsightedness.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Eye injury or certain types of eye surgery.
Glaucoma has Risk Factor: Taking corticosteroid medicines, especially eye drops, for a long time.
Glaucoma has Preventio: Get regular eye exams.
Glaucoma has Preventio: Know your family's eye health history.
Glaucoma has Preventio: Wear eye protection.
Glaucoma has Preventio: Take prescribed eye drops regularly.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Headache, particularly one that hurts the most in the morning.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Nausea and vomiting.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Confusion or a decline in brain function, such as problems with thinking and understanding information.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Memory loss.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Personality changes or irritability.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Vision changes, such as blurred vision, double vision or loss of peripheral vision.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Speech difficulties.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Trouble with balance or coordination.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Muscle weakness in the face, arms or legs.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Reduced sensation of touch.
Glioblastoma has Symptom: Seizures, especially in someone who hasn't had seizures before.
Glioblastoma has Cause: The cause of most glioblastomas isn't known.

Glioma has Risk Factor: Getting older.
Glioma has Risk Factor: Being exposed to radiation.
Glioma has Risk Factor: Having a family history of glioma.

Goiter has Cause: Two hormones produced by the thyroid are thyroxine (T-4) and triiodothyronine (T-3). When the thyroid releases T-4 and T-3 into the bloodstream, they play a role in many functions in the body, including the regulation of:
Goiter has Risk Factor: Anyone can develop a goiter. It may be present at birth or occur at any time throughout life. Some common risk factors for goiters include:
Goiter has Complication: A goiter itself usually doesn't cause complications. The appearance may be troublesome or embarrassing for some people. A large goiter may obstruct the airway and voice box.

Gonorrhea has Symptom: In many people, gonorrhea infection causes no symptoms. If there are symptoms, they often affect the genital tract, but also may occur in other places.

Gonorrhea has Cause: Gonorrhea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The gonorrhea bacteria are most often passed from one person to another during sexual contact, including oral, anal or vaginal intercourse.
Gonorrhea has Risk Factor: Having a new sex partner.
Gonorrhea has Risk Factor: Having a sex partner who has other partners.
Gonorrhea has Risk Factor: Having more than one sex partner.
Gonorrhea has Risk Factor: Having had gonorrhea or another sexually transmitted infection.
Gonorrhea has Complication: Infertility in women.
Gonorrhea has Complication: Infertility in men.
Gonorrhea has Complication: Infection that spreads to the joints and other areas of the body.
Gonorrhea has Complication: Increased risk of HIV/AIDS.

Gonorrhea has Preventio: Use a condom if you have sex.

Gonorrhea has Preventio: Consider regular gonorrhea screening.
Gout has Symptom: Intense joint pain.
Gout has Symptom: Lingering discomfort.
Gout has Symptom: Inflammation and redness.
Gout has Symptom: Limited range of motion.

Gout has Cause: Gout occurs when urate crystals accumulate in your joint, causing the inflammation and intense pain of a gout attack. Urate crystals can form when you have high levels of uric acid in your blood. Your body produces uric acid when it breaks down purines — substances that are found naturally in your body.
Gout has Risk Factor: Diet.
Gout has Risk Factor: Weight.
Gout has Risk Factor: Medical conditions.
Gout has Risk Factor: Certain medications.
Gout has Risk Factor: Family history of gout.

Gout has Risk Factor: Gout occurs more often in men, primarily because women tend to have lower uric acid levels. After menopause, however, women's uric acid levels approach those of men. Men are also more likely to develop gout earlier — usually between the ages of 30 and 50 — whereas women generally develop signs and symptoms after menopause.
Gout has Risk Factor: Recent surgery or trauma.
Gout has Complication: Recurrent gout.
Gout has Complication: Advanced gout.
Gout has Complication: Kidney stones.
Granuloma annulare has Symptom: Localized.
Granuloma annulare has Symptom: Generalized.
Granuloma annulare has Symptom: Under the skin.
Granuloma annulare has Cause: Animal or insect bites
Granuloma annulare has Cause: Infections, such as hepatitis
Granuloma annulare has Cause: Tuberculin skin tests
Granuloma annulare has Cause: Vaccinations
Granuloma annulare has Cause: Sun exposure
Granuloma annulare has Cause: Minor skin injuries
Granuloma annulare has Cause: Medicines

Granuloma annulare has Risk Factor: Granuloma annulare can be related to diabetes or thyroid disease, most often when you have many bumps all over the body. It may, rarely, be related to cancer, especially in older people whose granuloma annulare is severe, doesn't respond to treatment or returns after cancer treatment.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Symptom: Fever.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Symptom: Tiredness and not feeling well, also called malaise.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Symptom: Weight loss without a clear reason for it.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Symptom: Muscle aches and pain.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Symptom: Joint stiffness.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Cause: The exact cause of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) isn't clear. The immune system may play a role. Some white blood cells may not function as they should, and they may be involved in the disease. The immune system makes proteins called antibodies that protect the body from germs such as viruses and bacteria. GPA has been linked with the presence of certain antibodies that attack healthy cells by mistake.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Risk Factor: Age is a risk factor for granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Most often, the disease affects people between the ages of 40 and 65. But it can happen at any age.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: Hearing loss.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: A loss of height in the bridge of the nose caused by weakened cartilage.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: Skin sores or scarring.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: Kidney damage or kidney failure.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: Bleeding and scarring of the lungs.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: A blood clot that forms in one or more deep veins, usually in the leg.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: Heart conditions such as swelling of the sac that surrounds the heart.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis has Complication: Rarely, stroke or vision loss.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Feeling nervous and irritable.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Having a slight tremor of the hands or fingers.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Being sensitive to heat with an increase in sweating or warm, moist skin.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Losing weight, despite wanting to eat more.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Having an enlarged thyroid gland, also called goiter.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Having changes in menstrual cycles.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Not being able to get or keep an erection, called erectile dysfunction, or having less desire for sex.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Having bowel movements often.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Having bulging eyes — a condition called thyroid eye disease or Graves' ophthalmopathy.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Being tired.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Having thick, discolored skin mostly on the shins or tops of the feet, called Graves' dermopathy.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Having fast or irregular heartbeat, called palpitations.
Graves' disease has Symptom: Not sleeping well.
Graves' disease has Cause: Graves' disease is caused by the body's disease-fighting immune system not working correctly. Experts don't know why this happens.
Graves' disease has Risk Factor: Family history.
Graves' disease has Risk Factor: Women are much more likely to get Graves' disease than are men.
Graves' disease has Risk Factor: Graves' disease mostly happens between the ages of 30 and 60.
Graves' disease has Risk Factor: Another autoimmune condition.
Graves' disease has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Graves' disease has Complication: Pregnancy health concerns.
Graves' disease has Complication: Heart conditions.
Graves' disease has Complication: Thyroid storm.
Graves' disease has Complication: Brittle bones.

Group B strep disease has Symptom: Most babies born to women carrying group B strep are healthy. But the few who are infected by group B strep during labor can become very ill. Some infections with this type of bacteria can be life-threatening.

Group B strep disease has Cause: Many healthy people carry group B strep bacteria in their bodies. You might carry the bacteria in your body for a short time. It can come and go. Or you might always have it. Group B strep bacteria are not spread through sex, food or water. It isn't clear how the bacteria are spread to anyone other than newborns.
Group B strep disease has Risk Factor: An infant born prematurely, meaning earlier than 37 weeks, has a higher risk of getting group B strep disease.
Group B strep disease has Complication: Group B strep infection can lead to life-threatening disease in infants, including:

Group B strep disease has Preventio: If you're pregnant, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends a group B strep screening test during weeks 36 to 37 of pregnancy. Talk to your health care professional about when to get screened if you live outside of the U.S.

Growing pains has Symptom: Growing pains usually cause an aching or throbbing feeling in the legs. This pain often occurs in the front of the thighs, the calves or behind the knees. Usually both legs hurt. Some children may also experience abdominal pain or headaches during episodes of growing pains. The pain doesn't occur every day. It comes and goes.
Growing pains has Cause: The cause of growing pains is unknown. But there's no evidence that a child's growth is painful.

Growing pains has Risk Factor: Growing pains are common in preschool and school-age children. They're slightly more common in girls than in boys. Running, climbing or jumping during the day might increase the risk of leg pain at night.
Growth plate fractures has Symptom: Pain and tenderness, particularly in response to pressure on the growth plate
Growth plate fractures has Symptom: Inability to move the affected area or to put weight or pressure on the limb
Growth plate fractures has Symptom: Warmth and swelling at the end of a bone, near a joint
Growth plate fractures has Cause: A car accident
Growth plate fractures has Cause: Competitive sports, such as football, basketball, running, dancing or gymnastics
Growth plate fractures has Cause: Recreational activities, such as biking, sledding, skiing or skateboarding

Growth plate fractures has Risk Factor: Growth plate fractures occur twice as often in boys as in girls, because girls finish growing earlier than do boys. By the age of 12, most girls' growth plates have already matured and been replaced with solid bone.
Growth plate fractures has Complication: Severity of the injury.
Growth plate fractures has Complication: Age of the child.
Growth plate fractures has Complication: Location of the injury.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: A pins and needles feeling in the fingers, toes, ankles or wrists.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Weakness in the legs that spreads to the upper body.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Unsteady walk or not being able to walk or climb stairs.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Trouble with facial movements, including speaking, chewing or swallowing.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Double vision or inability to move the eyes.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Severe pain that may feel achy, shooting or cramplike and may be worse at night.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Trouble with bladder control or bowel function.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Rapid heart rate.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Low or high blood pressure.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Symptom: Trouble breathing.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Most commonly, an infection with campylobacter, a type of bacteria often found in undercooked poultry.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Influenza virus.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Cytomegalovirus.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Epstein-Barr virus.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Zika virus.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Hepatitis A, B, C and E.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: HIV, the virus that causesAIDS.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Mycoplasma pneumonia.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Surgery.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Trauma.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Hodgkin lymphoma.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: Rarely, influenza vaccinations or childhood vaccinations.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Cause: COVID-19virus.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Risk Factor: Guillain-Barre syndrome can affect all age groups, but the risk increases as you age. It's also slightly more common in males than females.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Trouble breathing.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Residual numbness or other sensations.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Heart and blood pressure problems.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Pain.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Trouble with bowel and bladder function.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Blood clots.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Pressure sores.
Guillain-Barre syndrome has Complication: Relapse.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Fever, but not always.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Aching muscles.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Chills and sweats.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Cough.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Sore throat.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Runny or stuffy nose.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Watery, red eyes.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Eye pain.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Body aches.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Headache.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Tiredness and weakness.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Diarrhea.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Symptom: Feeling sick to the stomach, vomiting, but this is more common in children than adults.

H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Cause: Influenza viruses such as H1N1 infect the cells that line your nose, throat and lungs. The virus spreads through the air in droplets released when someone with the virus coughs, sneezes, breathes or talks. The virus enters your body when you breathe in contaminated droplets. It also can enter your body if you touch a contaminated surface and then touch your eyes, nose or mouth.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: Influenza tends to have worse outcomes in children under age 2, and adults older than age 65.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: Living or working conditions.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: Weakened immune system.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: Chronic illnesses.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: Race.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: People on long-term aspirin therapy and who are younger than 19 years of age are at risk of Reye syndrome if infected with influenza.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: Pregnancy.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Risk Factor: Obesity.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Complication: Worsening of chronic conditions, such as heart disease and asthma.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Complication: Pneumonia.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Complication: Neurological symptoms, ranging from confusion to seizures.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Complication: Respiratory failure.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Complication: Bronchitis.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Complication: Muscle tenderness.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Complication: Bacterial infections.
