H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Preventio: Adults age 50 and older.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Preventio: Pregnant people.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Preventio: Children between 2 and 17 years old who are taking aspirin or a salicylate-containing medication.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Preventio: People with weakened immune systems.

H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Preventio: Close contacts or caregivers of people with highly weakened immune systems. Examples are people receiving chemotherapy, or recent bone marrow or solid organ transplantation.
H1N1 flu (swine flu) has Preventio: Children 2 to 4 years old who have had asthma or wheezing in the past 12 months.
Hair loss has Symptom: Gradual thinning on top of head.
Hair loss has Symptom: Circular or patchy bald spots.
Hair loss has Symptom: Sudden loosening of hair.
Hair loss has Symptom: Full-body hair loss.
Hair loss has Symptom: Patches of scaling that spread over the scalp.
Hair loss has Cause: Family history (heredity).
Hair loss has Cause: Hormonal changes and medical conditions.
Hair loss has Cause: Medications and supplements.
Hair loss has Cause: Radiation therapy to the head.
Hair loss has Cause: A very stressful event.
Hair loss has Cause: Hairstyles and treatments.
Hair loss has Risk Factor: A family history of balding on your mother's or father's side
Hair loss has Risk Factor: Age
Hair loss has Risk Factor: Significant weight loss
Hair loss has Risk Factor: Certain medical conditions, such as diabetes and lupus
Hair loss has Risk Factor: Stress
Hair loss has Risk Factor: Poor nutrition

Hair loss has Preventio: Be gentle with your hair. Use a detangler and avoid tugging when brushing and combing, especially when your hair is wet. A wide-toothed comb might help prevent pulling out hair. Avoid harsh treatments such as hot rollers, curling irons, hot-oil treatments and permanents. Limit the tension on hair from styles that use rubber bands, barrettes and braids.
Hair loss has Preventio: Ask your doctor about medications and supplements you take that might cause hair loss.
Hair loss has Preventio: Protect your hair from sunlight and other sources of ultraviolet light.
Hair loss has Preventio: Stop smoking. Some studies show an association between smoking and baldness in men.
Hair loss has Preventio: If you're being treated with chemotherapy, ask your doctor about a cooling cap. This cap can reduce your risk of losing hair during chemotherapy.
Hairy cell leukemia has Symptom: A feeling of fullness in your belly that may make it uncomfortable to eat more than a little at a time
Hairy cell leukemia has Symptom: Fatigue
Hairy cell leukemia has Symptom: Easy bruising
Hairy cell leukemia has Symptom: Recurring infections
Hairy cell leukemia has Symptom: Weakness
Hairy cell leukemia has Symptom: Losing weight without trying
Hairy cell leukemia has Cause: It's not clear what causes hairy cell leukemia.
Hairy cell leukemia has Risk Factor: Older adults.
Hairy cell leukemia has Risk Factor: Males.
Hairy cell leukemia has Complication: Hairy cell leukemia often gets worse very slowly. Sometimes it stays stable for many years. For this reason, few complications of the disease occur.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Symptom: Pain from wearing shoes.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Symptom: Trouble moving the affected toe.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Symptom: Toe stiffness.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Symptom: A change in skin color and swelling.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Symptom: Growth of corns and calluses from the affected toe rubbing against shoes or against the ground.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Cause: Certain shoes.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Cause: Injury.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Cause: Toe muscles that are out of balance.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Risk Factor: Women are more likely to develop hammertoe or mallet toe than are men.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Risk Factor: Certain diseases.

Hammertoe and mallet toe has Complication: For a while, you still might be able to straighten the toe. But over time, the tendons and joints of a hammertoe or mallet toe might tighten. This can cause the toe to stay bent.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Preventio: Enough toe room.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Preventio: Low heels.
Hammertoe and mallet toe has Preventio: Shoes that adjust.
Hamstring injury has Symptom: A hamstring injury typically causes a sudden, sharp pain in the back of the thigh. There might also be a "popping" or tearing sensation.

Hamstring injury has Cause: The hamstring muscles are a group of three muscles that run along the back of the thigh from the hip to just below the knee. These muscles make it possible to extend the leg back and to bend the knee. Stretching or overloading any one of these muscles beyond its limit can cause injury.
Hamstring injury has Risk Factor: Sports.
Hamstring injury has Risk Factor: Earlier hamstring injury.
Hamstring injury has Risk Factor: Tired muscles, weak muscles and muscles that don't stretch well.
Hamstring injury has Risk Factor: Muscle imbalance.
Hamstring injury has Risk Factor: Risk of injury increases with age.
Hamstring injury has Complication: Returning to tiring activities before hamstring muscles are completely healed might cause the injury to happen again.

Hamstring injury has Preventio: Being in good physical condition and doing regular stretching and strengthening exercises can help lessen the risk of a hamstring injury. Try to be in shape to play your sport. Don't play your sport to get in shape.
Hand-foot-and-mouth disease has Symptom: Symptoms usually appear 3 to 6 days after infection. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease may cause all of the following symptoms or just some of them.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease has Cause: The most common cause of hand-foot-and-mouth disease is infection from coxsackievirus A16. This coxsackievirus belongs to a group of viruses called nonpolio enteroviruses. Other types of enteroviruses also may cause hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease has Risk Factor: Age is the main risk factor for hand-foot-and-mouth disease. The disease mostly affects children younger than ages 5 to 7 years. Children in child care settings are especially at risk because the viruses that cause the illness spread by person-to-person contact.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease has Complication: The most common complication of hand-foot-and-mouth disease is dehydration. That's when the body loses more fluid than it takes in. Hand-foot-and-mouth disease can cause sores in the mouth and throat, making it painful to swallow.
Hand-foot-and-mouth disease has Preventio: You can lower your child's risk of hand-foot-and-mouth disease in many ways:
Hangovers has Symptom: Extreme tiredness and weakness.
Hangovers has Symptom: Thirst and dry mouth.
Hangovers has Symptom: Headache and muscle aches.
Hangovers has Symptom: Nausea, vomiting or belly pain.
Hangovers has Symptom: Poor sleep or not getting enough sleep.
Hangovers has Symptom: Low tolerance for light and sound.
Hangovers has Symptom: Dizziness or a sense of the room spinning.
Hangovers has Symptom: Shakiness and sweating.
Hangovers has Symptom: Problems concentrating or thinking clearly.
Hangovers has Symptom: Changes in mood, such as depression, anxiety and irritability.
Hangovers has Symptom: Fast heartbeat.
Hangovers has Cause: Alcohol causes the body to make more urine.
Hangovers has Cause: Alcohol triggers an inflammatory response from the immune system.
Hangovers has Cause: Alcohol irritates the lining of the stomach.
Hangovers has Cause: Alcohol can cause blood sugar levels to fall.
Hangovers has Cause: Alcohol prevents restful sleep.
Hangovers has Risk Factor: Drinking on an empty stomach.
Hangovers has Risk Factor: Using other drugs, such as nicotine, along with alcohol.
Hangovers has Risk Factor: Not sleeping well or long enough after drinking.
Hangovers has Risk Factor: Having a family history of alcohol use disorder.
Hangovers has Risk Factor: Darker colored drinks often contain a high level of congeners and may be more likely to produce a hangover.
Hangovers has Complication: Clear thinking and memory.
Hangovers has Complication: Attention and focus.
Hangovers has Complication: Tasks that require steady hands and body coordination.
Hangovers has Preventio: Up to one drink a day for women.
Hangovers has Preventio: Up to two drinks a day for men.

Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome has Symptom: The time from infection with the hantavirus to the start of illness is usually about 2 to 3 weeks. Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome advances through two distinct stages. In the first stage, which can last for several days, the most common signs and symptoms are:
Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome has Cause: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is a human disease found only in North and South America. Each strain of the hantavirus has a preferred rodent carrier.

Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome has Risk Factor: In the United States, hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is most common in rural areas of the West. However, any exposure to rodent habitats can increase the risk of disease.

Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome has Complication: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome can quickly become life-threatening. Severe disease can result in failure of the heart to deliver oxygen to the body. Each strain of the virus differs in severity. The death rate due to the strain carried by deer mice ranges from 30% to 50%.
Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome has Preventio: Keeping rodents out of your home and workplace can help reduce your risk of hantavirus infection. Try these tips:

Hashimoto's disease has Symptom: Hashimoto's disease progresses slowly over the years. You may not notice signs or symptoms of the disease. Eventually, the decline in thyroid hormone production can result in any of the following:

Hashimoto's disease has Cause: Hashimoto's disease is an autoimmune disorder. The immune system creates antibodies that attack thyroid cells as if they were bacteria, viruses or some other foreign body. The immune system wrongly enlists disease-fighting agents that damage cells and lead to cell death.
Hashimoto's disease has Risk Factor: The following factors are associated with an increased risk of Hashimoto's disease:

Hashimoto's disease has Complication: Thyroid hormones are essential for the healthy function of many body systems. Therefore, when Hashimoto's disease and hypothyroidism are left untreated, many complications can occur. These include:
Hay fever has Symptom: Runny nose and nasal stuffiness, called congestion.
Hay fever has Symptom: Watery, itchy, red eyes.
Hay fever has Symptom: Sneezing.
Hay fever has Symptom: Cough.
Hay fever has Symptom: Itchy nose, roof of mouth or throat.
Hay fever has Symptom: Mucus that runs down the back of the throat, called postnasal drip.
Hay fever has Symptom: Swollen, bruised-appearing skin under the eyes, known as allergic shiners.
Hay fever has Symptom: Extreme tiredness and fatigue, often due to poor sleep.

Hay fever has Cause: When someone has hay fever, the immune system identifies a harmless airborne substance as being harmful. This substance is called an allergen. The body produces immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies to protect against allergens. When the body comes in contact with an allergen, these antibodies signal the immune system to release chemicals such as histamine into the bloodstream. This causes a reaction that leads to the symptoms of hay fever.
Hay fever has Risk Factor: Having other allergies or asthma.
Hay fever has Risk Factor: Having a condition called atopic dermatitis or eczema, which makes skin irritated and itchy.
Hay fever has Risk Factor: Having a blood relative, such as a parent or sibling, with allergies or asthma.
Hay fever has Risk Factor: Living or working in an environment that constantly exposes someone to allergens — such as animal dander or dust mites.
Hay fever has Risk Factor: Being exposed to smoke and strong odors that irritate the lining of the nose.
Hay fever has Risk Factor: Having a mother who smoked during the first year of life.
Hay fever has Complication: Reduced quality of life.
Hay fever has Complication: Poor sleep.
Hay fever has Complication: Worsening asthma.
Hay fever has Complication: Sinusitis.
Hay fever has Complication: Ear infection.

Head lice has Risk Factor: Head lice infect hair of any length and type. Head lice spread mainly by direct head-to-head contact. So the risk of spreading head lice is greatest among children who play or go to school together. In the United States, head lice most often happen in children in preschool through grade school.
Head lice has Complication: When people scratch the itch that head lice cause, the skin may break. The broken skin may get infected.

Head lice has Preventio: You can stop the spread of lice by avoiding hair and head contact between people. The chance of spreading head lice from items that come in contact with the hair or head is small. But you can lower your risk of getting head lice by taking some precautions.

Heat exhaustion has Cause: The body's heat combined with environmental heat results in what's called your core temperature. This is your body's inner temperature. Your body needs to regulate heat gain in hot weather or heat loss in cold weather to keep a core temperature that's typical for you. The average core temperature is about 98.6 F (37 C).

Heat exhaustion has Risk Factor: Infants and children younger than 4 and adults older than 65 are at higher risk of heat exhaustion. The body's ability to regulate its temperature isn't fully developed in children. In older adults, illness, medicines or other factors can affect the body's ability to control temperature.

Heat exhaustion has Complication: If heat exhaustion isn't treated, it can lead to heatstroke. Heatstroke is a life-threatening condition. It happens when your core body temperature reaches 104 F (40 C) or higher. Heatstroke needs immediate medical attention to prevent permanent damage to your brain and other vital organs that can result in death.

Heat rash has Symptom: Adults usually develop heat rash in skin folds and where clothing rubs against the skin. In infants, the rash is mainly found on the neck, shoulders and chest. It can also show up in the armpits, elbow creases and groin.

Heat rash has Cause: Heat rash develops when a duct that leads from a sweat gland to the surface of the skin is blocked or inflamed. This then blocks the opening of the sweat duct on the surface of the skin (sweat pore). Instead of evaporating, sweat is trapped beneath the skin, causing irritation and bumps on the skin.
Heat rash has Risk Factor: Factors that increase the risk of heat rash include:

Heat rash has Complication: Heat rash usually heals without scarring. People with brown or Black skin are at risk of spots of skin that get lighter or darker in response to inflammatory skin conditions (postinflammatory hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation). These changes usually go away within weeks or months.

Hemangioma has Symptom: A hemangioma may be visible at birth, but it appears more often during the first month of life. It starts as a flat red mark on the body, most often on the face, scalp, chest or back. A child generally only has one mark, but some children may have more than one mark.
Hemangioma has Cause: A hemangioma is made up of extra blood vessels that group together into a dense clump. What causes the vessels to clump isn't known.
Hemangioma has Risk Factor: Hemangiomas occur more often in babies who are female, white or born prematurely. Babies with a low birth weight also are more likely to have a hemangioma.

Hemangioma has Complication: At times, a hemangioma can break down and develop a sore. This can lead to pain, bleeding, scarring or infection. Depending on the hemangioma's location, it may cause problems with your child's vision, breathing, hearing or ability to go to the bathroom. But this is rare.

Hemophilia has Cause: When a person bleeds, the body typically pools blood cells together to form a clot to stop the bleeding. Clotting factors are proteins in the blood that work with cells known as platelets to form clots. Hemophilia occurs when a clotting factor is missing or levels of the clotting factor are low.

Hepatitis A has Symptom: Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially on the upper right side beneath your lower ribs, which is over your liver
Hepatitis A has Symptom: Clay- or gray-colored stool
Hepatitis A has Symptom: Loss of appetite
Hepatitis A has Symptom: Low-grade fever
Hepatitis A has Symptom: Dark urine
Hepatitis A has Symptom: Joint pain
Hepatitis A has Symptom: Yellowing of the skin and the whites of your eyes (jaundice)
Hepatitis A has Symptom: Intense itching
Hepatitis A has Cause: Eating food handled by someone with the virus who doesn't thoroughly wash hands after using the toilet
Hepatitis A has Cause: Drinking contaminated water
Hepatitis A has Cause: Eating food washed in contaminated water
Hepatitis A has Cause: Eating raw shellfish from water polluted with sewage
Hepatitis A has Cause: Being in close contact with a person who has the virus — even if that person has no symptoms
Hepatitis A has Cause: Having sexual contact with someone who has the virus
Hepatitis A has Risk Factor: Travel or work in areas of the world where hepatitis A is common
Hepatitis A has Risk Factor: Live with another person who has hepatitis A
Hepatitis A has Risk Factor: Are a man who has sexual contact with other men
Hepatitis A has Risk Factor: Have any type of sexual contact with someone who has hepatitis A
Hepatitis A has Risk Factor: AreHIVpositive
Hepatitis A has Risk Factor: Are homeless
Hepatitis A has Risk Factor: Use any type of recreational drugs, not just those that are injected
Hepatitis A has Complication: Unlike other types of viral hepatitis, hepatitis A does not cause long-term liver damage, and it doesn't become an ongoing (chronic) infection.
Hepatitis A has Preventio: All children at age 1 year, or older children who didn't receive the childhood vaccine
Hepatitis A has Preventio: Anyone age 1 year or older who is homeless
Hepatitis A has Preventio: Infants ages 6 to 11 months traveling to parts of the world where hepatitis A is common
Hepatitis A has Preventio: Family and caregivers of adoptees from countries where hepatitis A is common
Hepatitis A has Preventio: People in direct contact with others who have hepatitis A
Hepatitis A has Preventio: Laboratory workers who may come into contact with hepatitis A
Hepatitis A has Preventio: Men who have sex with men
Hepatitis A has Preventio: People who work or travel in parts of the world where hepatitis A is common
Hepatitis A has Preventio: People who use any type of recreational drugs, not just injected ones
Hepatitis A has Preventio: People with chronic liver disease, including hepatitis B or hepatitis C
Hepatitis A has Preventio: Anyone wishing to obtain protection (immunity)
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Pain in the stomach area, also called the abdomen.
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Dark urine.
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Fever.
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Joint pain.
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Loss of appetite.
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Upset stomach and vomiting.
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Weakness and extreme tiredness.
Hepatitis B has Symptom: Jaundice, which is a yellowing of the whites of the eyes and the skin. Depending on skin color, this change may be harder or easier to see.
Hepatitis B has Cause: Sexual contact.
Hepatitis B has Cause: Sharing of needles.
Hepatitis B has Cause: Accidental needlesticks.
Hepatitis B has Cause: Pregnant person to newborn.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Have sex without a condom with multiple sex partners or with someone who's infected withHBV.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Share needles during the use of drugs injected into a vein.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Are born male and have sex with men.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Live with someone who has a chronicHBVinfection.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Are an infant who was born to an infected pregnant person.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Have a job that exposes you to human blood.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Have hepatitis C orHIV.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Receive dialysis treatment.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Are or have been in prison.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Need to take medicine that can weaken the immune system, such as chemotherapy.
Hepatitis B has Risk Factor: Travel to regions with high infection rates ofHBV, such as Asia, the Pacific Islands, Africa and Eastern Europe.
Hepatitis B has Complication: Scarring of the liver, also called cirrhosis.
Hepatitis B has Complication: Liver cancer.
Hepatitis B has Complication: Liver failure.
Hepatitis B has Complication: Sudden increase in the level of hepatitis B virus.
Hepatitis B has Complication: Other conditions.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: Newborns.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: Children and adolescents not vaccinated at birth.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: Those who work or live in centers for people who have developmental disabilities.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: People who live with someone who has hepatitis B.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: Healthcare workers, emergency workers and other people who come into contact with blood.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: Anyone who has a sexually transmitted infection, includingHIV.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: People born male who have sex with men.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: People who have multiple sexual partners.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: Sexual partners of someone who has hepatitis B.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: People who inject street drugs or share needles and syringes.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: People with chronic liver disease.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: People with end-stage kidney disease.
Hepatitis B has Preventio: Travelers planning to go to an area of the world with a highHBVinfection rate.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Bleeding easily.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Bruising easily.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Fatigue.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Not wanting to eat.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Yellowing of the skin, called jaundice. This might show up more in white people. Also, yellowing of the whites of the eyes in white, Black and brown people.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Dark-colored urine.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Itchy skin.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Fluid buildup in the stomach area, called ascites.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Swelling in the legs.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Weight loss.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech, called hepatic encephalopathy.
Hepatitis C has Symptom: Spiderlike blood vessels on the skin, called spider angiomas.
Hepatitis C has Cause: Hepatitis C infection is caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV). The infection spreads when blood that has the virus enters the bloodstream of a person who isn't affected.

Hepatitis C has Risk Factor: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that all adults ages 18 to 79 years be screened for hepatitis C. Screening is very important for people at high risk of exposure. This includes:
Hepatitis C has Complication: Scarring of the liver, called cirrhosis.
Hepatitis C has Complication: Liver cancer.
Hepatitis C has Complication: Liver failure.
Hepatitis C has Preventio: Stop using illegal drugs.
Hepatitis C has Preventio: Be careful about body piercing and tattooing.
Hepatitis C has Preventio: Practice safer sex.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Symptom: Results that are higher than expected on a blood test that looks for alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), which might be done as part of liver cancer screening in someone with a high risk of the disease.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Symptom: Growths, called nodules, on the liver, which might be detected on an ultrasound imaging test that's done as part of liver cancer screening.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Cause: The main causes of hepatocellular carcinoma are liver scarring, called cirrhosis, and infection with hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus. But not everyone with this type of cancer has a serious liver condition. It's not clear what causes hepatocellular carcinoma in people who don't have liver disease.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Hepatocellular carcinoma is more common in older adults.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Infection with hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Cirrhosis.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Certain inherited liver diseases.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Excess fat in the liver.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Diabetes.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Obesity.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Exposure to aflatoxins.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Excessive alcohol consumption.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Risk Factor: Smoking cigarettes.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Complication: Lungs.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Complication: Lymph nodes in the abdomen.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Complication: Bones.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Complication: Adrenal glands.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Complication: Brain.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has Preventio: Cirrhosis is scarring of the liver, and it increases the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma. You can reduce your risk of cirrhosis if you:
Hepatopulmonary syndrome has Symptom: Shortness of breath that's worse when sitting or standing and gets better when lying down.
Hepatopulmonary syndrome has Symptom: Clubbing of the fingers, in which the fingertips spread out and become rounder than usual.
Hepatopulmonary syndrome has Symptom: Broken blood vessels under the skin, called spider angioma.
Hepatopulmonary syndrome has Symptom: Bluish tinge of the lips and skin in white people. In Black and brown people, the lips or tongue might look light gray. This change in color is called cyanosis.

Hepatopulmonary syndrome has Cause: Hepatopulmonary syndrome is caused when blood vessels in and around the lungs widen, also called dilate. This affects the amount of oxygen that moves from the lungs into the bloodstream.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Nosebleeds. These can happen every day. They often start in childhood.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Lacy red vessels or tiny red spots, mostly on the lips, face, fingertips, tongue and inside the mouth. These are called telangiectasias.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Iron deficiency anemia due to bleeding from the nose or intestinal tract.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Shortness of breath.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Headaches.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Seizures.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Pus-filled swelling in the brain, called a brain abscess, and strokes.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Symptom: Infection in a bone, called osteomyelitis.

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Cause: HHT is a condition of gene changes, called genetic, that you get from your parents. It is an autosomal dominant disorder. That means if one of your parents has HHT, you have a 50% chance of getting it. If you have HHT, each of your children has a 50% chance of getting it from you.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia has Risk Factor: The major risk factor for hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is having a parent with the condition.
Herniated disk has Symptom: Arm or leg pain.
Herniated disk has Symptom: Numbness or tingling.
Herniated disk has Symptom: Weakness.

Herniated disk has Cause: Disk herniation is most often the result of a gradual, aging-related wear and tear called disk degeneration. As people age, the disks become less flexible and more prone to tearing or rupturing with even a minor strain or twist.
Herniated disk has Risk Factor: Weight.
Herniated disk has Risk Factor: Occupation.
Herniated disk has Risk Factor: Genetics.
Herniated disk has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Herniated disk has Risk Factor: Frequent driving.
Herniated disk has Risk Factor: Being sedentary.
Herniated disk has Complication: Worsening symptoms.
Herniated disk has Complication: Bladder or bowel dysfunction.
Herniated disk has Complication: Saddle anesthesia.
Herniated disk has Preventio: Exercise.
Herniated disk has Preventio: Maintain good posture.
Herniated disk has Preventio: Maintain a healthy weight.
Herniated disk has Preventio: Quit smoking.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Heartburn.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Backward flow of swallowed food or liquids into the mouth, called regurgitation.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Backflow of stomach acid into the esophagus, called acid reflux.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Trouble swallowing.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Chest or abdominal pain.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Feeling full soon after you eat.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Shortness of breath.
Hiatal hernia has Symptom: Vomiting of blood or passing of black stools, which could mean bleeding in the digestive tract.
Hiatal hernia has Cause: Age-related changes in your diaphragm.
Hiatal hernia has Cause: Injury to the area, for example, after trauma or certain types of surgery.
Hiatal hernia has Cause: Being born with a very large hiatus.
Hiatal hernia has Cause: Constant and intense pressure on the surrounding muscles. This can happen while coughing, vomiting, straining during a bowel movement, exercising or lifting heavy objects.
Hiatal hernia has Risk Factor: Age 50 or older.
Hiatal hernia has Risk Factor: Obese.
Hiccups has Symptom: Symptoms include uncontrolled spasms in your diaphragm and a "hic" sound. Sometimes you may feel a slight tightening sensation in your chest, stomach area or throat.
Hiccups has Cause: Drinking carbonated beverages.
Hiccups has Cause: Drinking too much alcohol.
Hiccups has Cause: Eating too much.
Hiccups has Cause: Being excited or under emotional stress.
Hiccups has Cause: Experiencing sudden temperature changes.
Hiccups has Cause: Swallowing air, such as when chewing gum or smoking.
Hiccups has Risk Factor: Mental or emotional issues.
Hiccups has Risk Factor: Surgery.
Hiccups has Complication: Ongoing hiccups may interfere with eating, drinking, sleeping and speaking. Hiccups also can worsen pain.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Symptom: Blackheads.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Symptom: Painful pea-sized lumps.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Symptom: Leaking bumps or sores.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Symptom: Tunnels.

Hidradenitis suppurativa has Cause: Hidradenitis suppurativa develops when hair follicles become blocked, but why this blockage occurs isn't known. Experts think it could be connected to hormones, genetic predisposition, cigarette smoking or excess weight.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Risk Factor: The risk of hidradenitis suppurativa is higher for people in their teens and 20s.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Risk Factor: Females are more likely to develop hidradenitis suppurativa than males.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Risk Factor: Race.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Risk Factor: Family history.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Risk Factor: Certain conditions.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Complication: Infection.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Complication: Scars and skin changes.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Complication: Restricted movement.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Complication: Skin cancer.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Complication: Swelling in the arms, legs or genitals.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Complication: Psychological effects and social isolation.
Hidradenitis suppurativa has Complication: Lifelong pain.

High blood pressure (hypertension) has Symptom: Most people with high blood pressure have no symptoms, even if blood pressure readings reach dangerously high levels. You can have high blood pressure for years without any symptoms.

High blood pressure (hypertension) has Cause: Blood pressure is determined by two things: the amount of blood the heart pumps and how hard it is for the blood to move through the arteries. The more blood the heart pumps and the narrower the arteries, the higher the blood pressure.
High blood pressure (hypertension) has Risk Factor: High blood pressure has many risk factors, including:

High blood pressure (hypertension) has Complication: The excessive pressure on the artery walls caused by high blood pressure can damage blood vessels and body organs. The higher the blood pressure and the longer it goes uncontrolled, the greater the damage.

High blood pressure in children has Symptom: High blood pressure usually doesn't cause symptoms. However, signs and symptoms that might indicate a high blood pressure emergency (hypertensive crisis) include:

High blood pressure in children has Cause: High blood pressure in younger children is often related to other health conditions, such as heart defects, kidney disease, genetic conditions or hormonal disorders. Older children — especially those who are overweight — are more likely to have primary hypertension. This type of high blood pressure occurs on its own, without an underlying condition.
High blood pressure in children has Risk Factor: Your child's risk factors for high blood pressure depend on health conditions, genetics and lifestyle factors.
High blood pressure in children has Complication: Children who have high blood pressure are likely to continue to have high blood pressure as adults unless they begin treatment.

High blood pressure in children has Preventio: High blood pressure can be prevented in children by making the same lifestyle changes that can help treat it — controlling your child's weight, providing a healthy diet low in salt (sodium) and encouraging your child to exercise.
High cholesterol has Symptom: High cholesterol has no symptoms. A blood test is the only way to find out if you have it.
High cholesterol has Cause: Familial hypercholesterolemia.
High cholesterol has Cause: Chronic kidney disease.
High cholesterol has Cause: Chronic liver disease.
High cholesterol has Cause: Diabetes.
High cholesterol has Cause: HIV/AIDS.
High cholesterol has Cause: Hypothyroidism.
High cholesterol has Cause: Lupus.
High cholesterol has Cause: Overweight and obesity.
High cholesterol has Cause: Sleep apnea.
High cholesterol has Risk Factor: Eating habits.
High cholesterol has Risk Factor: Obesity.
High cholesterol has Risk Factor: Lack of exercise.
High cholesterol has Risk Factor: Smoking.
High cholesterol has Risk Factor: Alcohol.
High cholesterol has Risk Factor: Even young children can have high cholesterol. But it's much more common in people over 40. As you age, your liver becomes less able to remove "bad" LDL cholesterol.
High cholesterol has Complication: Chest pain, also called angina.
High cholesterol has Complication: Heart attack.
High cholesterol has Complication: Stroke.
High cholesterol has Preventio: Eat a diet that focuses on lean protein, fruits, vegetables and whole grains. Limit sodium and added sugar.
High cholesterol has Preventio: Also limit the amount of saturated and trans fats you eat. Instead, eat foods with healthy fats such as fatty or oily fish, nuts, and olive or canola oil.
High cholesterol has Preventio: Lose extra weight and keep it off.
High cholesterol has Preventio: If you smoke, ask your care team to help you quit.
High cholesterol has Preventio: Exercise on most days of the week for at least 30 minutes.
High cholesterol has Preventio: Drink less alcohol, if at all. Limit alcohol to no more than up to one drink a day for women and up to two drinks a day for men.

Hip dysplasia has Symptom: Symptoms vary by age group. In infants, you might notice that one leg is longer than the other. Once a child begins walking, a limp may develop. During diaper changes, one hip may be less flexible than the other.
Hip dysplasia has Cause: First pregnancy.
Hip dysplasia has Cause: Large baby.
Hip dysplasia has Cause: Breech presentation.

Hip dysplasia has Risk Factor: Hip dysplasia tends to run in families and is more common in girls. The risk of hip dysplasia is also higher in babies born in the breech position and in babies who are swaddled tightly with the hips and knees straight.

Hip dysplasia has Complication: Later in life, hip dysplasia can damage the soft cartilage, called the labrum, that rims the socket portion of the hip joint. This is called a hip labral tear. Hip dysplasia can also make the joint more likely to develop osteoarthritis. This happens because of higher contact pressures over a smaller surface of the socket. Over time, this wears away the smooth cartilage on the bones that helps them glide against each other as the joint moves.
Hip fracture has Symptom: Symptoms of a hip fracture include:

Hip fracture has Cause: A serious impact, such as a car crash, can cause hip fractures in people of all ages. In older adults, a hip fracture is most often a result of a fall from a standing height. In people with very weak bones, a hip fracture can occur simply by standing on the leg and twisting.
Hip fracture has Risk Factor: Many things can increase the risk of hip fractures.

Hip fracture has Complication: A hip fracture can reduce independence and sometimes shorten life. About half the people who have a hip fracture aren't able to regain the ability to live independently.

Hip fracture has Preventio: Healthy lifestyle choices in early adulthood build a higher peak bone mass and reduce the risk of osteoporosis in later years. The same measures adopted at any age might lower the risk of falls and improve overall health.
Hip labral tear has Symptom: Many hip labral tears cause no signs or symptoms. Some people, however, have one or more of the following:
Hip labral tear has Cause: The cause of a hip labral tear might be:
Hip labral tear has Risk Factor: Anyone can get a hip labral tear, but certain conditions and activities increase the risk.
Hip labral tear has Complication: A hip labral tear can make it more likely that you'll develop osteoarthritis in that joint.
Hip labral tear has Preventio: If the sports you play put a lot of strain on your hips, condition the surrounding muscles with strength and flexibility exercises.
Hirschsprung's disease has Symptom: Symptoms of Hirschsprung disease depend on how bad the condition is. Usually symptoms start shortly after birth, but sometimes don't show up until later in life.
Hirschsprung's disease has Cause: The cause of Hirschsprung disease is unclear. It sometimes runs in families. In some cases, it might be associated with an altered gene.
Hirschsprung's disease has Risk Factor: Factors that may increase the risk of Hirschsprung disease include:

Hirschsprung's disease has Complication: Children who have Hirschsprung disease could develop enterocolitis, a serious intestinal infection. Enterocolitis can be life-threatening and should be treated right away.
Hirsutism has Symptom: Hirsutism is stiff or dark hair that appears on the body where women don't commonly have hair. That can include areas such as the:
Hirsutism has Cause: Hirsutism can be caused by:
Hirsutism has Risk Factor: Some factors can raise the risk of hirsutism, including:

Hirsutism has Complication: Hirsutism can be distressing. You might feel self-conscious about having unwanted hair. Some people become depressed. Hirsutism itself doesn't cause physical health problems. But if a medical condition is causing a hormonal imbalance, that may lead to other health concerns.
Hirsutism has Preventio: Hirsutism usually isn't preventable. But losing weight if you're overweight might help reduce hirsutism. That's especially true if you have polycystic ovary syndrome.

Histoplasmosis has Symptom: The mildest forms of histoplasmosis cause no symptoms. But serious infections can be life-threatening. When symptoms happen, they often appear 3 to 17 days after someone breathes in the spores that cause the infection.
Histoplasmosis has Cause: Histoplasmosis is caused by cells, also called spores, from the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. The spores can float into the air when dirt or other material is disturbed.
Histoplasmosis has Risk Factor: The chances of getting histoplasmosis symptoms rise with the number of spores you breathe in. People more likely to be exposed to the spores include:

Histoplasmosis has Complication: Histoplasmosis can cause many serious health conditions, even in otherwise healthy people. Infants, older adults and people with weakened immune systems can get complications that often are life-threatening.

Histoplasmosis has Preventio: It can be hard not to breathe in the spores that cause histoplasmosis. That's especially true in areas where the fungus is widespread. But you can take the following steps to help lower the risk of infection:
HIV/AIDS has Symptom: The symptoms ofHIVandAIDSvary depending on the person and the phase of infection.

HIV/AIDS has Cause: HIVis caused by a virus. It can spread through sexual contact, shooting of illicit drugs or use of shared needles, and contact with infected blood. It also can spread from parent to child during pregnancy, childbirth or breastfeeding.
HIV/AIDS has Risk Factor: Use a new latex or polyurethane condom every time you have sex. Anal sex is riskier than is vaginal sex. Your risk ofHIVincreases if you have more than one sexual partner.
HIV/AIDS has Risk Factor: Have anSTI.
HIV/AIDS has Risk Factor: Inject illicit drugs.
HIV/AIDS has Complication: HIVinfection weakens your immune system. The infection makes you much more likely to get many infections and certain types of cancers.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: Consider preexposure prophylaxis, also called PrEP.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: Use treatment as prevention, also called TasP.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: Use post-exposure prophylaxis, also called PEP, if you've been exposed toHIV.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: Use a new condom every time you have anal or vaginal sex.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: Tell your sexual partners you haveHIV.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: Use clean needles.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: If you're pregnant, get medical care right away.
HIV/AIDS has Preventio: Consider male circumcision.
Hives and angioedema has Symptom: The welts associated with hives can be:
Hives and angioedema has Cause: Foods.
Hives and angioedema has Cause: Medications.
Hives and angioedema has Cause: Airborne allergens.
Hives and angioedema has Cause: Insect bites and infections.
Hives and angioedema has Risk Factor: Have had hives or angioedema before
Hives and angioedema has Risk Factor: Have had other allergic reactions
Hives and angioedema has Risk Factor: Have a family history of hives, angioedema or hereditary angioedema
Hives and angioedema has Complication: Severe angioedema can be life-threatening if swelling of the tongue or in the throat blocks the airway.
Hives and angioedema has Preventio: Avoid known triggers.
Hives and angioedema has Preventio: Bathe and change your clothes.
Hoarding disorder has Symptom: Getting and keeping too many items that you may not have a need for right now and don't have space for.
Hoarding disorder has Symptom: Ongoing difficulty throwing out or parting with your things, regardless of their actual value.
Hoarding disorder has Symptom: Feeling a need to save these items and being upset by the thought of getting rid of them.
Hoarding disorder has Symptom: Building up clutter to the point where you can't use rooms.
Hoarding disorder has Symptom: Trying to be perfect and avoiding or delaying decisions.
Hoarding disorder has Symptom: Problems with planning and organizing.
Hoarding disorder has Cause: It's not clear what causes hoarding disorder. Genetics, brain function and stressful life events are being studied as possible causes.
Hoarding disorder has Risk Factor: Personality.
Hoarding disorder has Risk Factor: Family history.
Hoarding disorder has Risk Factor: Stressful life events.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: Increased risk of falls.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: Injury or being trapped by shifting or falling items.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: Family conflicts.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: Loneliness and social isolation.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: Conditions that aren't clean and can be a health risk.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: A fire hazard.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: Poor work performance.
Hoarding disorder has Complication: Legal issues, such as eviction.

Hoarding disorder has Preventio: Because little is understood about what causes hoarding disorder, there's no known way to prevent it. However, as with many mental health conditions, getting treatment at the first sign of a problem may help prevent hoarding from getting worse. This is especially important because by the time clutter becomes a noticeable problem, hoarding likely has been going on for a while.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Symptom: Swollen lymph nodes, which might feel like a lump under the skin. They happen most often in the neck, armpit and groin.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Symptom: Fever.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Symptom: Fatigue.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Symptom: Drenching night sweats.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Symptom: Weight loss that happens without trying.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Symptom: Itchy skin.

Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Cause: It's not clear what causes Hodgkin lymphoma. Cancer happens when cells develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the DNA changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells. In Hodgkin lymphoma, the cancer cells can build up in the lymph nodes, bone marrow, spleen and other tissues throughout the body.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Risk Factor: Hodgkin lymphoma is most often diagnosed in people in their 20s and 30s and those over age 65.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Risk Factor: A family history of lymphoma.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Risk Factor: Some infections.
Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Risk Factor: A weakened immune system or an autoimmune condition.

Hodgkin lymphoma (Hodgkin disease) has Complication: A potential complication of Hodgkin lymphoma is that the cancer may come back after treatment. This is called a relapse. Relapse is more common in people with advanced cancer.
Horner syndrome has Symptom: Horner syndrome usually affects only one side of the face. Common signs and symptoms include:

Horner syndrome has Cause: Horner syndrome is caused by damage to a certain pathway in the sympathetic nervous system. The sympathetic nervous system regulates heart rate, pupil size, perspiration, blood pressure and other functions that enable you to respond quickly to changes in your environment.
Hot flashes has Symptom: A hot flash might involve:
Hot flashes has Cause: Changing hormone levels before, during and after menopause are the most common causes of hot flashes. It's not clear how hormonal changes cause hot flashes.
Hot flashes has Risk Factor: Not all people who go through the change of life have hot flashes. Factors that may raise the risk of having them include:

Hot flashes has Complication: Hot flashes may affect daily activities and quality of life. Nighttime hot flashes, also called night sweats, can wake you from sleep. Over time, this can cause long-term sleep loss.
HPV infection has Symptom: Usually, the body's immune system defeats an HPV infection before it creates warts. Different types of HPV produce different warts, including:
HPV infection has Cause: HPV infection occurs when the virus enters the body, usually through a cut or other damage to skin. The virus spreads mainly by skin-to-skin contact.
HPV infection has Risk Factor: HPV infections are common. Risk factors for HPV infection include:

HPV infection has Complication: It's hard to prevent HPV infections that cause common warts. If you have a common wart, you can prevent the spread of the infection and keep new warts from forming by not picking at a wart and not biting your nails.

HPV infection has Preventio: It's hard to prevent HPV infections that cause common warts. If you have a common wart, you can prevent the spread of the infection and keep new warts from forming by not picking at a wart and not biting your nails.

Huntington's disease has Symptom: Huntington's disease usually causes movement disorders. It also causes mental health conditions and trouble with thinking and planning. These conditions can cause a wide spectrum of symptoms. The first symptoms vary greatly from person to person. Some symptoms appear to be worse or have a greater effect on functional ability. These symptoms may change in severity throughout the course of the disease.

Huntington's disease has Cause: Huntington's disease is caused by a difference in a single gene that's passed down from a parent. Huntington's disease follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. This means that a person needs only one copy of the nontypical gene to develop the disorder.

Huntington's disease has Risk Factor: People who have a parent with Huntington's disease are at risk of having the disease themselves. Children of a parent with Huntington's have a 50 percent chance of having the gene change that causes Huntington's.
Huntington's disease has Complication: Pneumonia or other infections.
Huntington's disease has Complication: Injuries related to falls.
Huntington's disease has Complication: Complications related to trouble swallowing.

Huntington's disease has Preventio: People with a known family history of Huntington's disease may be concerned about whether they may pass the Huntington gene on to their children. They might consider genetic testing and family planning options.
Hurthle cell cancer has Symptom: Hurthle cell cancer doesn't always cause symptoms, and it's sometimes detected during a physical examination or an imaging test done for some other reason.

Hurthle cell cancer has Risk Factor: Factors that increase the risk of developing thyroid cancer include:
Hurthle cell cancer has Complication: Possible complications of Hurthle cell cancer include:
Hydrocele has Symptom: Often the only sign of a hydrocele is a painless swelling of one or both testicles.
Hydrocele has Risk Factor: Injury or inflammation within the scrotum.
Hydrocele has Risk Factor: Infection, including a sexually transmitted infection.
Hydrocele has Complication: Infection or tumor.
Hydrocele has Complication: Inguinal hernia.
Hydrocephalus has Symptom: The symptoms of hydrocephalus can vary by age.
Hydrocephalus has Cause: Allowing the relatively heavy brain to float within the skull.
Hydrocephalus has Cause: Cushioning the brain to prevent injury.
Hydrocephalus has Cause: Removing waste products of the brain's metabolism.

Hydrocephalus has Cause: Flowing back and forth between the brain cavity and spinal column. This flow maintains a constant pressure within the brain and allows for changes in blood pressure in the brain.
Hydrocephalus has Risk Factor: Much of the time, the cause of hydrocephalus is not known. However, developmental or medical problems can contribute to or trigger hydrocephalus.

Hydrocephalus has Complication: In most cases, hydrocephalus worsens. Without treatment, hydrocephalus leads to complications. Complications may include learning disabilities or developmental and physical disabilities. Complications of this condition also can result in death. When hydrocephalus is mild and it's treated, there may be few, if any, serious complications.
Hydronephrosis has Symptom: Pain in the side and back that may travel to the lower stomach area or groin.
Hydronephrosis has Symptom: Pain with urination, or feeling a need to urinate that is urgent or happens often.

Hydronephrosis has Symptom: Fever.
Hydronephrosis has Symptom: Failure to thrive in infants.
Hydronephrosis has Symptom: Weight loss or loss of appetite.
Hydronephrosis has Symptom: Blood in urine.

Hydronephrosis has Cause: Kidney stones.
Hydronephrosis has Cause: Enlarged prostate.
Hydronephrosis has Cause: Injured or narrowed ureter.
Hydronephrosis has Cause: Urinary tract infection.
Hydronephrosis has Cause: Pregnancy.
Hydronephrosis has Cause: Cancer.

Hydronephrosis has Risk Factor: Hydronephrosis risk factors among adults ages 20 to 60 include being born female. The higher risk could be due to certain conditions that affect the uterus, such as pregnancy. It also could be due to conditions that affect the ovaries, such as cysts, buildups of pus and cancer. Risk factors for people older than age 60 include having an enlarged prostate or a urinary tract blockage from cancer.

Hydronephrosis has Complication: Hydronephrosis can lead to other health conditions called complications. Without treatment, some people who have severe hydronephrosis develop lasting kidney damage. Rarely, the condition can cause an affected kidney to lose its ability to filter blood, also called kidney failure.

Hypercalcemia has Symptom: Bones and muscles.
Hypercalcemia has Symptom: Brain.

Hypercalcemia has Complication: Osteoporosis.
Hypercalcemia has Complication: Kidney stones.
Hypercalcemia has Complication: Kidney failure.
Hypercalcemia has Complication: Nervous system conditions.
Hypercalcemia has Complication: Irregular heart rhythm.

Hypereosinophilic syndrome has Symptom: Muscle pain.
Hypereosinophilic syndrome has Symptom: Swelling in deep layers of the skin.
Hypereosinophilic syndrome has Symptom: Rash.
Hypereosinophilic syndrome has Symptom: Fever.
Hypereosinophilic syndrome has Cause: Eosinophils are important in fighting parasites and bacteria. They also regulate other immune system cells and proteins that cause allergic reactions.
Hypereosinophilic syndrome has Risk Factor: HES can affect anyone, but it occurs more often in men.

Hyperglycemia in diabetes has Symptom: Hyperglycemia usually doesn't cause symptoms until blood sugar (glucose) levels are high — above 180 to 200 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 10 to 11.1 millimoles per liter (mmol/L).

Hyperglycemia in diabetes has Cause: During digestion, the body breaks down carbohydrates from foods — such as bread, rice and pasta — into sugar molecules. One of the sugar molecules is called glucose. It's one of the body's main energy sources. Glucose is absorbed and goes directly into your bloodstream after you eat, but it can't enter the cells of most of the body's tissues without the help of insulin. Insulin is a hormone made by the pancreas.
Hyperglycemia in diabetes has Risk Factor: Many factors can contribute to hyperglycemia, including:

Hyperglycemia in diabetes has Complication: Keeping blood sugar in a healthy range can help prevent many diabetes-related complications. Long-term complications of hyperglycemia that isn't treated include:

Hyperhidrosis has Symptom: The main symptom of hyperhidrosis is heavy sweating. This goes beyond the sweating from being in a hot environment, exercising, or feeling anxious or stressed. The type of hyperhidrosis that usually affects the hands, feet, underarms or face causes at least one episode a week when you're awake. And the sweating usually happens on both sides of the body.

Hyperhidrosis has Cause: Menopause hot flashes
Hyperhidrosis has Cause: Thyroid problems
Hyperhidrosis has Cause: Some types of cancer
Hyperhidrosis has Cause: Nervous system disorders
Hyperhidrosis has Cause: Infections

Hyperhidrosis has Risk Factor: Taking medicines or supplements that cause sweating
Hyperhidrosis has Risk Factor: Having a medical condition that causes sweating
Hyperhidrosis has Complication: Infections.
Hyperhidrosis has Complication: Social and emotional effects.

Hyperparathyroidism has Cause: Hyperparathyroidism is caused by factors that raise the amount of parathyroid hormone in the blood.

Hyperparathyroidism has Complication: Health issues that can happen because of hyperparathyroidism, called complications, are mainly related to the long-term effects of too little calcium in the bones and too much calcium in the blood.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy has Cause: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy usually is caused by changes in genes that cause the heart muscle to thicken.

Hypoparathyroidism has Symptom: Symptoms of hypoparathyroidism often are related to low calcium levels in the blood. The symptoms can include:
Hypoparathyroidism has Cause: Hypoparathyroidism happens when the parathyroid glands don't make enough parathyroid hormone. There are four small parathyroid glands in the neck near the thyroid gland.
Hypoparathyroidism has Risk Factor: Factors that can raise the risk of hypoparathyroidism include:
Hypoparathyroidism has Complication: Hypoparathyroidism can lead to other health conditions. Some of these conditions can be reversed with treatment. Others can't be reversed.

Hypoparathyroidism has Preventio: There are no specific steps to take to prevent hypoparathyroidism. But if you're scheduled to have thyroid or neck surgery, talk to your surgeon. Ask about the risk of damage to your parathyroid glands during the procedure. Before surgery, your healthcare professional may choose to test your calcium, parathyroid hormone and vitamin D levels. Your care professional also may have you start taking supplements if needed.

Hypopituitarism has Symptom: The symptoms of hypopituitarism usually start slowly and get worse over time. They might not be noticed for months or even years. But for some people, symptoms start suddenly.
Hypopituitarism has Cause: Lack of blood flow to the brain or pituitary gland, known as a stroke, or bleeding, called hemorrhage, into the brain or pituitary gland.
Hypopituitarism has Cause: Certain medicines, such as narcotics, high-dose steroids or certain cancer medicines called checkpoint inhibitors.
Hypopituitarism has Cause: Swelling, known as inflammation, of the pituitary gland caused by an unusual immune system response, called hypophysitis.
Hypopituitarism has Cause: Infections of the brain, such as meningitis, or infections that can spread to the brain, such as tuberculosis or syphilis.

Hypopituitarism has Cause: Significant blood loss during childbirth, which can damage the front part of the pituitary gland. This condition is known as Sheehan syndrome or postpartum pituitary necrosis.
Hypopituitarism has Risk Factor: A head injury.
Hypopituitarism has Risk Factor: Brain surgery.
Hypopituitarism has Risk Factor: Radiation treatment to the head or neck.

These include an inflammatory disease that affects various organs, called sarcoidosis; a disease in which unusual cells cause scarring, called Langerhans cell histiocytosis; and a disease that causes too much iron in the liver and other tissues, called hemochromatosis.

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome has Symptom: Being more drowsy or less active than is typical for most babies.

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome has Cause: The body's main artery, called the aorta.

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome has Risk Factor: People who have a child with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) have a higher risk of having another baby with this or a similar condition.

Hypoplastic left heart syndrome has Preventio: There's no way to prevent hypoplastic left heart syndrome. If you were born with a heart condition, talk with a heart doctor and genetic counselor before getting pregnant.

Hypospadias has Symptom: Downward curve of the penis. This condition is called chordee.
Hypospadias has Symptom: Hooded appearance of the penis because only the top half of the penis is covered by foreskin.
Hypospadias has Symptom: Differences in spraying when passing urine.

Hypospadias has Cause: Hypospadias is a condition that is present at birth. As the penis develops in a male unborn baby, certain hormones stimulate how the urethra and foreskin form. Hypospadias results from a change in the action of these hormones. This keeps the two sides of the urethral folds from joining completely. The location of the urethral opening depends on when the joining stopped.
Hypospadias has Risk Factor: Family history.
Hypospadias has Risk Factor: Genetics.
Hypospadias has Risk Factor: Some research suggests that there may be a higher risk of hypospadias in male babies born to women older than 35 years.
Hypospadias has Risk Factor: Exposure to certain substances during pregnancy.
Hypospadias has Complication: Differences in how the penis looks.
Hypospadias has Complication: Problems learning to use a toilet.
Hypospadias has Complication: Unusual curve of the penis with an erection.
Hypospadias has Complication: Problems releasing sperm from the penis. This release is called an ejaculation.

Hypothermia has Symptom: Confusion or memory loss.

Hypothermia has Symptom: In infants, bright red, cold skin.

Hypothermia has Cause: Falling into the water, such as in a boating accident.
Hypothermia has Cause: Living in a house that's too cold, either from poor heating or too much air conditioning.
Hypothermia has Risk Factor: Exhaustion.

Hypothermia has Risk Factor: The body's ability to regulate temperature and to sense cold may lessen with age. And some older adults may not be able to tell someone when they are cold or to move to a warm location if they do feel cold.

Hypothermia has Risk Factor: Children lose heat faster than adults do. Children also may ignore the cold because they're having too much fun to think about it. They may not have the judgment to dress properly in cold weather or to get out of the cold when they should.

Hypothermia has Risk Factor: Alcohol and drug use.
Hypothermia has Risk Factor: Certain medical conditions.

Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Being preoccupied with having or getting a serious disease or health condition
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Worrying that minor symptoms or body sensations mean you have a serious illness
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Being easily alarmed about your health status
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Finding little or no reassurance from doctor visits or negative test results
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Worrying excessively about a specific medical condition or your risk of developing a medical condition because it runs in your family
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Having so much distress about possible illnesses that it's hard for you to function
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Repeatedly checking your body for signs of illness or disease
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Frequently making medical appointments for reassurance — or avoiding medical care for fear of being diagnosed with a serious illness
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Avoiding people, places or activities for fear of health risks
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Constantly talking about your health and possible illnesses
Illness anxiety disorder has Symptom: Frequently searching the internet for causes of symptoms or possible illnesses

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) has Symptom: Easy bruising.

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) has Symptom: Bleeding into the skin that looks like tiny reddish-purple spots, also known as petechiae. The spots mostly show up on the lower legs. They look like a rash.

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) has Symptom: Bleeding from the gums or nose.

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) has Symptom: Really heavy menstrual flow.

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) has Cause: Immune thrombocytopenia usually happens when the immune system makes a mistake. It attacks and destroys the cells that help blood clot, also known as platelets.

Infant jaundice has Symptom: Yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes — the main sign of infant jaundice — usually appears within a few days after birth.

Infant jaundice has Complication: High levels of bilirubin that cause severe jaundice can cause serious complications if not treated.
Infant jaundice has Preventio: The best preventive of infant jaundice is adequate feeding. Breastfed infants should have 8 to 12 feedings a day for the first several days of life.

Infertility has Symptom: The main symptom of infertility is not getting pregnant. There may be no other clear symptoms. Some women with infertility may have irregular menstrual periods or no periods. And some men may have some symptoms of hormonal problems, such as changes in hair growth or sexual function.

Infertility has Cause: All of the steps during ovulation and fertilization need to happen correctly in order to get pregnant. Ovulation is the release of an egg from an ovary. Fertilization is when the egg and sperm unite to form an embryo, which becomes an unborn baby during pregnancy. Sometimes, the issues that cause infertility in couples are present at birth. Other times, they develop later in life.

Infertility has Risk Factor: Women's fertility slowly declines with age, especially in the mid-30s. It drops quickly after age 37. Infertility in older women likely is due to the lower number and quality of eggs, or to health problems that affect fertility. Men over age 40 may be less fertile than younger men. The risk of birth defects and genetic problems also rises for children born to men over age 40.
Infertility has Risk Factor: Tobacco use.
Infertility has Risk Factor: Marijuana use.

Infertility has Risk Factor: Being overweight.

Inflammatory breast cancer has Cause: Inflammatory breast cancer happens when cells in the breast develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the DNA changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.

Influenza (flu) has Cause: Influenza is caused by viruses. These viruses travel through the air in droplets when someone with the infection coughs, sneezes or talks. You can inhale the droplets directly. Or you can pick up the virus from touching an object, such as a computer keyboard, and then touching your eyes, nose or mouth.

Inherited metabolic disorders has Cause: Inherited metabolic disorders are caused by changes in specific genes that affect metabolism. Different gene changes cause different types of inherited metabolic disorders. These gene changes are most commonly passed down from both parents. But sometimes the gene change comes only from one parent, most often from the mother. There are hundreds of inherited metabolic disorders caused by different genes.

Inherited metabolic disorders has Risk Factor: The risk of an inherited metabolic disorder is higher if one or both parents have the gene change that can cause the condition. In some cases, future parents may decide to have carrier testing before pregnancy. This test can identify some gene changes in parents that may raise the risk that future children will have certain types of inherited metabolic disorders.

Interstitial cystitis has Symptom: The signs and symptoms of interstitial cystitis vary from person to person. If you have interstitial cystitis, your symptoms may also vary over time, periodically flaring in response to common triggers, such as menstruation, sitting for a long time, stress, exercise and sexual activity.

Interstitial cystitis has Cause: The exact cause of interstitial cystitis isn't known, but it's likely that many factors contribute. For instance, people with interstitial cystitis may also have a defect in the protective lining (epithelium) of the bladder. A leak in the epithelium may allow toxic substances in urine to irritate your bladder wall.

Interstitial lung disease has Cause: An underlying systemic condition.
Interstitial lung disease has Cause: Certain types of medicines, or radiation.

Interstitial lung disease has Risk Factor: ILD is much more likely to affect adults, although babies and children sometimes get the disease.
Interstitial lung disease has Risk Factor: Exposure to toxins at work or in the environment.

Interstitial lung disease has Preventio: To prevent interstitial lung disease, avoid exposure to toxins at work, such as asbestos, coal dust and silica dust. Also, avoid exposure to toxins in the environment, such as bird protein, mold and bacteria. If you must be around these toxins, protect yourself by wearing a respirator. Other ways to prevent ILD include not smoking and avoiding secondhand smoke.

Intracranial venous malformations has Cause: Experts don't understand what causes intracranial venous malformations. Certain genetic changes might play a role, and the malformations may happen during fetal development. However, some types may not be inherited and are acquired later in life, possibly after an injury to the central nervous system.

Intussusception has Symptom: The first sign of intussusception in an otherwise healthy baby may be sudden, loud crying caused by belly pain. Infants who have belly pain may pull their knees to their chests when they cry.

Intussusception has Cause: The intestine is shaped like a long tube. In intussusception, one part of the intestine — usually the small intestine — slides inside a part next to it. This is sometimes called telescoping because it's similar to the way a collapsible telescope slides together.
Intussusception has Risk Factor: Risk factors for intussusception include:

Intussusception has Complication: Intussusception can cut off the blood supply to the affected portion of the intestine. If left untreated, the lack of blood causes the tissue of the intestinal wall to die. Tissue death can lead to a tear in the intestinal wall, called a perforation. This can cause an infection of the lining of the abdominal cavity, known as peritonitis.

Klinefelter syndrome has Symptom: Symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome vary widely. Many children with Klinefelter syndrome show few or only mild symptoms. Most often the condition isn't diagnosed until puberty or adulthood, or it may never be diagnosed. For others, the condition has a noticeable effect on growth or appearance. Klinefelter syndrome may affect development, physical appearance, sexual development and mental health.

Klinefelter syndrome has Cause: More than one extra copy of the X sex chromosome, which is rare and results in a severe form of the syndrome.

Klinefelter syndrome has Risk Factor: Klinefelter syndrome occurs because of a random genetic change in the sperm or the egg. The risk of Klinefelter syndrome is not raised by anything parents do or don't do. For people carrying a pregnancy after age 35, the risk is higher but only slightly.
Klinefelter syndrome has Complication: Anxiety and depression.
Klinefelter syndrome has Complication: Social, emotional and behavioral problems, such as low self-esteem.
Klinefelter syndrome has Complication: Problem with fertility and sexual function.

Lazy eye (amblyopia) has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of lazy eye include:

Lazy eye (amblyopia) has Cause: Lazy eye develops because of abnormal visual experience early in life that changes the nerve pathways between a thin layer of tissue (retina) at the back of the eye and the brain. The weaker eye receives fewer visual signals. Eventually, the eyes' ability to work together decreases, and the brain suppresses or ignores input from the weaker eye.
Lazy eye (amblyopia) has Risk Factor: Factors associated with an increased risk of lazy eye include:
Lazy eye (amblyopia) has Complication: Untreated, lazy eye can cause permanent vision loss.

Lead poisoning has Symptom: Initially, lead poisoning can be hard to detect — even people who seem healthy can have high blood levels of lead. Signs and symptoms usually don't appear until dangerous amounts have accumulated.

Lead poisoning has Cause: Lead is a metal that occurs naturally in the earth's crust, but human activity — mining, burning fossil fuels and manufacturing — has caused it to become more widespread. Lead was also once used in paint and gasoline and is still used in batteries, solder, pipes, pottery, roofing materials and some cosmetics.
Lead poisoning has Risk Factor: Factors that may increase your risk of lead poisoning include:

Lead poisoning has Complication: Exposure to even low levels of lead can cause damage over time, especially in children. The greatest risk is to brain development, where irreversible damage can occur. Higher levels can damage the kidneys and nervous system in both children and adults. Very high lead levels may cause seizures, unconsciousness and death.

Lobular carcinoma in situ begins when cells in a milk-producing gland of a breast, called a lobule, develop changes in their DNA. These changes cause the cells to look different from healthy cells. The changed cells remain in the lobule and don't extend into, or invade, nearby breast tissue.

The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.

Malignant hyperthermia has Symptom: In most cases, no signs or symptoms of susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia exist until you're exposed to certain drugs used for anesthesia.

Malignant hyperthermia has Cause: Malignant hyperthermia can result when you have malignant hyperthermia susceptibility (MHS), a genetic disorder that's caused by a gene change (mutation). The affected gene increases your risk of malignant hyperthermia when you're exposed to certain anesthesia drugs that trigger a reaction. The affected gene is most commonly inherited, usually from one parent who also has it. Less often, the affected gene is not inherited and is the result of a random gene change.
Malignant hyperthermia has Risk Factor: Your risk of having the genetic disorder malignant hyperthermia susceptibility (MHS) is higher if someone in your family has it.
Malignant hyperthermia has Complication: If not treated promptly, malignant hyperthermia can result in major complications, such as:

Malignant hyperthermia has Preventio: If you have a family history of malignant hyperthermia or a relative who has problems with anesthesia, tell your health care provider or anesthesiologist before surgery or any procedure that requires anesthesia.

Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors has Risk Factor: Noncancerous nerve tumors.
Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors has Risk Factor: A condition that runs in families.

Mammary duct ectasia has Cause: Experts don't know exactly what causes mammary duct ectasia. The condition may be related to changes in the breast tissue. Your breasts are made up of connective tissues that have tiny tubes inside called milk ducts that carry milk to your nipple. Mammary duct ectasia happens when a milk duct beneath the nipple widens, which often happens with age. The duct walls may thicken and fill with fluid, becoming blocked or clogged with a sticky substance. This can cause painful swelling, called inflammation.
Mammary duct ectasia has Complication: Usually, the complications of mammary duct ectasia aren't serious, but they can be bothersome. They may include:

Marfan syndrome has Cause: Marfan syndrome is caused by a defect in the gene that enables your body to produce a protein that helps give connective tissue its elasticity and strength.

Marginal zone lymphoma has Symptom: Bloating.
Marginal zone lymphoma has Symptom: Nausea.

Marginal zone lymphoma has Cause: It's not always clear what causes marginal zone lymphoma (MZL). Cancer happens when cells develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the DNA changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.
Marginal zone lymphoma has Risk Factor: Marginal zone lymphoma can happen at any age. But it's most common in people 60 or older.
Marginal zone lymphoma has Risk Factor: Ongoing infections.
Marginal zone lymphoma has Risk Factor: Autoimmune conditions.

Marginal zone lymphoma has Complication: A complication of marginal zone lymphoma is the risk of the cancer turning into a more aggressive type, such as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Marginal zone lymphoma also has a risk of coming back after treatment, known as a relapse. Repeated relapses are common.

MCAD deficiency has Cause: When you don't have enough of theMCADenzyme in your body, certain fats called medium-chain fatty acids can't be broken down and turned into energy. This leads to low energy and low blood sugar. Also, fatty acids can build up in body tissues and cause damage.

MCAD deficiency has Risk Factor: A child is at risk ofMCADdeficiency if both parents are carriers of a gene known to cause it. The child then inherits two copies of the gene — one from each parent. Children who inherit only one copy of the affected gene from one parent typically won't developMCADdeficiency but will be carriers of the gene.

MCAD deficiency has Complication: Liver problems.
MCAD deficiency has Complication: Brain damage.
MCAD deficiency has Complication: Coma.

Measles has Symptom: Measles symptoms show up around 7 to 14 days after contact with the virus.

Measles has Cause: Measles is caused by a virus that spreads only among humans. When someone with measles coughs, sneezes or talks, droplets spray into the air. People who breathe in the droplets can catch the virus. Droplets also may land on surfaces. You can catch measles if you touch an infected surface and then touch your mouth, nose or eyes. These droplets can infect other people for up to two hours.

Measles has Risk Factor: Your risk of measles goes up if you aren't vaccinated. Your risk also goes up if you've had only one dose of the vaccine. People who travel to places where measles regularly spreads or where there is a measles outbreak are more likely to get the illness. This is especially true if you haven't had two doses of the measles vaccine.
Measles has Complication: Complications of measles may include:

Measles has Preventio: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, also called CDC, recommends that children and adults get a measles vaccine. On average, the vaccine gives lifelong protection from measles for about 97% of people who get two doses of the vaccine.

Median arcuate ligament syndrome (MALS) has Symptom: The stomach pain gets better by leaning forward or backward or standing while eating.

Median arcuate ligament syndrome (MALS) has Risk Factor: Because the cause ofMALSis poorly understood, the risk factors are unclear. Median arcuate ligament syndrome is more common in adults than in children. It also is more common among women than among men.

The symptoms can be similar to those of other conditions. It may take some time to get an accurate diagnosis.
