Merkel cell carcinoma has Complication: Even with treatment, Merkel cell carcinoma often spreads to other parts of the body. When cancer spreads, healthcare professionals sometimes say it metastasizes. Merkel cell carcinoma tends to travel first to nearby lymph nodes.

Merkel cell carcinoma has Preventio: While exposure to sunlight isn't proved to cause all Merkel cell carcinomas, it is thought to be a risk factor for this cancer. Getting less sun exposure may lower your risk of skin cancer.
Mesenteric ischemia has Symptom: Symptoms of the acute form of mesenteric ischemia include:

Mesenteric ischemia has Cause: Both acute and chronic mesenteric ischemia are caused by a decrease in blood flow to the small intestine. Acute mesenteric ischemia is most commonly caused by a blood clot in the main mesenteric artery. The blood clot often starts in the heart. The chronic form is most commonly caused by a buildup of fatty deposits, called plaque, that narrows the arteries.
Mesenteric ischemia has Risk Factor: Atrial fibrillation — an irregular and often very rapid heart rhythm.
Mesenteric ischemia has Risk Factor: Congestive heart failure — a condition in which the heart muscle doesn't pump blood as well as it should.
Mesenteric ischemia has Risk Factor: Recent vascular surgery.
Mesenteric ischemia has Complication: Irreversible bowel damage.
Mesenteric ischemia has Complication: Sepsis.
Mesenteric ischemia has Complication: Death.
Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Symptom: Pain in the stomach area, often on the lower right side, but the pain can be more spread out.
Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Symptom: General tenderness of the stomach area.
Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Symptom: Fever.
Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Symptom: Enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes.

Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Cause: The most common cause of mesenteric lymphadenitis is a viral infection, such as gastroenteritis. Gastroenteritis is often called stomach flu. This infection causes inflammation and swelling in the lymph nodes in the thin tissue that attaches the intestine to the back of the wall around the stomach area, called mesentery.
Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Risk Factor: Viral or bacterial gastroenteritis.
Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Risk Factor: Inflammatory bowel disease.
Mesenteric lymphadenitis has Risk Factor: Lymphoma.

Mesothelioma has Cause: It's not always clear what causes mesothelioma. Experts believe that being around asbestos causes many mesotheliomas. But not everyone with mesothelioma has been around asbestos. Exactly what causes the cancer may not be known.

Mesothelioma has Risk Factor: A family history of mesothelioma.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy has Cause: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an inherited disorder caused by an abnormal (mutated) gene. The condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. The abnormal recessive gene is located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). To inherit an autosomal recessive disorder, both parents must be carriers, but they do not typically show signs of the condition. The affected child inherits two copies of the abnormal gene — one from each parent.

Microcephaly has Cause: Microcephaly usually is the result of a problem with brain development, which can occur in the womb (congenital) or during infancy. Microcephaly may be genetic. Other causes may include:

Microcephaly has Complication: Some children with microcephaly achieve developmental milestones even though their heads will always be small for their age and sex. But depending on the cause and severity of the microcephaly, complications may include:

Migraine has Symptom: Migraines can affect children and teenagers as well as adults. A migraine can progress through four stages that have different symptoms: prodrome, aura, attack and postdrome. Not everyone who has migraines goes through all stages.
Migraine has Cause: Though migraine causes aren't fully understood, genetics and environmental factors appear to play a role.
Migraine has Risk Factor: Family history.
Migraine has Risk Factor: Migraines can begin at any age, though the first often occurs when you're a teenager. Migraines tend to peak during your 30s and then gradually become less frequent.
Migraine has Risk Factor: Women are three times more likely than men to have migraines.
Migraine has Risk Factor: Hormonal changes.

Migraine has Complication: A complication for some people with migraines is medication overuse headaches. Taking painkillers too often can trigger these headaches. Medication overuse headaches may occur if you take aspirin or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) for more than 14 days a month. Or they can occur if you take medicines known as triptans for more than nine days a month. The risk seems to be highest with medicines that combine aspirin, acetaminophen and caffeine.

Migraine with aura has Symptom: Migraine aura symptoms include temporary visual or other disturbances. Aura symptoms usually strike before other migraine symptoms such as intense head pain, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound.

Migraine with aura has Cause: There is evidence that migraine auras are due to electrical or chemical waves that move across the brain. This is called cortical spreading depression. The part of the brain where an electrical or chemical wave spreads determines the symptoms you might experience.

Migraine with aura has Risk Factor: Although no specific factors appear to increase the risk of migraine with aura, migraines in general seem to be more common in people with a family history of migraine.

Migraine with aura has Complication: People who have migraine with aura are at a mildly increased risk of stroke. Depression, anxiety and sleep issues also are more common in people with migraine, including migraine with aura.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Forgetting things more often.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Missing appointments or social events.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Losing their train of thought. Or not following the plot of a book or movie.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Trouble following a conversation.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Trouble finding the right word or with language.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Finding it hard to make decisions, finish a task or follow instructions.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Trouble finding their way around places they know well.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Poor judgment.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Symptom: Changes that are noticed by family and friends.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Cause: Clumps of beta-amyloid protein, called plaques, and neurofibrillary tangles of tau proteins that are seen in Alzheimer's disease.

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Cause: Microscopic clumps of a protein called Lewy bodies. These clumps are related to Parkinson's disease, dementia with Lewy bodies and, sometimes, Alzheimer's disease.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Cause: Small strokes or less blood flow through brain blood vessels.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Risk Factor: Older age.

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Risk Factor: Having a form of a gene known as APOE e4. This gene also is linked to Alzheimer's disease. But having the gene doesn't guarantee a decline in thinking and memory.

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Complication: Complications of mild cognitive impairment include a higher risk — but not a certainty — of dementia. Overall, about 1% to 3% of older adults develop dementia every year. Studies suggest that around 10% to 15% of people with mild cognitive impairment go on to develop dementia each year.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Don't drink large amounts of alcohol.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Limit exposure to air pollution.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Reduce your risk of a head injury, such as by wearing a helmet when riding a motorcycle or bicycle.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Don't smoke.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Manage health conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure, obesity and depression.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Watch your levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and get treatment if the levels are high.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Practice good sleep habits and manage any sleep conditions.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Eat a healthy diet full of nutrients. Include fruits and vegetables and foods low in saturated fats.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Stay social with friends and family.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Get moderate to vigorous exercise most days of the week.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Wear a hearing aid if you have hearing loss.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Get regular eye exams and treat any vision changes.
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) has Preventio: Stimulate your mind with puzzles, games and memory training.
Milk allergy has Symptom: Milk allergy symptoms, which differ from person to person, start a few minutes to a few hours after you or your child drinks milk or eats milk products.

Milk allergy has Cause: All true food allergies are caused by an immune system malfunction. If you have milk allergy, your immune system identifies certain milk proteins as harmful, triggering the production of immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies to neutralize the protein (allergen). The next time you come in contact with these proteins, IgE antibodies recognize them and signal your immune system to release histamine and other chemicals, causing a range of allergic symptoms.
Milk allergy has Risk Factor: Certain factors may increase the risk of developing milk allergy:
Milk allergy has Complication: Children who are allergic to milk are more likely to develop certain other health problems, including:

Milk allergy has Preventio: There's no sure way to prevent a food allergy, but you can prevent reactions by avoiding the food that causes them. If you know that you or your child is allergic to milk, avoid milk and milk products.
Miscarriage has Symptom: Bleeding from the vagina with or without pain, including light bleeding called spotting.
Miscarriage has Symptom: Pain or cramping in the pelvic area or lower back.
Miscarriage has Symptom: Fluid or tissue passing from the vagina.
Miscarriage has Symptom: Fast heartbeat.

Miscarriage has Cause: Most miscarriages happen because the unborn baby doesn't develop properly. About half to two-thirds of miscarriages in the first trimester are linked with extra or missing chromosomes. Chromosomes are structures in each cell that contain genes, the instructions for how people look and function. When an egg and sperm unite, two sets of chromosomes — one from each parent — join together. But if either set has fewer or more chromosomes than usual, that can lead to a miscarriage.

Miscarriage has Risk Factor: If you're older than age 35, you have a higher risk of miscarriage than a younger person. At age 35, you have about a 20% risk. At age 40, the risk is about 33% to 40%. And at age 45, it ranges from 57% to 80%.
Miscarriage has Risk Factor: If you've had one or more prior miscarriages before, you're at higher risk of pregnancy loss.
Miscarriage has Risk Factor: Long-term conditions.
Miscarriage has Risk Factor: Uterine or cervical problems.
Miscarriage has Risk Factor: Smoking, alcohol, caffeine and illegal drugs.
Miscarriage has Risk Factor: Weight.
Miscarriage has Risk Factor: Genetic conditions.
Miscarriage has Complication: Fever higher than 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit more than two times.
Miscarriage has Complication: Chills.
Miscarriage has Complication: Pain in the lower stomach area.
Miscarriage has Complication: Foul-smelling fluid called discharge from the vagina.
Miscarriage has Complication: Vaginal bleeding.
Miscarriage has Preventio: Get regular prenatal care while you're pregnant and right after you give birth.
Miscarriage has Preventio: Stay away from miscarriage risk factors — such as smoking, drinking alcohol and illegal drug use.
Miscarriage has Preventio: Take a daily multivitamin.
Miscarriage has Preventio: If you've had one or more prior miscarriages, ask your health care professional if you should take low-dose aspirin.

Miscarriage has Preventio: Limit caffeine. Many experts recommend having no more than 200 milligrams per day while pregnant. This is the amount of caffeine in a 12-ounce cup of brewed coffee. Also, check food labels for amounts of caffeine. The effects of caffeine aren't clear for your unborn baby and higher amounts may include miscarriage or preterm birth. Ask your pregnancy care team what's right for you.

Mitral valve regurgitation has Complication: High blood pressure in the lungs, called pulmonary hypertension.
Mitral valve regurgitation has Complication: Congestive heart failure.

Mitral valve stenosis has Symptom: Fatigue, especially during increased activity.
Mitral valve stenosis has Symptom: Swollen feet or legs.
Mitral valve stenosis has Symptom: Pounding, skipping or otherwise irregular heartbeats, called arrhythmias.
Mitral valve stenosis has Symptom: Dizziness or fainting.
Mitral valve stenosis has Symptom: Fluid buildup in the lungs.
Mitral valve stenosis has Symptom: Chest discomfort or chest pain.
Mitral valve stenosis has Symptom: Coughing up blood.

Mitral valve stenosis has Preventio: Rheumatic fever is the most common cause of mitral valve stenosis. So the best way to prevent mitral valve stenosis is to prevent rheumatic fever. You can do this by making sure you and your children see a healthcare professional for sore throats. Untreated strep throat infections can develop into rheumatic fever. Strep throat is usually easily treated with antibiotics.
Mittelschmerz has Symptom: On one side of your lower abdomen
Mittelschmerz has Symptom: Dull and achy, similar to menstrual cramps
Mittelschmerz has Symptom: Sharp and sudden
Mittelschmerz has Symptom: Accompanied by slight vaginal bleeding or discharge

Mittelschmerz has Complication: Mittelschmerz doesn't lead to other health conditions, also called complications. The pain goes away on its own, or with medicine or home remedies.
Mittelschmerz has Preventio: Mittelschmerz can't be prevented. It's linked with natural changes in the body that happen during the menstrual cycle.

Mixed connective tissue disease has Cause: Experts don't know what causes mixed connective tissue disease. It's a condition in which the immune system attacks healthy cells by mistake, called an autoimmune condition. Most often, the immune system fights off diseases.
Mixed connective tissue disease has Risk Factor: Mixed connective tissue disease can happen at any age. But it seems to be most common in people assigned female at birth who are younger than age 50.
Mixed connective tissue disease has Complication: Mixed connective tissue disease can lead to serious complications. Some of them can be fatal. Complications include:
Molar pregnancy has Symptom: Dark brown to bright red bleeding from the vagina during the first three months
Molar pregnancy has Symptom: Severe nausea and vomiting
Molar pregnancy has Symptom: Sometimes grapelike cysts that pass from the vagina

Molar pregnancy has Cause: An egg fertilized atypically causes a molar pregnancy. Human cells usually have 23 pairs of chromosomes. In a typical fertilization, one chromosome in each pair comes from the father, the other from the mother.
Molar pregnancy has Risk Factor: Earlier molar pregnancy.
Molar pregnancy has Risk Factor: A molar pregnancy is more likely in people older than age 43 or younger than age 15.

Molar pregnancy has Complication: After removing a molar pregnancy, molar tissue might remain and continue to grow. This is called persistent gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).GTNhappens more often in complete molar pregnancies than it does in partial molar pregnancies.

Molar pregnancy has Preventio: If you've had a molar pregnancy, talk to your pregnancy care provider before trying to get pregnant again. You might want to wait six months to one year. The risk of having another molar pregnancy is low, but it's higher once you've had a molar pregnancy.
Mold allergy has Symptom: A mold allergy causes the same symptoms that happen in other types of upper respiratory allergies, such as hay fever. Symptoms caused by a mold allergy can include:

Mold allergy has Cause: Like any allergy, mold allergy symptoms are triggered by an overly sensitive immune system response. When you inhale tiny airborne mold spores, your body recognizes them as foreign invaders and develops allergy-causing antibodies to fight them.
Mold allergy has Risk Factor: A number of factors can make someone more likely to develop a mold allergy or make mold allergy symptoms worse, including:

Mold allergy has Complication: Most allergic responses to mold involve hay fever-type symptoms that can make you miserable but aren't serious. However, certain allergic conditions caused by mold are more serious. These include:
Mold allergy has Preventio: To reduce mold growth in your home, follow these tips:
Moles has Symptom: Color and texture.
Moles has Symptom: Shape.
Moles has Symptom: Size.

Moles has Cause: Moles are caused when cells in the skin called melanocytes grow in clusters. Melanocytes generally are distributed throughout the skin. They produce melanin, the natural pigment that gives skin its color.
Moles has Complication: Being born with large moles.
Moles has Complication: Having unusual moles.
Moles has Complication: Having many moles.
Moles has Complication: Having a personal or family history of melanoma.
Moles has Complication: Using tanning lamps or beds.

Molluscum contagiosum has Cause: The virus that causes molluscum contagiosum spreads easily through:

If scratched, these bumps can become infected and heal with scarring. If sores appear on the eyelids, pink eye (conjunctivitis) can develop.

Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) has Symptom: People with monoclonal gammopathy often don't have symptoms. Some people have a rash or nerve problems, such as numbness or tingling. A blood test for another condition might findMGUSby chance.

Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) has Cause: Experts don't know what causesMGUS. Changes in genes and being around certain chemicals, such as those used to kill pests, appear to play a role.
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) has Risk Factor: The average age at diagnosis is 70 years.
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) has Risk Factor: Race.
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) has Risk Factor: MGUSis more common in men.
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) has Risk Factor: Family history.

Mononucleosis has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of mononucleosis may include:

Mononucleosis has Cause: The most common cause of mononucleosis is the Epstein-Barr virus, but other viruses also can cause similar symptoms. This virus is spread through saliva, and you may catch it from kissing or from sharing food or drinks.
Mononucleosis has Complication: Complications of mononucleosis can sometimes be serious.

Mononucleosis has Preventio: Mononucleosis is spread through saliva. If you're infected, you can help prevent spreading the virus to others by not kissing them and by not sharing food, dishes, glasses and utensils until several days after your fever has improved — and even longer, if possible. And remember to wash your hands regularly to prevent spread of the virus.
Mood disorders has Symptom: Cause you to feel sad, empty, anxious and cranky.
Mood disorders has Symptom: Affect your ability to focus and function.
Mood disorders has Symptom: Cause loss of pleasure in most or all activities.
Mood disorders has Symptom: Affect your energy level and quality of life.
Mood disorders has Symptom: Make you feel worthless or guilty.
Mood disorders has Symptom: Affect how much you eat and sleep.
Mood disorders has Symptom: Raise thoughts about suicide.

Mood disorders has Cause: Mood disorders are caused by traits passed down to you, as well as environmental factors and life events. Environmental factors can include, for example, childhood experiences and stressful life events. Some prescription drugs, such as corticosteroids and medicines for Parkinson's disease, and street drugs also can cause mood disorders.
Mood disorders has Risk Factor: Risk factors include life experiences and stressful life events that increase the risk of certain types of mood disorders.
Morning sickness has Symptom: Nausea, with or without vomiting, is common in pregnancy. Morning sickness is often brought on by smelling certain odors or eating certain foods.

Morning sickness has Cause: The cause of morning sickness is not known. Hormone changes might play a role. Rarely, a medical condition not related to pregnancy, such as thyroid or gallbladder disease, can cause serious nausea or vomiting.
Morning sickness has Risk Factor: Had nausea or vomiting from other causes before becoming pregnant, such as motion sickness or migraines.
Morning sickness has Risk Factor: Had morning sickness during a prior pregnancy.
Morning sickness has Risk Factor: Are pregnant with twins or other multiples.
Morning sickness has Complication: Mild nausea and vomiting of pregnancy usually won't cause harm.
Morning sickness has Preventio: There's no sure way to prevent morning sickness. However, taking a daily vitamin supplement before and during pregnancy might help.
Morphea has Symptom: Reddish or purplish oval patches of skin, often on the belly, chest or back
Morphea has Symptom: Patches that gradually develop a lighter or whitish center
Morphea has Symptom: Linear patches, especially on the arms or legs and possibly the forehead or scalp
Morphea has Symptom: A gradual change in the affected skin, which becomes firm, thickened, dry and shiny

Morphea has Cause: The cause of morphea is unknown. It may be caused by an unusual reaction of your immune system. In people at increased risk of morphea, it could be triggered by injury to the affected area, medications, chemical toxins, an infection or radiation therapy.
Morphea has Risk Factor: Being white and female.
Morphea has Risk Factor: The condition can affect people at any age. It usually appears between the ages of 2 and 14 or in the mid-40s.
Morphea has Risk Factor: A family history of morphea.
Morphea has Complication: Self-esteem issues.
Morphea has Complication: Movement problems.

Morphea has Complication: Loss of hair and sweat glands.
Morphea has Complication: Eye damage.

Morton neuroma has Symptom: Pain when stretching toes.
Morton neuroma has Symptom: A clicking sensation in the forefoot.

Morton neuroma has Cause: Activities.

Morton neuroma has Risk Factor: Certain sports.
Morton neuroma has Risk Factor: Foot deformities.
Mosquito bites has Symptom: An itchy, inflamed bump that forms a few minutes after a bite
Mosquito bites has Symptom: A painful spot that looks like a hive and forms within 24 hours after a bite
Mosquito bites has Symptom: Small blisters

Mosquito bites has Cause: Mosquito bites are caused by female mosquitoes feeding on your blood. As a biting mosquito fills itself with blood, it injects saliva into your skin. The saliva triggers an immune system reaction that results in the classic itching and bump.
Mosquito bites has Risk Factor: Sweating
Mosquito bites has Risk Factor: Wearing floral scents
Mosquito bites has Risk Factor: Living in an area where mosquitoes are active
Mosquito bites has Risk Factor: Spending time outside without using mosquito repellent
Mosquito bites has Complication: Scratching bites can lead to infection.

Moyamoya disease has Symptom: Headache.
Moyamoya disease has Symptom: Seizures.
Moyamoya disease has Symptom: Weakness, numbness or paralysis in the face, arm or leg. This is typically on one side of the body.

Moyamoya disease has Symptom: Trouble speaking or understanding others, known as aphasia.

Moyamoya disease has Cause: The exact cause of moyamoya disease isn't known. Moyamoya disease is most commonly seen in Japan, Korea and China. But it also happens in other parts of the world. Because moyamoya disease is most common in these Asian countries, researchers believe this strongly suggests a genetic factor in some populations.

Moyamoya disease has Risk Factor: Although moyamoya disease is found all over the world, it's more common in East Asian countries, especially Korea, Japan and China. This may be due to certain genetic factors in those populations. People with Asian heritage living in Western countries also have a higher risk of moyamoya disease.
Moyamoya disease has Risk Factor: Family history of moyamoya disease.
Moyamoya disease has Risk Factor: Medical conditions.
Moyamoya disease has Risk Factor: Being female.
Moyamoya disease has Risk Factor: Being young.

Moyamoya disease has Complication: Most complications from moyamoya disease are linked to the effects of strokes. They include seizures, paralysis and vision problems. Other complications include speech problems, movement disorders and developmental delays. Moyamoya disease can cause serious and permanent damage to the brain.
Moyamoya disease has Preventio: There is no way to prevent moyamoya disease. However, moyamoya treatments can prevent strokes and other complications.
MRSA infection has Symptom: Staph skin infections, includingMRSA, generally start as swollen, painful red bumps that might look like pimples or spider bites. The affected area might be:

MRSA infection has Cause: Different varieties of Staphylococcus aureus bacteria, commonly called "staph," exist. Staph bacteria are normally found on the skin or in the nose of about one-third of the population. The bacteria are generally harmless unless they enter the body through a cut or other wound, and even then they usually cause only minor skin problems in healthy people.
MRSA infection has Risk Factor: Because hospital and community strains ofMRSAgenerally occur in different settings, the risk factors for the two strains differ.

MRSA infection has Complication: MRSAinfections can resist the effects of many common antibiotics, so they're more difficult to treat. This can allow the infections to spread and sometimes become life-threatening.

MRSA infection has Preventio: In the hospital, people who are infected or colonized withMRSAoften are placed in isolation as a measure to prevent the spread ofMRSA. Visitors and health care workers caring for people in isolation may need to wear protective garments.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1) has Cause: Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1) is caused by a change in the MEN1 gene. That gene controls how the body makes a protein called menin. Menin helps to keep cells in the body from growing and dividing too quickly.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1) has Risk Factor: Children with a parent who has a genetic change in the MEN1 gene are at risk of the MEN 1 condition. That's because these children have a 50% chance of having the same genetic change that causes MEN 1.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1) has Risk Factor: Parents and siblings of people who have a change in the MEN1 gene also are at risk. That's because they may have the same genetic change, even if they haven't had any symptoms of MEN 1.
Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2) has Symptom: Lumps in the throat or neck
Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2) has Symptom: Trouble breathing or swallowing
Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2) has Symptom: Hoarseness
Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2) has Symptom: Diarrhea
Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2) has Cause: MEN 2is an inherited condition. This means someone who has a changed gene that can causeMEN 2can pass that gene on to their children.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2) has Complication: MEN 2can cause the parathyroid glands to put too much calcium into the blood. This is known as primary hyperparathyroidism. The parathyroid glands are located in your neck. The extra calcium in the blood can cause many issues, including weak bones, called osteoporosis, kidney stones and having to urinate a lot. Medullary thyroid cancer shows up as a lump on the thyroid or neck. It can be hard to swallow when the tumor is large or other symptoms if the cancer spreads outside the neck.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2) has Preventio: Genetic testing is used to find out if someone has a changed gene that causesMEN 2. Children of someone who has this changed gene could inherit it and developMEN 2. Parents and siblings also could have the changed gene even if they don't have symptoms.

Multiple sclerosis has Cause: The cause of multiple sclerosis is not known. It's considered an immune-mediated disease in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues. In MS, the immune system attacks and destroys the fatty substance that coats and protects nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord. This fatty substance is called myelin.

Multiple sclerosis has Complication: Trouble with bladder, bowel or sexual function.
Multiple sclerosis has Complication: Trouble with thinking and memory.
Multiple system atrophy has Symptom: Multiple system atrophy (MSA) symptoms affect many parts of the body. Symptoms start in adulthood, usually in the 50s or 60s.

Multiple system atrophy has Cause: There is no known cause for multiple system atrophy (MSA). Some researchers are studying the possible role of genetics or environmental causes such as a toxin in MSA. But there's no substantial evidence to support these theories.

Multiple system atrophy has Risk Factor: A risk factor for multiple system atrophy (MSA) is having rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder. People with this disorder act out their dreams. Most people who have MSA have a history of REM sleep behavior disorder.

Mumps has Symptom: Symptoms of mumps show up about 2 to 3 weeks after exposure to the virus. Some people may have no symptoms or very mild symptoms.
Mumps has Cause: Mumps is caused by a type of germ called a virus. When someone has mumps, the virus is in saliva. Coughing or sneezing can release tiny droplets with the virus into the air.
Mumps has Complication: Complications of mumps are more likely among people who aren't vaccinated. They can happen even if a person didn't have swollen salivary glands.
Mumps has Preventio: Most people who have had the mumps vaccines, called fully vaccinated, are protected from mumps infections. People who aren't vaccinated are more likely to get mumps.

Muscle cramp has Symptom: Muscle cramps occur mostly in leg muscles, most often in the calf. Cramps usually last for seconds to minutes. After the cramp eases, the area might be sore for hours or days.
Muscle cramp has Cause: Not enough blood flow.
Muscle cramp has Cause: Nerve compression.
Muscle cramp has Cause: Not enough minerals.

Muscle cramp has Risk Factor: Extreme sweating.
Muscle cramp has Risk Factor: Pregnancy.
Muscle cramp has Risk Factor: Medical issues.
Muscle cramp has Risk Factor: Weight.

Muscle cramp has Preventio: Stretch your muscles.

Muscle strains has Risk Factor: Hands.
Muscle strains has Risk Factor: Elbows.

Muscle strains has Preventio: Regular stretching and strengthening exercises for your sport, fitness or work activity, as part of an overall physical conditioning program, can help to minimize your risk of muscle strains. Try to be in shape to play your sport; don't play your sport to get in shape. If you have a physically demanding occupation, regular conditioning can help prevent injuries.

Muscular dystrophy has Risk Factor: Muscular dystrophy occurs in people of all ages and ethnic groups. But the most common type, Duchenne, usually affects young boys. People with a family history of muscular dystrophy have a higher risk of getting the disease or passing it on to their children.
Muscular dystrophy has Complication: Muscular dystrophy can lead to serious health issues, such as the following:

Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) has Risk Factor: Women are diagnosed withME/CFSmuch more often than men, but it may be that women are simply more likely to report their symptoms to a doctor.

Myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS) has Complication: Symptoms ofME/CFScan come and go, and often are triggered by physical activity or emotional stress. This can make it difficult for people to maintain a regular work schedule or to even take care of themselves at home.

Myasthenia gravis has Symptom: Symptoms of myasthenia gravis may come and go. They usually get better when the weak muscle is rested but get worse again when the muscle is used. Symptoms often progress and may be at their worst one or two years after the disease begins.

Myasthenia gravis has Cause: The exact cause of myasthenia gravis is not known. Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune condition. These conditions happen when the immune system creates antibodies that mistakenly work against or attack healthy cells or tissue. Antibodies are proteins that help fight unhealthy or foreign substances in the body, such as bacteria or viruses.
Myasthenia gravis has Risk Factor: Genetics.
Myasthenia gravis has Risk Factor: Thymus gland issues.
Myasthenia gravis has Risk Factor: Myasthenia gravis is more common in people younger than 40 who were assigned female at birth, and in people older than 60 who were assigned male at birth.
Myasthenia gravis has Risk Factor: Lifestyle and health.
Myasthenia gravis has Complication: Complications of myasthenia gravis are treatable, but some can be life-threatening.
Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) has Symptom: Inflammation of the optic nerve.
Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) has Symptom: Inflammation of the spinal cord.
Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) has Symptom: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord.

Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) has Cause: The cause ofMOGADis not known. It's an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues. In people withMOGAD, the immune system destroys the fatty substance called myelin. Myelin coats and protects nerve fibers in the optic nerve, brain and spinal cord.
Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) has Risk Factor: Children and young adults are slightly more likely to developMOGAD.
Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) has Risk Factor: Recent infection or vaccination.

Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) has Complication: Trouble with language, memory and thinking.
Myelodysplastic syndromes has Symptom: Fatigue
Myelodysplastic syndromes has Symptom: Shortness of breath
Myelodysplastic syndromes has Symptom: Unusual paleness (pallor), which occurs due to a low red blood cell count (anemia)

Myelofibrosis has Risk Factor: Exposure to benzene.

Myocardial ischemia has Symptom: Some people who have myocardial ischemia don't have any signs or symptoms (silent ischemia).

Myocardial ischemia has Cause: Myocardial ischemia occurs when the blood flow through one or more of your coronary arteries is decreased. The low blood flow decreases the amount of oxygen your heart muscle receives.
Myocardial ischemia has Risk Factor: Factors that can increase your risk of developing myocardial ischemia include:
Myocardial ischemia has Complication: Myocardial ischemia can lead to serious complications, including:

Myocardial ischemia has Preventio: The same lifestyle habits that can help treat myocardial ischemia can also help prevent it from developing in the first place. Leading a heart-healthy lifestyle can help keep your arteries strong, elastic and smooth, and allow for maximum blood flow.

Nail fungus has Symptom: Brittle, crumbly or ragged
Nail fungus has Symptom: Misshapen
Nail fungus has Symptom: Separated from the nail bed

Nail fungus has Cause: Nail fungus is caused by various fungal organisms (fungi). The most common is a type called dermatophyte. Yeast, bacteria and molds also can cause nail infections. The discoloration from a bacterial infection tends to be green or black.
Nail fungus has Risk Factor: Older age
Nail fungus has Risk Factor: Wearing shoes that make your feet sweat heavily
Nail fungus has Risk Factor: Having had athlete's foot in the past

Nail fungus has Risk Factor: Having a minor skin or nail injury
Nail fungus has Risk Factor: Having a skin condition that affects the nails, such as psoriasis

Nail fungus has Complication: A severe case of nail fungus can be painful and may cause permanent damage to your nails. And it may lead to other serious infections that spread beyond your feet if you have a suppressed immune system due to medication, diabetes or other conditions.

Nail fungus has Preventio: Keep your nails clean and dry. Wash your hands and feet regularly. Wash your hands after touching an infected nail. Dry well, apply an antifungal foot powder and moisturize your nails. Consider applying a nail hardener, which might help strengthen nails and cuticles.

Nail fungus has Preventio: Keep your nails trimmed. Cut nails straight across, smooth the edges with a file and file down thickened areas. Disinfect your nail clippers after each use. Letting your nails grow long creates more places for the fungus to grow.
Nail fungus has Preventio: Wear absorbent socks or change your socks throughout the day.
Nail fungus has Preventio: Choose shoes made of materials that breathe.
Nail fungus has Preventio: Discard old shoes or treat them with disinfectants or antifungal powders.
Nail fungus has Preventio: Wear footwear in pool areas and locker rooms.
Nail fungus has Preventio: Choose a nail salon that uses sterilized manicure tools for each customer. Or disinfect tools you use for home pedicures.
Nail fungus has Preventio: Give up nail polish and artificial nails.
Nail fungus has Preventio: If you have athlete's foot, treat it with an antifungal product.

Nasal and paranasal tumors has Cause: Nasal and paranasal tumors happen when cells in the nasal cavity or chambers around the nose develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell a cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions also tell the cells to die at a set time. In tumor cells, the changes give different instructions. The changes tell the tumor cells to make many more cells quickly. Tumor cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.

The attack occurs because altered antibodies bind to proteins in the central nervous system and cause damage.

Nickel allergy has Preventio: The best strategy to prevent nickel allergy is to avoid prolonged exposure to items containing nickel. If you already have a nickel allergy, the best way to prevent an allergic reaction is to avoid contact with the metal.

Niemann-Pick disease has Cause: Niemann-Pick disease is caused by changes in specific genes related to how the body breaks down and uses fats. These fats include cholesterol and lipids. The gene changes are passed from parents to children in a pattern called autosomal recessive inheritance. This means that both the mother and the father must pass on a changed gene for the child to have the condition.

Niemann-Pick disease has Risk Factor: Risk factors for Niemann-Pick disease depend on the type. The condition is caused by changes in genes that are passed down in families. Although the condition can occur in any population, type A occurs more often in people of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Type B occurs more often in people of North African descent. Type C occurs in many different populations, but it occurs more often in people of Acadian and Bedouin descent.

Norovirus infection has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of norovirus infection may start suddenly and include:

Norovirus infection has Cause: Noroviruses are highly contagious. That means the norovirus infection can easily spread to others. The virus is shed in stool and vomit. You can spread the virus from the time you first have symptoms of illness until several days after you recover. Noroviruses can stay on surfaces and objects for days or weeks.
Norovirus infection has Risk Factor: Risk factors for becoming infected with a norovirus include:

Norovirus infection has Complication: For most people, norovirus infection usually clears up within a few days and isn't life-threatening. But in some people — especially young children; older adults; and people with weakened immune systems or other medical conditions or who are pregnant — norovirus infection can be severe. Norovirus infection can cause severe dehydration and even death.
Norovirus infection has Preventio: Norovirus infection is highly contagious. There are many types of noroviruses. Anyone can get norovirus infection more than once.

Obesity has Symptom: Body mass index, known as BMI, is often used to diagnose obesity. To calculateBMI, multiply weight in pounds by 703, divide by height in inches and then divide again by height in inches. Or divide weight in kilograms by height in meters squared. There are several online calculators available that help calculateBMI.

Obesity has Cause: Although there are genetic, behavioral, metabolic and hormonal influences on body weight, obesity occurs when you take in more calories than you burn through typical daily activities and exercise. Your body stores these excess calories as fat.
Obesity has Risk Factor: Obesity often results from a combination of causes and contributing factors:

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) has Symptom: Obsessive-compulsive disorder usually includes both obsessions and compulsions. But it's also possible to have only obsession symptoms or only compulsion symptoms. You may or may not know that your obsessions and compulsions are beyond reason. But they take up a great deal of time, reduce your quality of life, and get in the way of your daily routines and responsibilities.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) has Complication: Poor quality of life.
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) has Complication: Thoughts about suicide and behavior related to suicide.

Obstructive sleep apnea has Symptom: Loud snoring.

Obstructive sleep apnea has Risk Factor: The risk of obstructive sleep apnea increases as you age but appears to level off after your 60s and 70s.

Skin rosacea affects more women than men, and ocular rosacea affects men and women equally. It's also more common in fair-skinned people of Celtic and Northern European origin.

Corneal complications can lead to visual symptoms. Inflammation of your eyelids (blepharitis) can cause secondary irritation of the cornea from misdirected eyelashes or other complications. Ultimately, corneal complications can lead to vision loss.

Some factors may raise your risk of getting oral lichen planus, such as having a condition that lowers your immunity or taking certain medicines. But more research is needed.

Oral thrush has Cause: A healthy immune system works to get rid of harmful invading organisms, such as viruses, bacteria and fungi. This maintains a balance between "good" and "bad" microbes in your body. But sometimes these protective measures fail. Then candida fungus grows and allows an oral thrush infection to take hold.
Oral thrush has Risk Factor: Weakened immunity.
Oral thrush has Risk Factor: Diabetes.
Oral thrush has Risk Factor: Vaginal yeast infections.
Oral thrush has Risk Factor: Medicines.

But for people with lowered immunity, such as from cancer treatment orHIV/AIDS, thrush can be more serious. Oral thrush that isn't treated can lead to more-serious systemic candida infections. If you have a weakened immune system, thrush may spread to your esophagus or other parts of your body.

Oral thrush has Preventio: Treat dry mouth.

Orthostatic hypotension (postural hypotension) has Cause: When standing from a sitting or lying position, gravity causes blood to collect in the legs and belly. Blood pressure drops because there's less blood flowing back to the heart.
Orthostatic hypotension (postural hypotension) has Risk Factor: The risk factors for orthostatic hypotension include:

Osteoarthritis has Cause: Osteoarthritis happens when the cartilage that cushions the ends of bones in the joints gradually wears away. Cartilage is a firm, slippery tissue that allows nearly frictionless joint motion.
Osteoarthritis has Risk Factor: Factors that can increase your risk of osteoarthritis include:
Osteoarthritis has Complication: Osteoarthritis is a disease that worsens over time, often resulting in chronic pain. Joint pain and stiffness can become severe enough to make daily tasks difficult.

Osteochondritis dissecans has Symptom: Swelling and tenderness.
Osteochondritis dissecans has Symptom: Joint popping or locking.
Osteochondritis dissecans has Symptom: Joint weakness.

Osteochondritis dissecans has Cause: The cause of osteochondritis dissecans is unknown. The reduced blood flow to the end of the affected bone might result from repetitive trauma — small, multiple episodes of minor, unrecognized injury that damage the bone. There might be a genetic component, making some people more inclined to develop the disorder.
Osteochondritis dissecans has Risk Factor: Osteochondritis dissecans occurs most commonly in children and adolescents between the ages of 10 and 20 who are highly active in sports.
Osteochondritis dissecans has Complication: Osteochondritis dissecans can increase your risk of eventually developing osteoarthritis in that joint.

Osteochondritis dissecans has Preventio: Adolescents participating in organized sports might benefit from education on the risks to their joints associated with overuse. Learning the proper mechanics and techniques of their sport, using the proper protective gear, and participating in strength training and stability training exercises can help reduce the chance of injury.

Osteoporosis has Symptom: Back pain caused by a broken or collapsed bone in the spine.

Osteoporosis has Symptom: A stooped posture.
Osteoporosis has Symptom: A bone that breaks much more easily than expected.

Osteoporosis has Cause: Your bones are in a constant state of renewal — new bone is made and old bone is broken down. When you're young, your body makes new bone faster than it breaks down old bone and your bone mass increases. After the early 20s this process slows, and most people reach their peak bone mass by age 30. As people age, bone mass is lost faster than it's created.

Osteoporosis has Risk Factor: A number of factors can increase the likelihood that you'll develop osteoporosis. Risk factors include your age, race, lifestyle choices, and medical conditions and treatments.

Osteoporosis has Complication: Bone breaks, particularly in the spine or hip, are the most serious complications of osteoporosis. Hip fractures often are caused by a fall. A hip fracture can result in disability and even an increased risk of death within the first year after the injury.
Osteoporosis has Preventio: Good nutrition and regular exercise are essential for keeping your bones healthy throughout your life.
Osteosarcoma has Symptom: Bone or joint pain. Pain might come and go at first. It can be mistaken for growing pains.

Osteosarcoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma has Risk Factor: Other bone conditions. These include Paget's disease of bone and fibrous dysplasia.
Osteosarcoma has Risk Factor: Prior treatment with radiation therapy or chemotherapy.

Ovarian cysts has Preventio: There's no way to prevent most ovarian cysts. But, regular pelvic exams help ensure that changes in your ovaries are diagnosed as early as possible. Talk to your health care provider about changes that concern you.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome has Cause: The cause of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome isn't fully understood. Having a high level of human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) — a hormone usually produced during pregnancy — introduced into your system plays a role. Ovarian blood vessels react abnormally to human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) and begin to leak fluid. This fluid swells the ovaries, and sometimes large amounts move into the abdomen.
Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome has Risk Factor: Sometimes,OHSShappens in women with no risk factors at all. But factors that are known to increase your risk ofOHSSinclude:
Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome has Complication: Severe ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is uncommon, but can be life-threatening. Complications may include:

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome has Preventio: To decrease your chances of developing ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, you'll need an individualized plan for your fertility medications. Expect your health care provider to carefully monitor each treatment cycle, including frequent ultrasounds to check the development of follicles and blood tests to check your hormone levels.

Overactive bladder has Symptom: Lose urine without meaning to after an urgent need to urinate, called urgency incontinence.

Overactive bladder has Symptom: Wake up more than twice a night to urinate, called nocturia.

Overactive bladder has Complication: Anxiety.
Overactive bladder has Complication: Emotional distress or depression.
Overactive bladder has Complication: Sexual problems.
Overactive bladder has Complication: Sleep disturbances and interrupted sleep cycles.

Another theory is that Paget's disease of the breast starts in the nipple.
Paget's disease of the breast has Risk Factor: Paget's disease of the breast is a form of breast cancer. Factors that may increase the risk of breast cancer include:

Pancreatic cancer has Symptom: New diagnosis of diabetes or diabetes that's getting harder to control.
Pancreatic cancer has Symptom: Pain and swelling in an arm or leg, which might be caused by a blood clot.
Pancreatic cancer has Symptom: Tiredness or weakness.

Pancreatic cancer has Cause: It's not clear what causes pancreatic cancer. Doctors have found some factors that might raise the risk of this type of cancer. These include smoking and having a family history of pancreatic cancer.

Pancreatic cancer has Risk Factor: Type 2 diabetes.

Pancreatic cysts has Cause: The cause of most pancreatic cysts is unknown. Some cysts are associated with rare illnesses, including polycystic kidney disease or von Hippel-Lindau disease, a genetic disorder that can affect the pancreas and other organs.

Pancreatic cysts has Risk Factor: Heavy alcohol use and gallstones are risk factors for pancreatitis, and pancreatitis is a risk factor for pseudocysts. Abdominal injury also is a risk factor for pseudocysts.

Pancreatic cysts has Preventio: The best way to avoid pseudocysts is to avoid pancreatitis, which is usually caused by gallstones or heavy alcohol use. If gallstones are triggering pancreatitis, you may need to have your gallbladder removed. If your pancreatitis is due to alcohol use, not drinking can reduce your risk.

Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors has Cause: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors happen when cells in the pancreas develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell the cell what to do. The changes, which doctors call mutations, tell the cells to multiply quickly. The changes let the cells continue living when healthy cells would die as part of their natural life cycle. This causes many extra cells. The cells might form a mass called a tumor. Sometimes the cells can break away and spread to other organs, such as the liver. When cancer spreads, it's called metastatic cancer.

Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors has Risk Factor: Syndromes present at birth that increase the risk of tumors.

Pancreatitis has Cause: Pancreas cancer.

Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system has Cause: Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system are not caused by cancer cells directly or by the cancer spreading, known as metastasis. Parkinson's disease has Cause: Genes.
Parkinson's disease has Cause: Environmental factors.

Parkinson's disease has Risk Factor: The risk of Parkinson's disease increases with age. Usually, it starts around age 50 or older. The average age of onset is around age 70. Parkinson's disease can occur in younger adults, but it is rare. When people younger than age 50 have the disease, it's known as early-onset Parkinson's disease.

Parkinson's disease has Risk Factor: Men are more likely to develop Parkinson's disease than are women.

Parotid tumors has Symptom: Pain in the face.

Parotid tumors has Cause: It's not clear what causes parotid tumors. These tumors start as a growth of cells in the parotid glands. The parotid glands are two salivary glands that sit just in front of the ears. There is one on each side of the face. Salivary glands make saliva to help with chewing and digesting food.

Parvovirus infection has Complication: A parvovirus infection can lead to other health conditions called complications. The risk of complications is higher for some people, including:
Parvovirus infection has Preventio: There's no vaccine to prevent human parvovirus infection. But you can practice healthy habits to lower the chances of getting the illness:
Patellar tendinitis has Symptom: Pain is the first symptom of patellar tendinitis. The pain most often is between the kneecap and where the tendon joins the shinbone, also called the tibia.
Patellar tendinitis has Cause: Patellar tendinitis is a common injury caused by too much use. The repeated stress on the patellar tendon results in tiny tears in the tendon.
Patellar tendinitis has Risk Factor: A mix of factors may be part of getting patellar tendinitis. They include:
Patellar tendinitis has Complication: Working through the pain can cause more and larger tears in the patellar tendon. Rarely, the tendon can rupture.
Patellar tendinitis has Preventio: To reduce your risk of developing patellar tendinitis, take these steps:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome has Preventio: Build up slowly.

During the first six weeks of pregnancy, an unborn baby's heart starts to form and beat. The major blood vessels to and from the heart grow. It's during this time that certain congenital heart defects may begin to develop.

Peanut allergy has Risk Factor: Food allergies are most common in children, especially toddlers and infants. As a person grows, the digestive system matures. Then the body is less likely to react to food that triggers allergies.

Peanut allergy has Preventio: Studies have shown a strong link between early peanut exposure and lower food allergy risk. In the studies, peanuts were introduced to high-risk babies and children from 4 months to 3 years old. By doing so, their food allergy risk was reduced up to 80%. Children at risk of peanut allergy include those with mild to severe eczema, egg allergy, or both. Before introducing your child to peanuts, discuss the best approach with your child's healthcare professional.

Pemphigus has Cause: Pemphigus is an autoimmune disorder, which means that your immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells in your body. With pemphigus the immune system attacks cells in the skin and mucous membranes.

Pemphigus has Risk Factor: The risk of pemphigus increases if you're middle-aged or older. The condition also is more common in people of Jewish, Indian, southeast European or Middle Eastern ancestry.

This is called postinflammatory hyperpigmentation when the skin darkens and postinflammatory hypopigmentation when the skin loses color. People with brown or Black skin have a higher risk of long-term skin color changes.

Pemphigus has Complication: Side effects from the medicine used to treat pemphigus. Examples are high blood pressure and infection.

Penicillin allergy has Risk Factor: While anyone can have an allergic reaction to penicillin, a few factors can increase the risk. These include:

Pericarditis has Symptom: Get worse when coughing, lying down or taking a deep breath.

Pericarditis has Cause: Injury to the heart or chest.
Pericarditis has Cause: Lupus.

Periodontitis has Cause: Plaque can cause gingivitis,

Peritonitis has Cause: Peritoneal dialysis uses tubes, also called catheters, to remove waste products from the blood. An infection may happen during peritoneal dialysis due to an unclean treatment room, poor hygiene or tainted equipment.

Persistent post-concussive symptoms (Post-concussion syndrome) has Risk Factor: Persistent post-concussive symptoms usually are reported in people ages 20 to 30. But studies also show that older adults are at risk of more serious and prolonged persistent post-concussive symptoms.

Personality disorders has Symptom: In some cases, you may not know that you have a personality disorder. That's because how you think and behave seems natural to you. You also may think others are responsible for your challenges.

Personality disorders has Cause: It's believed that personality disorders are caused by a blend of how genetics and your environment affect you. Your genes may make it more likely that you develop a personality disorder, and what happens to you in life may set a personality disorder into motion.
Personality disorders has Risk Factor: Specific personality traits.
Personality disorders has Risk Factor: Early life experiences.

Personality disorders has Complication: Personality disorders can seriously disrupt your life and the lives of those who care about you. They may cause issues in relationships, work or school. And they can lead to social isolation, other mental health issues with addictions, as well as occupational and legal issues.
Pet allergy has Symptom: Pet allergy symptoms typically include:
Pet allergy has Cause: Allergies occur when your immune system reacts to a foreign substance such as pollen, mold or pet dander.
Pet allergy has Risk Factor: Pet allergies are common. However, you're more likely to develop a pet allergy if allergies or asthma runs in your family.

Pet allergy has Complication: Pet allergy can cause ongoing swelling in your nose that may block your sinuses. These blockages may make you more likely to develop bacterial infections of the sinuses, such as sinusitis.
Pet allergy has Preventio: If you don't have a pet but are considering adopting or buying one, make sure you don't have pet allergies before making the commitment.

Peyronie's disease has Symptom: Pain in the penis.
Peyronie's disease has Symptom: Other changes in how the penis looks.
Peyronie's disease has Cause: The exact cause of Peyronie's disease isn't clear. But various factors seem to be involved.
Peyronie's disease has Risk Factor: Family history.
Peyronie's disease has Risk Factor: Connective tissue diseases.

Peyronie's disease has Risk Factor: Peyronie's disease can happen at any age. But it becomes more common between the ages of 45 and 70. Curving of the penis in younger men less often is due to Peyronie's disease. It is more commonly called congenital penile curvature. A small amount of curvature in younger men is typical and not concerning.
Peyronie's disease has Complication: Not being able to have sex.
Peyronie's disease has Complication: Trouble getting or keeping an erection, also called erectile dysfunction.
Peyronie's disease has Complication: Anxiety, stress, or depression over challenges having sex or the way your penis looks.
Peyronie's disease has Complication: Stress on your relationship with your sexual partner.
Peyronie's disease has Complication: Trouble having a child because it's challenging or not possible to have sex.
Peyronie's disease has Complication: Shorter penis length.
Peyronie's disease has Complication: Penile pain.

Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Symptom: Nervous system (neurological) problems that may include seizures
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Symptom: Skin rashes, such as eczema
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Symptom: Lighter skin, hair and eye color than family members, because phenylalanine can't transform into melanin — the pigment responsible for hair and skin tone
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Symptom: Unusually small head size (microcephaly)
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Symptom: Hyperactivity

Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Symptom: Behavioral, emotional and social problems
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Symptom: Mental health disorders

Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Cause: A gene change (genetic mutation) causesPKU, which can be mild, moderate or severe. In a person withPKU, a change in the phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) gene causes a lack of or reduced amount of the enzyme that's needed to process phenylalanine, an amino acid.
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Risk Factor: Having both parents with a gene change that causesPKU.
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Risk Factor: Being of a certain racial or ethnic descent.
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Complication: Irreversible brain damage and marked intellectual disability beginning within the first few months of life
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Complication: Neurological problems such as seizures and tremors
Phenylketonuria (PKU) has Complication: Behavioral, emotional and social problems in older children and adults

Pheochromocytoma has Symptom: Headache.
Pheochromocytoma has Symptom: Heavy sweating.
Pheochromocytoma has Symptom: Rapid heartbeat.

Pheochromocytoma has Cause: Researchers don't know exactly what causes a pheochromocytoma. The tumor forms in cells called chromaffin cells. These cells are located in the center of an adrenal gland. They release certain hormones, mainly adrenaline and noradrenaline. These hormones help control many body functions, such as heart rate, blood pressure and blood sugar.
Pheochromocytoma has Risk Factor: Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN 2).
Pheochromocytoma has Risk Factor: Von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Pheochromocytoma has Risk Factor: Neurofibromatosis 1.
Pheochromocytoma has Risk Factor: Hereditary paraganglioma syndromes.
Pheochromocytoma has Complication: Heart disease.
Pheochromocytoma has Complication: Stroke.
Pheochromocytoma has Complication: Kidney failure.
Pheochromocytoma has Complication: Vision loss.

Pilocytic astrocytoma has Symptom: Symptoms of pilocytic astrocytoma can vary depending on the tumor's size and where it's growing in the brain. These tumors grow slowly, so symptoms may develop over weeks or months and get worse over time. Many of the signs and symptoms of pilocytic astrocytoma are caused by increased pressure in the brain or by the tumor pressing on nearby structures.

Pilocytic astrocytoma has Cause: The exact cause of pilocytic astrocytomas isn't known. Most of these tumors happen without a known trigger. However, scientists have found certain factors in genes and the environment that may play a role in the growth of pilocytic astrocytoma tumors.

Pilocytic astrocytoma has Risk Factor: While experts don't know exactly what causes pilocytic astrocytoma, researchers have found some risk factors that may raise a person's chances of developing this kind of tumor:

Pilonidal cyst has Symptom: Pus or blood leaking from an opening in the skin.
Pilonidal cyst has Symptom: An odor from draining pus.

Pilonidal cyst has Cause: The cause of most pilonidal cysts is loose hairs that puncture the skin. Friction and pressure from rubbed skin, tight clothing, cycling or long periods of sitting can force hair into the skin.
Pilonidal cyst has Risk Factor: Being a young adult white male.
Pilonidal cyst has Risk Factor: Being overweight.
Pilonidal cyst has Risk Factor: Having an inactive lifestyle.
Pilonidal cyst has Risk Factor: Sitting for long periods at a time.
Pilonidal cyst has Risk Factor: Having thick, stiff body hair.

Pilonidal cyst has Complication: Some people have pilonidal cysts that become infected again and again over a long time. Without treatment, these people may be at increased risk of a type of skin cancer called squamous cell carcinoma.

Pilonidal cyst has Preventio: Achieve or maintain a healthy weight.
Pilonidal cyst has Preventio: Avoid prolonged sitting.

Pinworm infection has Symptom: Symptoms of a pinworm infection can include:

Pinworm infection has Cause: Most often, swallowing pinworm eggs causes a pinworm infection. The eggs spread through stool. This can be carried to the mouth by tainted food or drink or by unwashed fingers. Once swallowed, the eggs hatch in the small intestine. They grow into adult worms within a few weeks.
Pinworm infection has Risk Factor: Risk factors for a pinworm infection include:

Pinworm infection has Complication: Most often, pinworm infections don't cause serious problems called complications. Rarely, having many pinworms in the body can cause infection of female genitals. The worms can travel from the anal area to the vagina.
Pinworm infection has Preventio: You can take the following steps to help prevent a pinworm infection. If you've had a recent infection, these steps also can help lower the risk of another one:

Pituitary tumors has Symptom: Not all pituitary tumors cause symptoms. Sometimes these tumors are found during an imaging test, such as anMRIor aCTscan, that is done for another reason. If they don't cause symptoms, pituitary tumors usually don't need treatment.

Pituitary tumors has Cause: The pituitary gland is a small organ about the size of a pea. It's located behind the nose at the base of the brain. Despite its small size, the pituitary gland has an effect on nearly every part of the body. The hormones it makes control important body functions, such as growth, blood pressure and reproduction.
Pituitary tumors has Risk Factor: Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1, also called MEN 1.
Pituitary tumors has Risk Factor: Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 4, also called MEN 4.
Pituitary tumors has Risk Factor: Carney complex.
Pituitary tumors has Risk Factor: McCune-Albright syndrome.
Pituitary tumors has Complication: Problems with eyesight, including vision loss.
Pituitary tumors has Complication: High blood pressure.
Pituitary tumors has Complication: High blood sugar.
Pituitary tumors has Complication: Bone loss.
Pituitary tumors has Complication: Heart problems.
Pituitary tumors has Complication: Problems with thinking and memory.

Pityriasis rosea has Symptom: Pityriasis rosea typically begins with an oval, slightly raised, scaly patch — called the herald patch — on the face, back, chest or abdomen. Before the herald patch appears, some people have headache, fatigue, fever or sore throat.

Pityriasis rosea has Cause: The exact cause of pityriasis rosea is unclear. It might be triggered by an infection with a virus, particularly by certain strains of the herpes virus. But it's not related to the herpes virus that causes cold sores. Pityriasis rosea isn't contagious.

Pityriasis rosea has Risk Factor: Having family members with pityriasis rosea increases your risk of developing the condition. Taking certain medicines may increase the risk of this condition as well. Examples include terbinafine, isotretinoin, omeprazole, gold, arsenic and barbiturates.
Pityriasis rosea has Complication: Complications of pityriasis rosea aren't likely. If they do occur, they may include:
Placenta accreta has Symptom: Placenta accreta often causes no signs or symptoms during pregnancy — although vaginal bleeding during the third trimester might occur.

Placenta accreta has Cause: Placenta accreta is thought to be related to abnormalities in the lining of the uterus, typically due to scarring after a C-section or other uterine surgery. Sometimes, however, placenta accreta occurs without a history of uterine surgery.
Placenta accreta has Risk Factor: Many factors can increase the risk of placenta accreta, including:
Placenta accreta has Complication: Placenta accreta can cause:

Placenta previa has Symptom: The main sign of placenta previa is bright red vaginal bleeding, usually without pain, after 20 weeks of pregnancy. Sometimes, spotting happens before an event with more blood loss.
Placenta previa has Cause: The exact cause of placenta previa is unknown.
Placenta previa has Risk Factor: Placenta previa is more common among women who:
Placenta previa has Complication: If you have placenta previa, your health care provider will monitor you and your baby to reduce the risk of these serious complications:

Placental abruption has Symptom: Placental abruption is most likely to occur in the last trimester of pregnancy, especially in the last few weeks before birth. Signs and symptoms of placental abruption include:

Placental abruption has Cause: The cause of placental abruption is often unknown. Possible causes include trauma or injury to the abdomen — from an auto accident or fall, for example — or rapid loss of the fluid that surrounds and cushions the baby in the uterus (amniotic fluid).
Placental abruption has Risk Factor: Factors that can increase the risk of placental abruption include:
Placental abruption has Complication: Placental abruption can cause life-threatening problems for both mother and baby.

Placental abruption has Preventio: You can't prevent placental abruption, but you can decrease certain risk factors. For example, don't smoke or use illegal drugs, such as cocaine. If you have high blood pressure, work with your health care provider to monitor the condition.
Plague has Symptom: There are three types of plague. The symptoms vary for each type.
Plague has Cause: Rats, mice and voles.
Plague has Cause: Squirrels.
Plague has Cause: Rabbits.
Plague has Cause: Prairie dogs.
Plague has Cause: Ground squirrels and chipmunks.
Plague has Risk Factor: The risk of getting plague is very low. Worldwide, only a few thousand people get plague each year. In the United States, seven people on average get plague each year.
Plague has Complication: Gangrene.
Plague has Complication: Meningitis.
Plague has Complication: Pharyngeal plague.
Plague has Preventio: No vaccine is available, but scientists are working to develop one. Antibiotics can help prevent infection if you were likely exposed to plague.

Plantar fasciitis has Symptom: Plantar fasciitis typically causes a stabbing pain in the bottom of your foot near the heel. The pain is usually the worst with the first few steps after awakening, although it also can be triggered by long periods of standing or when you get up from sitting.

Plantar fasciitis has Cause: The plantar fascia is a band of tissue, called fascia, that connects your heel bone to the base of your toes. It supports the arch of the foot and absorbs shock when walking.
Plantar fasciitis has Risk Factor: Plantar fasciitis is most common in people between the ages of 40 and 60.
Plantar fasciitis has Risk Factor: Certain types of exercise.
Plantar fasciitis has Risk Factor: Foot mechanics.
Plantar fasciitis has Risk Factor: Obesity.
Plantar fasciitis has Risk Factor: Occupations that keep you on your feet.

Plantar fasciitis has Complication: Ignoring plantar fasciitis can result in chronic heel pain that hinders your regular activities. You're likely to change your walk to try to avoid plantar fasciitis pain, which might lead to foot, knee, hip or back problems.
Plantar warts has Symptom: A small, rough growth on the bottom of your foot, usually at the base of the toes or on the ball or heel
Plantar warts has Symptom: On brown and Black skin, the growth may be lighter than unaffected skin
Plantar warts has Symptom: Hard, thickened skin (callus) over a spot on the skin, where a wart has grown inward
Plantar warts has Symptom: Black pinpoints, which are small clotted blood vessels commonly called wart seeds
Plantar warts has Symptom: A cluster of growths on the sole of the foot (mosaic warts)
Plantar warts has Symptom: A growth that interrupts the normal lines and ridges in the skin of your foot
Plantar warts has Symptom: Pain or tenderness when walking or standing

Plantar warts has Cause: Plantar warts are caused by an infection with HPV in the outer layer of skin on the soles of the feet. The warts develop when the virus enters through tiny cuts, breaks or weak spots on the bottom of the foot. If left untreated, warts can last from a few months to 2 years in children, and several years in in adults.
Plantar warts has Risk Factor: Children and teenagers
Plantar warts has Risk Factor: People with weak immune systems
Plantar warts has Risk Factor: People who have had plantar warts before
Plantar warts has Risk Factor: People who walk barefoot in areas where a wart-causing virus is common, such as locker rooms and swimming pools

Plantar warts has Complication: When plantar warts cause pain, you may alter your normal posture or gait — perhaps without realizing it. Eventually, this change in how you stand, walk or run can cause muscle or joint discomfort.
Plantar warts has Preventio: Avoid direct contact with warts. This includes your own warts. Wash your hands carefully after touching a wart.
Plantar warts has Preventio: Keep your feet clean and dry.
Plantar warts has Preventio: Wear sandals or other foot protection when walking around swimming pools, in locker rooms or in gym showers.
Plantar warts has Preventio: Don't pick at or scratch warts.
Plantar warts has Preventio: When using an emery board, pumice stone or nail clipper on your warts, choose one that you don't use on your healthy skin and nails.
Pleurisy has Symptom: Chest pain that worsens when you breathe, cough or sneeze.
Pleurisy has Symptom: Shortness of breath — often from trying to limit breathing in and out.
Pleurisy has Symptom: Cough — only in some cases.
Pleurisy has Symptom: Fever — only in some cases.

Pleurisy has Cause: Bacterial infection, such as pneumonia.

Pleurisy has Cause: Autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus.
Pleurisy has Cause: Lung cancer near the pleural surface.
Pleurisy has Cause: Pulmonary embolism.
Pleurisy has Cause: Tuberculosis (TB).
Pleurisy has Cause: Rib fracture or trauma.
Pleurisy has Cause: Certain inherited diseases, such as sickle cell disease.
Pleurisy has Cause: Certain medications and recreational drugs.

Pleurisy has Risk Factor: The risk of pleurisy increases if you get certain infections, such as the flu or pneumonia. Some medical conditions, such as lupus, TB and sickle cell disease also can increase your risk. And taking certain medicines or certain recreational drugs raise the risk of pleurisy.

Plexiform neurofibroma has Symptom: Swelling or soft lumps.

Plexiform neurofibroma has Symptom: Emotional changes.

Plexiform neurofibroma has Cause: Most plexiform neurofibromas occur in people with a condition called neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). NF1 is caused by a change in the NF1 gene, which is located on chromosome 17. This gene typically helps control how cells grow. When it isn't working properly, cells that support nerves may grow too much and form tumors like plexiform neurofibromas.

Plexiform neurofibroma has Risk Factor: Plexiform neurofibromas are linked to a genetic condition called neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Anyone with NF1 has a risk of developing these tumors. The number, size and location of tumors can vary from person to person.
Plexiform neurofibroma has Preventio: There is no known way to prevent plexiform neurofibromas. The tumors develop because of a genetic change that is present from birth and cannot be reversed.

Pneumonia has Symptom: Fatigue
Pneumonia has Symptom: Fever, sweating and shaking chills
Pneumonia has Symptom: Lower than normal body temperature (in adults older than age 65 and people with weak immune systems)

Pneumonitis has Symptom: Joint and muscle pain.
Pneumonitis has Symptom: Headache.
Pneumonitis has Symptom: Weight loss.

Pneumonitis has Cause: Pneumonitis happens when an irritating substance causes inflammation in the tiny air sacs called alveoli in your lungs. Inflamed lung tissue makes it hard for oxygen to pass through the alveoli into the bloodstream.
Pneumonitis has Risk Factor: Some factors cause a higher risk of pneumonitis, including:

Pneumothorax has Symptom: The main symptoms of a pneumothorax are sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. Severity of symptoms may depend on how much of the lung is collapsed.

Polycythemia vera has Symptom: Many people with polycythemia vera don't notice symptoms. Some people get symptoms such as headache, dizziness, tiredness and blurred vision.

Polycythemia vera has Cause: Polycythemia vera happens when a change in a gene causes a problem with making blood cells. The body typically controls the number of each of the three types of blood cells. These are red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets. But in polycythemia vera, the bone marrow makes too many of some of these blood cells.
Polycythemia vera has Risk Factor: Polycythemia vera can happen at any age. But it's more common in adults over age 60. Men are more likely to get polycythemia vera than women are.

Polyhydramnios has Cause: A decreased amount of red blood cells in the baby, also called fetal anemia.
Polyhydramnios has Cause: A condition in which the pregnant parent's blood cells attack the baby's blood cells.

A condition that affects the developing baby, such as a problem with the digestive tract, central nervous system or other organs, may also put you at risk of polyhydramnios.

Polymyositis has Symptom: The muscle weakness associated with polymyositis involves the muscles closest to the trunk, such as those in your hips, thighs, shoulders, upper arms and neck. The weakness affects both the left and right sides of your body, and tends to gradually worsen.

Polymyositis has Cause: The exact cause of polymyositis is unknown, but the disease shares many characteristics with autoimmune disorders, in which your immune system mistakenly attacks your own body tissues.

Popliteal artery entrapment syndrome has Risk Factor: The condition is most often seen in people who are in their late teens or 20s. It's rarely diagnosed in those over age 40.

Porphyria has Symptom: Symptoms can vary widely by type of porphyria and in how severe the symptoms are. Symptoms also can vary among people with the condition. Some people with a gene change that causes porphyria never have any symptoms.

Porphyria has Cause: All types of porphyria involve a problem making heme. Heme is a part of hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen from the lungs to all parts of the body. Heme also plays a role in clearing drugs and hormones from the body.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Exposure to sunlight.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Certain medicines, for example, birth control pills, sedatives and barbiturates.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Recreational or illicit drugs.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Dieting or fasting.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Physical stress, such as infections or other illnesses or surgery.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Emotional stress.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Alcohol use.
Porphyria has Risk Factor: Hormone changes during the menstrual period.
Porphyria has Complication: Acute porphyrias
Porphyria has Complication: Cutaneous porphyrias
Porphyria has Preventio: Although there's no way to prevent porphyria, if you have the condition, avoid triggers to help prevent symptoms.
