Posterior cortical atrophy has Symptom: Identifying left from right.

Posterior cortical atrophy has Cause: The most common cause of posterior cortical atrophy is a form of Alzheimer's disease that's not typical. It affects the back of the brain. Other less common causes include corticobasal degeneration, Lewy body dementia and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Researchers are looking at potential gene variations that may be related to the condition.
Posterior cortical atrophy has Risk Factor: Further study is needed to determine whether the risk factors for Alzheimer's disease may play a role in posterior cortical atrophy.

Postherpetic neuralgia has Symptom: Not being able to stand light touch.
Postherpetic neuralgia has Symptom: Itching or loss of feeling.

Postherpetic neuralgia has Cause: The chickenpox virus causes shingles. Once you've had chickenpox, the virus stays in your body for the rest of your life. The virus can become active again and cause shingles. This risk goes up with age. The risk also rises if something turns down the body's immune system, such as chemotherapy medicines to treat cancer.
Postherpetic neuralgia has Risk Factor: You're older than 60.
Postherpetic neuralgia has Risk Factor: How bad the case of shingles was.

Postherpetic neuralgia has Risk Factor: No shingles vaccine.
Postherpetic neuralgia has Complication: Depression.

Postherpetic neuralgia has Complication: Tiredness
Postherpetic neuralgia has Complication: Not feeling as hungry as usual.
Postherpetic neuralgia has Preventio: Shingles vaccines can help prevent shingles and postherpetic neuralgia. Ask your health care provider when you should get a vaccine.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Symptom: Post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms may start within the first three months after a traumatic event. But sometimes symptoms may not appear until years after the event. These symptoms last more than one month and cause major problems in social or work situations and how well you get along with others. They also can affect your ability to do your usual daily tasks.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Cause: Extremely stressful experiences, as well as the amount and severity of trauma you've gone through in your life.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Cause: Inherited mental health risks, such as a family history of anxiety and depression.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Cause: Inherited features of your personality — often called your temperament.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Risk Factor: Were physically injured during the traumatic event.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Risk Factor: Have other mental health problems, such as anxiety or depression.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Risk Factor: Drink too much or misuse drugs.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Risk Factor: Do not have a good support system of family and friends.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Complication: Depression and anxiety disorders.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Complication: Issues with drugs or alcohol use.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) has Complication: Thinking about and attempting suicide.

Pouchitis has Symptom: Symptoms of pouchitis can include diarrhea, belly pain, joint pain, cramps and fever. Other symptoms include passing stool more often, stool leakage at night, trouble controlling stool passage and a strong urge to pass stool.
Pouchitis has Cause: The cause of pouchitis is unknown. The condition appears to be due to an interaction between bacteria in the pouch and an underlying issue with the immune system.

Prader-Willi syndrome has Cause: Paternal genes on chromosome 15 are missing.
Prader-Willi syndrome has Cause: The child inherited two copies of chromosome 15 from the mother and no chromosome 15 from the father.
Prader-Willi syndrome has Cause: There's some change in paternal genes on chromosome 15.

Prader-Willi syndrome has Risk Factor: A child with an error in one or more genes in chromosome 15 is at the highest risk of getting Prader-Willi syndrome. For example, one of the genes might be missing. This error may or may not be inherited.

As a result, they need fewer calories, and they may not be physically active. These factors make them prone to obesity and the medical problems related to obesity, such as:

Preeclampsia has Symptom: The defining feature of preeclampsia is high blood pressure, proteinuria, or other signs of damage to the kidneys or other organs. You may have no noticeable symptoms. The first signs of preeclampsia are often detected during routine prenatal visits with a health care provider.

Preeclampsia has Cause: The exact cause of preeclampsia likely involves several factors. Experts believe it begins in the placenta — the organ that nourishes the fetus throughout pregnancy. Early in a pregnancy, new blood vessels develop and evolve to supply oxygen and nutrients to the placenta.
Preeclampsia has Risk Factor: Conditions that are linked to a higher risk of preeclampsia include:
Preeclampsia has Complication: Complications of preeclampsia may include:

Preeclampsia has Preventio: The best clinical evidence for prevention of preeclampsia is the use of low-dose aspirin. Your primary care provider may recommend taking an 81-milligram aspirin tablet daily after 12 weeks of pregnancy if you have one high-risk factor for preeclampsia or more than one moderate-risk factor.

Premature birth has Risk Factor: A previous premature birth.

Priapism has Symptom: Priapism symptoms vary depending on the type of priapism. The two main types of priapism are ischemic priapism and nonischemic priapism.

Priapism has Cause: An erection normally occurs in response to physical or psychological stimulation. This stimulation causes certain smooth muscles to relax, increasing blood flow to spongy tissues in the penis. As a result, the blood-filled penis becomes erect. After stimulation ends, the blood flows out and the penis returns to its nonrigid (flaccid) state.

Priapism has Complication: Ischemic priapism can cause serious complications. The blood trapped in the penis is deprived of oxygen. When an erection lasts for too long — usually more than four hours — this lack of oxygen can begin to damage or destroy tissues in the penis. Untreated priapism can cause erectile dysfunction.

Primary biliary cholangitis has Symptom: Fatigue.
Primary biliary cholangitis has Symptom: Itchy skin.

Primary biliary cholangitis has Cause: It's not clear what causes primary biliary cholangitis. Many experts consider it an autoimmune disease in which the body turns against its own cells. Researchers believe this autoimmune response may be triggered by environmental and genetic factors.
Primary biliary cholangitis has Risk Factor: Most people with primary biliary cholangitis are women.
Primary biliary cholangitis has Risk Factor: It's most likely to occur in people 30 to 60 years old.
Primary biliary cholangitis has Risk Factor: Genetics.
Primary biliary cholangitis has Risk Factor: Geography.

Primary biliary cholangitis has Complication: Increased risk of other disease.

Primary immunodeficiency has Symptom: One of the most common signs of primary immunodeficiency is having infections that are more frequent, longer lasting or harder to treat than are the infections of someone with a typical immune system. You also may get infections that a person with a healthy immune system likely wouldn't get. These are called opportunistic infections.

Primary immunodeficiency has Cause: Many primary immunodeficiency disorders are inherited — passed down from one or both parents. Problems in the genetic code that acts as a blueprint for producing the cells of the body (DNA) cause many of these immune system defects.

Primary immunodeficiency has Risk Factor: The only known risk factor for primary immune deficiency disorder is having a family history of the condition. This increases the risk of having the condition.
Primary immunodeficiency has Complication: Complications caused by a primary immunodeficiency disorder vary depending on what type you have. They can include:

Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: Stiffness, weakness and muscle spasms in the legs. This is known as spasticity. Rarely, spasticity starts in only one leg and moves to the arms, hands, tongue and jaw.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: Slowed movement.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: Tripping, being clumsy and having trouble with balance.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: Hand clumsiness.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: A hoarse voice, as well as slowed, slurred speech and drooling.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: Trouble chewing and swallowing.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: Sometimes, frequent, rapid and intense shifts in emotions.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Symptom: Rarely, breathing problems and bladder problems late in the disease.

Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Cause: In primary lateral sclerosis, the nerve cells in the brain that control movement slowly break down and stop working. These nerve cells are called upper motor neurons.
Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Risk Factor: There are no established environmental risk factors for primary lateral sclerosis.

Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) has Complication: It can take as long as 20 years for primary lateral sclerosis to progress and become worse. Symptoms vary from person to person. Some people continue to walk, but others eventually need to use wheelchairs or other assistive devices.

Primary ovarian insufficiency has Symptom: Trouble getting pregnant.

Primary ovarian insufficiency has Cause: Unknown factors.

Primary progressive aphasia has Symptom: Primary progressive aphasia symptoms vary based on which part of the brain's language areas are involved. The condition has three types. Each type causes different symptoms. Symptoms develop over time and gradually get worse.

Primary progressive aphasia has Cause: Primary progressive aphasia is caused by a shrinking of certain areas of the brain, known as lobes. In primary progressive aphasia, the frontal, temporal or parietal lobes are affected. When areas of the brain shrink, it's called atrophy. The atrophy caused by primary progressive aphasia mainly happens on the left side of the brain. The areas affected are responsible for speech and language.
Primary progressive aphasia has Risk Factor: Learning disabilities.
Primary progressive aphasia has Risk Factor: Certain gene changes.

Primary progressive aphasia has Complication: People with primary progressive aphasia eventually lose the ability to speak and write. This may take anywhere from 3 to 15 years. People with the condition also have trouble understanding written and spoken language.

Progeria has Symptom: Slowed growth and poor weight gain, with below-average height and weight.
Progeria has Symptom: Lack of fat that's stored just beneath the skin.
Progeria has Symptom: Head that is large compared with the face.
Progeria has Symptom: Small jaw, chin and mouth and thin lips.
Progeria has Symptom: Thin, curved nose with a slight hook at the end, which may look like a bird's beak.
Progeria has Symptom: Large eyes and eyelids that don't close completely.
Progeria has Symptom: Hair loss, including eyelashes and eyebrows.
Progeria has Symptom: Thin, spotty and wrinkled skin.
Progeria has Symptom: Veins easily seen through the skin.
Progeria has Symptom: High-pitched voice.
Progeria has Symptom: Premature aging.

Progeria has Cause: A change in one gene causes progeria. This gene, known as lamin A (LMNA), makes a protein that's needed to hold the center of a cell, called the nucleus, together. When theLMNAgene has a change, a flawed lamin A protein called progerin is made. Progerin makes cells unstable and appears to lead to progeria's aging process.

Progeria has Risk Factor: There are no known factors, such as lifestyle or environmental issues, that increase the risk of having progeria or giving birth to a child with progeria. But the age of the father has been described as a possible risk factor. Progeria is extremely rare. If you've had one child with progeria, the chances of having a second child with progeria are slightly higher than the general population but are still low.
Progeria has Complication: Problems with blood vessels that supply the heart, resulting in heart attack and congestive heart failure.
Progeria has Complication: Problems with blood vessels that supply the brain, resulting in stroke.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Symptom: A loss of balance while walking.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Symptom: An inability to aim your eyes properly.

Progressive supranuclear palsy has Cause: The cause of progressive supranuclear palsy isn't known. Its symptoms result from the damage of cells in areas of the brain, especially areas that help you control body movements and thinking.

Progressive supranuclear palsy has Risk Factor: The only proven risk factor for progressive supranuclear palsy is age. The condition typically affects people in their late 60s and 70s. It's virtually unknown in people under the age of 40.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Complication: Falling, which could lead to head injuries, fractures and other injuries.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Complication: Trouble focusing your eyes, which also can lead to injuries.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Complication: Trouble sleeping, which can lead to feeling tired and excessive daytime sleeping.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Complication: Not being able to look at bright lights.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Complication: Trouble swallowing, which can lead to choking or inhaling food or liquid into the airway, known as aspiration.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Complication: Pneumonia, which can be caused by aspiration. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death in people with progressive supranuclear palsy.
Progressive supranuclear palsy has Complication: Impulsive behaviors. For example, standing up without waiting for assistance, which can lead to falls.

Prostatitis has Symptom: Trouble urinating, such as dribbling or trouble starting a stream of urine or keeping it going.

Prostatitis has Symptom: Urgent need to urinate.
Prostatitis has Symptom: Cloudy urine.

Prostatitis has Symptom: Painful ejaculation.

Prostatitis has Cause: Acute bacterial prostatitis.
Prostatitis has Cause: Chronic bacterial prostatitis.
Prostatitis has Cause: Chronic prostatitis, also called chronic pelvic pain syndrome.
Prostatitis has Cause: Asymptomatic inflammatory prostatitis.
Prostatitis has Risk Factor: Young or middle adulthood.
Prostatitis has Risk Factor: Earlier prostatitis.
Prostatitis has Risk Factor: Infection of the urinary or reproductive system.
Prostatitis has Risk Factor: HIV infection or AIDS.
Prostatitis has Risk Factor: Use of a tube put into the urethra to drain the bladder, called a urinary catheter.
Prostatitis has Risk Factor: Having a sample of prostate tissue taken for study in a lab, called a biopsy.
Prostatitis has Complication: Bacterial infection of the blood, called bacteremia.
Prostatitis has Complication: Irritation of the coiled tube attached to the back of the testicle, called epididymitis.
Prostatitis has Complication: Pus-filled cavity in the prostate, called a prostatic abscess.
Prostatitis has Complication: Infection that spreads to the upper pelvic bone or lower spine.

Pseudobulbar affect has Symptom: The primary sign of pseudobulbar affect (PBA) is frequent, involuntary and uncontrollable outbursts of crying or laughing that are exaggerated or not connected to your emotional state. Laughter often turns to tears. Your mood will appear normal between episodes, which can occur at any time. Crying appears to be a more common sign of PBA than laughing.
Pseudobulbar affect has Cause: Stroke
Pseudobulbar affect has Cause: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
Pseudobulbar affect has Cause: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
Pseudobulbar affect has Cause: Traumatic brain injury
Pseudobulbar affect has Cause: Alzheimer's disease
Pseudobulbar affect has Cause: Parkinson's disease

Pseudobulbar affect has Complication: Severe symptoms of pseudobulbar affect (PBA) can cause embarrassment, social isolation, anxiety and depression. The condition might interfere with your ability to work and do daily tasks, especially when you're already coping with a neurological condition.

Pseudocholinesterase deficiency has Symptom: For most people with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, no signs or symptoms of the condition occur until you get the muscle relaxant succinylcholine. This medication is used as part of anesthesia.

Pseudocholinesterase deficiency has Cause: If you have pseudocholinesterase deficiency, your body has no pseudocholinesterase or an amount that's too low. This enzyme is needed to break down (metabolize) drugs known as choline esters. Succinylcholine is used as part of anesthesia to relax the muscles during medical procedures.
Pseudocholinesterase deficiency has Risk Factor: Your risk of having pseudocholinesterase deficiency is higher if you or a first-degree relative, such as a parent, child or sibling, has:

Pseudocholinesterase deficiency has Preventio: If you have a family history of pseudocholinesterase deficiency or have a family member who had any problem with anesthesia, tell your health care provider before getting a medical procedure that requires anesthesia.
Pseudogout has Symptom: Swollen
Pseudogout has Symptom: Warm
Pseudogout has Symptom: Severely painful

Pseudogout has Cause: Pseudogout has been linked to the presence of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals within the affected joint. These crystals become more numerous as people age, appearing in nearly half the population older than age 85. But most people who have these crystal deposits never develop pseudogout. It's not clear why some people have symptoms and others don't.
Pseudogout has Risk Factor: The risk of developing pseudogout increases with age.
Pseudogout has Risk Factor: Joint trauma.
Pseudogout has Risk Factor: Genetic disorder.
Pseudogout has Risk Factor: Mineral imbalances.
Pseudogout has Risk Factor: Other medical conditions.
Pseudogout has Complication: The crystal deposits associated with pseudogout can also cause joint damage, which can mimic the signs and symptoms of osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
Pseudomembranous colitis has Symptom: Symptoms of pseudomembranous colitis may include:

Pseudomembranous colitis has Cause: The most common cause of pseudomembranous colitis is the bacterium Clostridioides difficile, also called C. diff. In some cases, a C. diff infection is mild to moderate. Pseudomembranous colitis is a sign of more serious disease.
Pseudomembranous colitis has Risk Factor: Factors that may increase the risk of pseudomembranous colitis include:

Pseudomembranous colitis has Complication: Treatment of pseudomembranous colitis is usually successful. However, even with prompt diagnosis and treatment, pseudomembranous colitis can be life-threatening. Possible complications include:

Pseudomembranous colitis has Preventio: To help prevent the spread of C. difficile, hospitals and other healthcare facilities follow strict infection-control guidelines. If you have a friend or family member in a hospital or nursing home, follow hygiene guidelines and ask questions if you see someone not following guidelines.
Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension) has Symptom: Pseudotumor cerebri signs and symptoms might include:

Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension) has Cause: The cause of pseudotumor cerebri is unknown. If a cause is determined, the condition is called secondary intracranial hypertension, rather than idiopathic.

Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension) has Complication: For some people with pseudotumor cerebri, their vision continues to worsen, leading to blindness.
Psoriasis has Symptom: A patchy rash that varies widely in how it looks from person to person, ranging from spots of dandruff-like scaling to major eruptions over much of the body
Psoriasis has Symptom: Rashes that vary in color, tending to be shades of purple with gray scale on brown or Black skin and pink or red with silver scale on white skin
Psoriasis has Symptom: Small scaling spots (commonly seen in children)
Psoriasis has Symptom: Dry, cracked skin that may bleed
Psoriasis has Symptom: Itching, burning or soreness
Psoriasis has Symptom: Cyclic rashes that flare for a few weeks or months and then subside

Psoriasis has Cause: Psoriasis is thought to be an immune system problem that causes skin cells to grow faster than usual. In the most common type of psoriasis, known as plaque psoriasis, this rapid turnover of cells results in dry, scaly patches.
Psoriasis has Risk Factor: Family history.
Psoriasis has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Psoriasis has Complication: Psoriatic arthritis, which causes pain, stiffness, and swelling in and around the joints
Psoriasis has Complication: Temporary skin color changes (post-inflammatory hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation) where plaques have healed
Psoriasis has Complication: Eye conditions, such as conjunctivitis, blepharitis and uveitis
Psoriasis has Complication: Obesity
Psoriasis has Complication: Type 2 diabetes
Psoriasis has Complication: High blood pressure
Psoriasis has Complication: Cardiovascular disease
Psoriasis has Complication: Other autoimmune diseases, such as celiac disease, sclerosis and the inflammatory bowel disease called Crohn's disease

Psoriatic arthritis has Symptom: Psoriatic arthritis and psoriasis are long-term conditions that can get worse over time. But symptoms also can come and go. You may have flare-ups where symptoms get worse. And you may have periods of relief when symptoms improve or go away for a while.

Psoriatic arthritis has Cause: Psoriatic arthritis happens when the immune system attacks healthy joints and skin by mistake. The immune system is the part of the body that fights illness, but in psoriatic arthritis it attacks healthy tissue. This causes swelling in the joints and makes the body make too many skin cells.
Psoriatic arthritis has Risk Factor: Some things make it more likely that you will develop psoriatic arthritis, including:

Psoriatic arthritis has Complication: In rare cases, psoriatic arthritis can lead to a serious condition called arthritis mutilans. This form of the disease causes severe pain and damage to the small bones in the hands, especially the fingers. Over time, it can change the shape of the fingers and make it hard to use the hands for everyday tasks.
Pubic lice (crabs) has Symptom: If you have pubic lice (crabs), you may experience intense itching in your genital region. Pubic lice can spread to other areas with coarse body hair, including the:
Pubic lice (crabs) has Cause: Pubic lice are most commonly spread during sexual activity. You may also get pubic lice from infested sheets, blankets, towels or clothes.
Pubic lice (crabs) has Risk Factor: People who have other sexually transmitted infections are more likely to also have pubic lice.
Pubic lice (crabs) has Complication: Pubic lice infestations can usually be treated with a louse-killing lotion or gel. However, a pubic lice infestation sometimes leads to complications such as:

Pubic lice (crabs) has Preventio: To prevent pubic lice infestation, avoid having sexual contact or sharing bedding or clothing with anyone who has an infestation. If you are being treated for pubic lice, all sexual partners also must be treated.
Pulmonary atresia has Symptom: Blue or gray skin, lips or fingernails due to low oxygen levels. Depending on the skin color, these changes may be harder or easier to see.
Pulmonary atresia has Symptom: Fast breathing or shortness of breath.
Pulmonary atresia has Symptom: Tiring easily.
Pulmonary atresia has Symptom: Not feeding well.

Pulmonary atresia has Cause: The cause of pulmonary atresia is not clear. During the first six weeks of pregnancy, the baby's heart begins to form and starts beating. The major blood vessels that run to and from the heart also begin to develop during this critical time. It's at this point in a baby's development that a congenital heart defect such as pulmonary atresia may begin to develop.
Pulmonary atresia has Risk Factor: Obesity.
Pulmonary atresia has Risk Factor: Alcohol or tobacco use.
Pulmonary atresia has Risk Factor: Diabetes.
Pulmonary atresia has Risk Factor: Use of some types of medicines during pregnancy, such as certain acne and blood pressure medicines.
Pulmonary atresia has Complication: Bacterial infection of the inner lining of the heart and valves, called infectious endocarditis.
Pulmonary atresia has Complication: Irregular heartbeats, called arrhythmias.
Pulmonary atresia has Complication: Weakening of heart function.
Pulmonary atresia has Preventio: Control other health conditions.
Pulmonary atresia has Preventio: Don't smoke and don't be around others who smoke.
Pulmonary atresia has Preventio: Aim for a healthy weight.
Pulmonary atresia has Preventio: Get recommended vaccinations.

Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Symptom: Fast breathing or shortness of breath.
Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Symptom: Tiredness.
Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Symptom: Poor feeding.

Most congenital heart conditions happen during the first six weeks of pregnancy. The major blood vessels that run to and from the heart also begin to grow at this time. This is when a congenital heart defect such as pulmonary atresia may occur.
Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Risk Factor: Alcohol use.
Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Risk Factor: Some medicines.

Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Risk Factor: Diabetes.
Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect has Risk Factor: Rubella, also called German measles.
Pulmonary edema has Symptom: Pulmonary edema symptoms may appear suddenly or develop over time. Symptoms depend on the type of pulmonary edema.
Pulmonary edema has Cause: The causes of pulmonary edema vary. Pulmonary edema falls into two categories, depending on where the problem starts.
Pulmonary edema has Risk Factor: Heart failure and other heart conditions that raise pressure in the heart increase the risk of pulmonary edema. Risk factors for heart failure include:
Pulmonary edema has Complication: Complications of pulmonary edema depend on the cause.
Pulmonary edema has Preventio: You may be able to prevent pulmonary edema by managing existing heart or lung conditions and following a healthy lifestyle.

Pulmonary embolism has Symptom: Chest pain.
Pulmonary embolism has Symptom: Fainting.
Pulmonary embolism has Cause: Fat from the inside of a broken long bone
Pulmonary embolism has Cause: Part of a tumor
Pulmonary embolism has Cause: Air bubbles
Pulmonary embolism has Risk Factor: Although anyone can develop blood clots that result in a pulmonary embolism, certain factors can increase your risk.

Pulmonary embolism has Complication: A pulmonary embolism can be life-threatening. About one-third of people with an undiagnosed and untreated pulmonary embolism don't survive. When the condition is diagnosed and treated promptly, however, that number drops dramatically.
Pulmonary embolism has Preventio: Blood thinners (anticoagulants).
Pulmonary embolism has Preventio: Compression stockings.
Pulmonary embolism has Preventio: Leg elevation.
Pulmonary embolism has Preventio: Physical activity.
Pulmonary embolism has Preventio: Pneumatic compression.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Symptom: Shortness of breath.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Symptom: Dry cough.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Symptom: Extreme tiredness.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Symptom: Weight loss that's not intended.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Symptom: Aching muscles and joints.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Symptom: Widening and rounding of the tips of the fingers or toes, called clubbing.

Pulmonary fibrosis has Risk Factor: Certain types of work.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Risk Factor: Cancer treatments.

Pulmonary fibrosis has Complication: Right-sided heart failure.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Complication: Respiratory failure.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Complication: Lung cancer.
Pulmonary fibrosis has Complication: Other lung problems.

Pulmonary hypertension has Symptom: Blue or gray skin. Depending on skin color, these changes may be harder or easier to see.
Pulmonary hypertension has Symptom: Chest pressure or pain.
Pulmonary hypertension has Symptom: Dizziness or fainting.
Pulmonary hypertension has Symptom: Fast pulse or pounding heartbeat.
Pulmonary hypertension has Symptom: Fatigue.
Pulmonary hypertension has Symptom: Swelling in the ankles, legs and belly area.

Pulmonary hypertension has Cause: Pulmonary hypertension is caused by changes in the cells that line the lung arteries. The changes can make the artery walls narrow, stiff, swollen and thick. It gets harder for blood to flow through the lungs.
Pulmonary hypertension has Risk Factor: A family history of the condition.
Pulmonary hypertension has Risk Factor: Being overweight.
Pulmonary hypertension has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Pulmonary hypertension has Risk Factor: Blood-clotting disorders or a family history of blood clots in the lungs.
Pulmonary hypertension has Risk Factor: A history of being around asbestos.
Pulmonary hypertension has Risk Factor: A heart condition present at birth, called a congenital heart defect.

Pulmonary hypertension has Complication: Blood clots.
Pulmonary hypertension has Complication: Irregular heartbeats, also called arrhythmias.
Pulmonary hypertension has Complication: Bleeding in the lungs.
Pulmonary hypertension has Complication: Pregnancy complications.
Pulmonary valve disease has Symptom: Chest pain.
Pulmonary valve disease has Symptom: Shortness of breath at rest or when active or lying down.
Pulmonary valve disease has Symptom: Fatigue.
Pulmonary valve disease has Symptom: Fainting.

Pulmonary valve disease has Cause: Usually, pulmonary valve disease is caused by a heart condition that develops before birth, called a congenital heart defect. But pulmonary valve disease may happen later in life as a complication of another illness.

Pulmonary valve disease has Risk Factor: Chest injury.
Pulmonary valve disease has Risk Factor: German measles, also called rubella.
Pulmonary valve disease has Risk Factor: Infection of the lining of the heart and heart valves, also called endocarditis.

Pulmonary valve stenosis has Risk Factor: Things that may increase the risk of pulmonary valve stenosis include:
Pulmonary valve stenosis has Complication: Possible complications of pulmonary stenosis include:

Pyoderma gangrenosum has Symptom: Pyoderma gangrenosum usually starts with a small bump on the skin. It might look like a spider bite. Within days it can turn into a large and painful open sore.

Pyoderma gangrenosum has Cause: No one knows the exact cause of pyoderma gangrenosum. It's often seen in people who have autoimmune diseases, such as ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease and arthritis. And some studies suggest that it may be passed down through families.
Pyoderma gangrenosum has Risk Factor: Being a woman between 20 and 50 years of age.
Pyoderma gangrenosum has Risk Factor: Having an inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease.
Pyoderma gangrenosum has Risk Factor: Having rheumatoid arthritis.
Pyoderma gangrenosum has Risk Factor: Having a blood disorder, such as acute myelogenous leukemia or myelodysplasia.

Pyoderma gangrenosum has Complication: Possible complications of pyoderma gangrenosum include infection, uncontrolled pain, scarring and and changes in skin color after the affected skin heals. This change in skin color is called postinflammatory hyperpigmentation when the skin darkens and postinflammatory hypopigmentation when the skin loses color. People with brown or Black skin have a higher risk of long-term skin color changes.

Pyoderma gangrenosum has Preventio: You can't prevent the first instance of pyoderma gangrenosum. If you have the condition, you can help prevent new sores by protecting your skin from injury. Injury or trauma to the skin, including from surgery, can cause new sores to form.
Rabies has Symptom: The first symptoms of rabies may be very similar to those of the flu and may last for days.
Rabies has Cause: The rabies virus causes a rabies infection. The virus spreads through the saliva of infected animals. Infected animals can spread the virus by biting another animal or a person.
Rabies has Risk Factor: Factors that can increase your risk of rabies include:
Rabies has Preventio: To reduce your risk of coming in contact with rabid animals:

Radiation enteritis has Symptom: The symptoms of radiation enteritis include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting and stomach cramps. Symptoms occur because of irritation of the intestines from radiation therapy for cancer. Symptoms usually go away several weeks after treatment ends. But sometimes they last longer. Radiation enteritis that goes on for longer can cause anemia and bowel obstruction.

Radiation enteritis has Risk Factor: The risk of radiation enteritis is higher in people undergoing radiation treatments for cancers in the belly and the pelvis. Radiation enteritis occurs because radiation therapy can cause irritation of the intestines.

Radiation sickness has Symptom: The severity of radiation sickness symptoms depends on how much radiation you've absorbed. How much you absorb depends on the strength of the radiated energy, the time of your exposures, and the distance between you and the source of radiation.
Radiation sickness has Cause: Radiation sickness is caused by being exposed to a high dose of radiation. Radiation is the energy released from atoms as either a wave or a tiny particle of matter.
Radiation sickness has Risk Factor: An accident at a nuclear industrial facility.
Radiation sickness has Risk Factor: An attack on a nuclear industrial facility.
Radiation sickness has Risk Factor: A small radioactive device going off.
Radiation sickness has Risk Factor: An explosive device that sends out radioactive material. This is called a dirty bomb.
Radiation sickness has Risk Factor: A nuclear weapon going off.
Radiation sickness has Complication: Experiencing a radioactive accident or attack.
Radiation sickness has Complication: Mourning friends or family who haven't survived.
Radiation sickness has Complication: Dealing with the uncertainty of a mysterious and potentially fatal illness.
Radiation sickness has Complication: Worrying about the eventual risk of cancer due to radiation exposure.

Radiation sickness has Preventio: In the event of a radiation emergency, listen to the radio or watch television to hear what protective actions local, state and federal authorities recommend. Those actions depend on the situation, but you will be told to either stay in place or evacuate your area.
Ramsay Hunt syndrome has Symptom: The two main signs and symptoms of Ramsay Hunt syndrome are:

Ramsay Hunt syndrome has Cause: Ramsay Hunt syndrome occurs in people who've had chickenpox. Once you recover from chickenpox, the virus stays in your body — sometimes reactivating in later years to cause shingles, a painful rash with fluid-filled blisters.

Ramsay Hunt syndrome has Risk Factor: Ramsay Hunt syndrome can occur in anyone who has had chickenpox. It's more common in older adults, typically affecting people older than 60. Ramsay Hunt syndrome is rare in children.
Ramsay Hunt syndrome has Complication: Complications of Ramsay Hunt syndrome may include:

Ramsay Hunt syndrome has Preventio: Children are now routinely vaccinated against chickenpox, which greatly reduces the chances of becoming infected with the chickenpox virus. A shingles vaccine for people age 50 or older also is recommended.
Raynaud's disease has Symptom: Cold fingers or toes.
Raynaud's disease has Symptom: Areas of skin that turn white then blue. Depending on your skin color, these color changes may be harder or easier to see.
Raynaud's disease has Symptom: Numb, prickly feeling or stinging pain upon warming or easing of stress.
Raynaud's disease has Cause: Experts don't fully understand the cause of Raynaud's attacks. But blood vessels in the hands and feet appear to react too strongly to cold temperatures or stress.
Raynaud's disease has Risk Factor: The condition affects more women than men.
Raynaud's disease has Risk Factor: Although anyone can develop the condition, primary Raynaud's often begins between the ages of 15 and 30.
Raynaud's disease has Risk Factor: Climate.
Raynaud's disease has Risk Factor: Family history.
Raynaud's disease has Complication: If secondary Raynaud's is severe, reduced blood flow to fingers or toes could cause tissue damage. But that's rare.
Raynaud's disease has Preventio: Bundle up outdoors.
Raynaud's disease has Preventio: Warm your car.
Raynaud's disease has Preventio: Take care indoors.
Reactive arthritis has Symptom: The signs and symptoms of reactive arthritis generally start 1 to 4 weeks after exposure to a triggering infection. They might include:

Reactive arthritis has Cause: Reactive arthritis develops in reaction to an infection in your body, often in your intestines, genitals or urinary tract. You might not be aware of the triggering infection if it causes mild symptoms or none at all.
Reactive arthritis has Risk Factor: Certain factors increase your risk of reactive arthritis:

Reactive arthritis has Preventio: Genetic factors appear to play a role in whether you're likely to develop reactive arthritis. Though you can't change your genetic makeup, you can reduce your exposure to the bacteria that may lead to reactive arthritis.

Reactive attachment disorder has Symptom: Reactive attachment disorder usually starts in infancy. There's little research on signs and symptoms of reactive attachment disorder beyond early childhood, and it remains uncertain whether it occurs in children older than 5 years.

Reactive attachment disorder has Cause: To feel safe and develop trust, infants and young children need a stable, caring environment. Their basic emotional and physical needs must be consistently met by caregivers. For instance, when a baby cries, the need for comfort, a meal or a diaper change must be met with a shared emotional exchange that may include eye contact, smiling and caressing.

Reactive attachment disorder has Risk Factor: The risk of developing reactive attachment disorder from severe social and emotional neglect or the lack of opportunity to develop stable attachments may increase in children who, for example:

Reactive attachment disorder has Complication: Without proper treatment, reactive attachment disorder can continue for several years and may have lifelong consequences. These can include problems with relationships, social interactions, mental and physical health, behavior, intellectual development, and substance abuse.

Reactive attachment disorder has Preventio: While it's not known with certainty if reactive attachment disorder can be prevented, there may be ways to reduce the risk of its development. Infants and young children need a stable, caring environment and their basic emotional and physical needs must be consistently met. The following parenting suggestions may help.

Rectal cancer has Symptom: Narrow stool.

Rectal cancer has Symptom: Weakness or fatigue.
Rectal cancer has Symptom: A lump in the rectum, which may be found during a medical exam.

Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Family history of colorectal cancer.
Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Inflammatory bowel disease.
Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Inherited syndromes that increase colorectal cancer risk.
Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Excess weight.

Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Colorectal cancer can be diagnosed at any age, but most people with this type of cancer are older than 50. The rates of colorectal cancer in people younger than 50 have been increasing, but healthcare professionals aren't sure why.
Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Radiation therapy for previous cancer.
Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Rectal cancer has Risk Factor: Too little exercise.
Rectal cancer has Complication: Bleeding in the rectum.
Rectal cancer has Complication: Intestinal obstruction.

Rectal cancer has Preventio: There's no sure way to prevent rectal cancer, but you can reduce your risk if you:

Rectal prolapse has Symptom: Constipation or loose stools.
Rectal prolapse has Symptom: Leaking blood or mucus from the rectum.

Rectal prolapse has Cause: The cause of rectal prolapse is unclear. Though it's a common belief that rectal prolapse is related to childbirth, about one-third of women with this health problem never had children.
Rectal prolapse has Risk Factor: Most people with rectal prolapse are women.
Rectal prolapse has Risk Factor: Rectal prolapse most often happens in people over age 50.
Rectal prolapse has Risk Factor: Constipation.

Rectovaginal fistula has Symptom: The most common symptom of a rectovaginal fistula is passing gas or stool from the vagina. Depending on the fistula's size and location, you may have only minor symptoms. Or you may have significant problems with stool and gas leakage and keeping the area clean.

Rectovaginal fistula has Complication: Fistula recurrence.
Rectovaginal fistula has Complication: Issues with self-esteem and intimacy.
Rectovaginal fistula has Preventio: There are no steps you need to take to prevent a rectovaginal fistula.
Recurrent breast cancer has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of recurrent breast cancer vary depending on where the cancer comes back.

Recurrent breast cancer has Cause: Recurrent breast cancer occurs when cells that were part of your original breast cancer break away from the original tumor and hide nearby in the breast or in another part of your body. Later, these cells begin growing again.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Lymph node involvement.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Larger tumor size.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Positive or close tumor margins.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Lack of radiation treatment following a lumpectomy.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Younger people, particularly those under age 35 at the time of their original breast cancer diagnosis, face a higher risk of recurrent breast cancer.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Inflammatory breast cancer.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Lack of endocrine therapy for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Cancer cells with certain characteristics.
Recurrent breast cancer has Risk Factor: Obesity.

Recurrent breast cancer has Preventio: Radiation therapy.
Recurrent breast cancer has Preventio: Targeted therapy.
Recurrent breast cancer has Preventio: Bone-building drugs.
Recurrent breast cancer has Preventio: Maintaining a healthy weight.
Recurrent breast cancer has Preventio: Exercising.

REM sleep behavior disorder has Symptom: Movement, such as kicking, punching, arm flailing or jumping from bed, in response to action-filled or violent dreams, such as being chased or defending yourself from an attack
REM sleep behavior disorder has Symptom: Noises, such as talking, laughing, shouting, emotional outcries or even cursing

REM sleep behavior disorder has Cause: Nerve pathways in the brain that prevent muscles from moving are active during normal REM or dreaming sleep, resulting in temporary paralysis of your body. In REM sleep behavior disorder, these pathways no longer work and you may physically act out your dreams.
REM sleep behavior disorder has Risk Factor: Being male and over 50 years old

Renal artery stenosis has Symptom: High blood pressure that begins suddenly or gets worse without a known cause.

Renal artery stenosis has Risk Factor: High cholesterol.

Renal artery stenosis has Risk Factor: Smoking and other tobacco use.
Renal artery stenosis has Risk Factor: A family history of early heart disease.
Renal artery stenosis has Risk Factor: Lack of exercise.

Renal artery stenosis has Complication: Fluid retention in the legs. This causes swollen ankles or feet.
Residual limb pain has Symptom: Prickling.
Residual limb pain has Symptom: Throbbing.
Residual limb pain has Symptom: Burning.
Residual limb pain has Symptom: Squeezing.
Residual limb pain has Symptom: Stabbing.
Residual limb pain has Symptom: Cramping.
Residual limb pain has Cause: Issues in the bone or the soft tissue, such as sores or bone spurs.
Residual limb pain has Cause: Infection.
Residual limb pain has Cause: Poor blood supply to the part of the arm or leg that's left.
Residual limb pain has Cause: A tumor.
Residual limb pain has Cause: A tangle of nerve endings that forms after the arm or leg is removed, called a neuroma.
Residual limb pain has Cause: Nerve damage.

Residual limb pain has Risk Factor: How high on the body the arm or leg was removed, called amputation.
