Residual limb pain has Complication: Residual limb pain affects quality of life and may get in the way of using a replacement arm or leg, called a prosthesis. People with residual limb pain may be more likely to be depressed or anxious than people who don't have the pain.

Residual limb pain has Preventio: A replacement limb, called a prothesis, that fits well can ease pressure between the residual limb and the prothesis. This can help prevent residual limb pain. Taking good care of the skin that comes into contact with the prothesis also can help prevent residual limb pain.

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection most commonly appear about four to six days after exposure to the virus. In adults and older children, RSV usually causes mild cold-like signs and symptoms. These may include:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) has Cause: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) enters the body through the eyes, nose or mouth. It spreads easily through the air on infected respiratory droplets. You or your child can become infected if someone with RSV coughs or sneezes near you. The virus also passes to others through direct contact, such as shaking hands.

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) has Risk Factor: By age 2, most children will have been infected with respiratory syncytial virus, but they can get infected by RSV more than once. Children who attend child care centers or who have siblings who attend school are at a higher risk of exposure and reinfection. RSV season — when outbreaks tend to occur — is the fall to the end of spring.
Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) has Complication: Complications of respiratory syncytial virus include:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) has Preventio: Respiratory syncytial virus can infect anyone. But premature babies and young infants, as well as older adults, with heart or lung disease or a weakened immune system are at higher risk of severe infection.
Restless legs syndrome has Symptom: Uncomfortable sensations that begin while resting.
Restless legs syndrome has Symptom: Relief with movement.
Restless legs syndrome has Symptom: Worsening of symptoms in the evening.
Restless legs syndrome has Symptom: Nighttime leg twitching.

Restless legs syndrome has Cause: Often, there's no known cause for restless legs syndrome. Researchers suspect the condition may be caused by an imbalance of the brain chemical dopamine. Dopamine sends messages to control muscle movement.
Restless legs syndrome has Risk Factor: Peripheral neuropathy.
Restless legs syndrome has Risk Factor: Iron deficiency.
Restless legs syndrome has Risk Factor: Kidney failure.
Restless legs syndrome has Risk Factor: Spinal cord conditions.
Restless legs syndrome has Risk Factor: Parkinson's disease.

Restless legs syndrome has Complication: Restless legs syndrome symptoms can range from being mild to having a serious impact on people's lives. Many people withRLSfind it hard to fall or stay asleep.
Retinal detachment has Symptom: The sudden appearance of tiny specks or squiggly lines that seem to drift through your field of vision. These are called floaters.
Retinal detachment has Symptom: Flashes of light in one or both eyes. These are called photopsias.
Retinal detachment has Symptom: Blurred vision.
Retinal detachment has Symptom: Side vision, also called peripheral vision, that becomes worse.
Retinal detachment has Symptom: A curtainlike shadow over your field of vision.
Retinal detachment has Cause: Rhegmatogenous (reg-mu-TOJ-uh-nus).
Retinal detachment has Cause: Tractional.
Retinal detachment has Cause: Exudative.
Retinal detachment has Risk Factor: Aging — retinal detachment is more common in people ages 40 to 70.
Retinal detachment has Risk Factor: Past retinal detachment in one eye.
Retinal detachment has Risk Factor: Family history of retinal detachment.
Retinal detachment has Risk Factor: Extreme nearsightedness, also called myopia.
Retinal detachment has Risk Factor: Past eye surgery, such as cataract removal.
Retinal detachment has Risk Factor: Past severe eye injury.
Retinal detachment has Risk Factor: History of other eye disease or condition, including retinoschisis, uveitis or thinning of the peripheral retina called lattice degeneration.
Retinal diseases has Symptom: Seeing floating specks or cobwebs.
Retinal diseases has Symptom: Blurred or distorted vision in which straight lines can look wavy.
Retinal diseases has Symptom: Defects in the side vision.
Retinal diseases has Symptom: Vision loss.
Retinal diseases has Risk Factor: Aging.
Retinal diseases has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Retinal diseases has Risk Factor: Being obese.
Retinal diseases has Risk Factor: Having diabetes or other diseases.
Retinal diseases has Risk Factor: Eye trauma.
Retinal diseases has Risk Factor: A family history of retinal diseases.
Retinoblastoma has Symptom: A white color in the center circle of the eye when light is shone in the eye. It might show up in flash photos.
Retinoblastoma has Symptom: Eye redness.
Retinoblastoma has Symptom: Eye swelling.
Retinoblastoma has Symptom: Eyes that seem to be looking in different directions.
Retinoblastoma has Symptom: Vision loss.
Retinoblastoma has Cause: Retinoblastoma is caused by changes inside the cells in the eye. It's not always clear what causes the changes that lead to this eye cancer.
Retinoblastoma has Risk Factor: Retinoblastoma is most common in very young children. It's typically diagnosed by age 2. Retinoblastoma that happens later in life is very rare.
Retinoblastoma has Risk Factor: DNA changes that run in families.
Retinoblastoma has Complication: Children with retinoblastoma can develop complications.
Retinoblastoma has Preventio: There's no way to prevent retinoblastoma.
Retractile testicle has Symptom: The testicle may be moved by hand from the groin into the scrotum and won't immediately retreat to the groin.
Retractile testicle has Symptom: The testicle might spontaneously appear in the scrotum and remain there for a time.
Retractile testicle has Symptom: The testicle might spontaneously disappear again for a time.

Retractile testicle has Cause: An overactive muscle causes a testicle to become a retractile testicle. The cremaster muscle is a thin pouch-like muscle in which a testicle rests. When the cremaster muscle contracts, it pulls the testicle up toward the body. The cremaster reflex can be stimulated by rubbing a nerve on the inner thigh and by emotion, such as fear and laughter. The cremaster is also activated by a cold environment.
Retractile testicle has Risk Factor: There are no known risk factors for retractile testicles.
Retractile testicle has Complication: Retractile testicles are generally not associated with complications, aside from a greater risk of the testicle becoming an ascending testicle.

Retrograde ejaculation has Symptom: Retrograde ejaculation doesn't affect your ability to get an erection or have an orgasm — but when you climax, semen goes into your bladder instead of coming out of your penis. Retrograde ejaculation signs and symptoms include:

Retrograde ejaculation has Cause: During a male orgasm, a tube called the vas deferens transports sperm to the prostate, where they mix with other fluids to produce liquid semen (ejaculate). The muscle at the opening of the bladder (bladder neck muscle) tightens to prevent ejaculate from entering the bladder as it passes from the prostate into the tube inside the penis (urethra). This is the same muscle that holds urine in your bladder until you urinate.
Retrograde ejaculation has Risk Factor: You're at increased risk of retrograde ejaculation if:
Retrograde ejaculation has Complication: Retrograde ejaculation isn't harmful. However, potential complications include:
Retrograde ejaculation has Preventio: If you take medications or have health problems that put you at risk of retrograde ejaculation, ask your doctor what you can do to lower your risk.

Rett syndrome has Symptom: Babies with Rett syndrome usually are born after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Most infants with Rett syndrome seem to grow and behave as expected for the first six months. After that, signs and symptoms start to appear.

Rett syndrome has Cause: Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder. Classic Rett syndrome, as well as several variants (atypical Rett syndrome) with milder or more-severe symptoms, occur based on several specific genetic changes (mutations).

Rett syndrome has Risk Factor: Rett syndrome is rare. The genetic changes known to cause the disease are random, and no risk factors have been identified. In a very small number of cases, inherited factors — for instance, having close family members with Rett syndrome — may play a role.
Rett syndrome has Complication: Complications of Rett syndrome include:

Rett syndrome has Preventio: There's no known way to prevent Rett syndrome. In most cases, the genetic changes that cause the disorder occur spontaneously. Even so, if you have a child or other family member with Rett syndrome, you may want to ask your health care provider about genetic testing and genetic counseling.

Reye's syndrome has Symptom: The symptoms of Reye's syndrome usually start about 3 to 5 days after a viral infection begins. The viral infection may be the flu, also known as influenza, or chickenpox. Or Reye's syndrome may develop after an upper respiratory infection such as a cold.

Reye's syndrome has Cause: The exact cause of Reye's syndrome is not known. The use of aspirin during a viral illness has most commonly been linked to Reye's syndrome. Several factors may play a role.
Reye's syndrome has Risk Factor: Using aspirin to treat a viral infection such as chickenpox, the flu or an upper respiratory infection.
Reye's syndrome has Risk Factor: Having a metabolic condition. This may include a fatty acid oxidation disorder.

Reye's syndrome has Complication: Most children and teenagers who have Reye's syndrome survive. However, varying degrees of lasting brain damage are possible. Without proper diagnosis and treatment, Reye's syndrome can cause death within a few days.
Reye's syndrome has Preventio: Acetylsalicylic acid.
Reye's syndrome has Preventio: Acetylsalicylate.
Reye's syndrome has Preventio: Salicylic acid.
Reye's syndrome has Preventio: Salicylate.
Rhabdomyosarcoma has Symptom: Headache.
Rhabdomyosarcoma has Symptom: Bleeding in the nose, throat or ears.
Rhabdomyosarcoma has Symptom: Tearing, bulging or swelling of the eyes.

Rhabdomyosarcoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes rhabdomyosarcoma. It starts when a soft tissue cell develops changes in its DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell a cell what to do.
Rhabdomyosarcoma has Risk Factor: Rhabdomyosarcoma most often happens to children younger than 10.
Rhabdomyosarcoma has Risk Factor: Inherited syndromes.
Rhabdomyosarcoma has Complication: Cancer that spreads.
Rhabdomyosarcoma has Complication: Long-term side effects.
Rheumatic fever has Symptom: Fever.
Rheumatic fever has Symptom: Joint pain or swelling — most often the knees, ankles, elbows and wrists. Joints may feel hot or tender.
Rheumatic fever has Symptom: Pain in one joint that travels to another joint.
Rheumatic fever has Symptom: Chest pain.
Rheumatic fever has Symptom: Fatigue.
Rheumatic fever has Symptom: Small, painless bumps beneath the skin.
Rheumatic fever has Symptom: Flat or slightly raised, painless rash with a ragged edge.

Rheumatic fever has Cause: Rheumatic fever can happen after a throat infection from group A streptococcus bacteria, also called strep bacteria. The bacteria cause strep throat and scarlet fever. Improperly treated strep throat or scarlet fever infections cause rheumatic fever.
Rheumatic fever has Risk Factor: Genes.
Rheumatic fever has Risk Factor: Specific type of strep bacteria.
Rheumatic fever has Risk Factor: Environmental factors.
Rheumatic fever has Complication: Narrowing of a heart valve, also called valve stenosis.
Rheumatic fever has Complication: Backward flow of blood across a heart valve.
Rheumatic fever has Complication: Damage to heart muscle.
Rheumatic fever has Complication: Heart failure.
Rheumatic fever has Complication: Irregular heartbeats.

Rheumatic fever has Preventio: The best way to prevent rheumatic fever is to treat strep throat infections or scarlet fever right away. It's also important to finish all of the prescribed antibiotics as directed.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Symptom: Painful, warm, swollen joints.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Symptom: Joint stiffness that most often is worse in the mornings and after periods of rest. It can last for 45 minutes or longer.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Symptom: Tiredness, fever and not wanting to eat.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Cause: Experts don't know the cause of rheumatoid arthritis. But it's a condition in which the immune system attacks healthy joint tissue by mistake, called autoimmune.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Risk Factor: People assigned female at birth are more likely than those assigned male at birth to get rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis has Risk Factor: Rheumatoid arthritis can happen at any age. But most often it begins in middle age. Children and young teens may get a related condition called juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Risk Factor: Family history.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Risk Factor: Smoking.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Risk Factor: Gum infection.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Risk Factor: Excess weight.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Osteoporosis.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Rheumatoid nodules.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Dry eyes and mouth.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Infections.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Carpal tunnel syndrome.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Heart problems.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Lung disease.
Rheumatoid arthritis has Complication: Lymphoma.
Rickets has Symptom: Symptoms of rickets can include:

Rickets has Cause: Your child's body needs vitamin D to absorb calcium and phosphorus from food. Rickets can occur if your child's body doesn't get enough vitamin D or has problems using vitamin D properly. Occasionally, not getting enough calcium or lack of calcium and vitamin D can cause rickets.
Rickets has Risk Factor: Factors that can increase a child's risk of rickets include:
Rickets has Complication: If not treated, rickets can lead to:

Rickets has Preventio: Exposure to sunlight provides the best source of vitamin D. During most seasons, 10 to 15 minutes of exposure to the sun near midday is enough. But if you have brown or Black skin, if it's winter, or if you live in northern latitudes, you might not be able to get enough vitamin D from sun exposure.
Ringworm (body) has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of ringworm may include:

Ringworm (body) has Cause: Ringworm is a contagious fungal infection caused by common mold-like parasites that live on the cells in the outer layer of your skin. It can be spread in the following ways:
Ringworm (body) has Risk Factor: You're at higher risk of ringworm of the body if you:

Ringworm (body) has Complication: A fungal infection rarely spreads below the surface of the skin to cause serious illness. But people with weak immune systems, such as those with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), may find it difficult to get rid of the infection.

Ringworm (body) has Preventio: Ringworm is difficult to prevent. The fungus that causes it is common, and the condition is contagious even before symptoms appear. Take these steps to reduce your risk of ringworm:
Ringworm (scalp) has Symptom: Signs and symptoms of ringworm of the scalp may include:

Ringworm (scalp) has Cause: Ringworm of the scalp is caused by a common fungus. The fungus attacks the outer layer of skin on the scalp and the hair. This causes those hairs to break. The condition can be spread in the following ways:
Ringworm (scalp) has Risk Factor: Risk factors for ringworm of the scalp include:

Ringworm (scalp) has Complication: Some people with ringworm of the scalp may develop a severe inflammation called kerion. Kerion appears as soft, raised swellings that drain pus and cause thick, yellow crusting on the scalp.

Ringworm (scalp) has Preventio: Ringworm of the scalp is difficult to prevent. The fungus that causes it is common, and the condition is contagious even before symptoms appear. Take these steps to reduce the risk of ringworm:
Rosacea has Symptom: Facial redness and flushing.
Rosacea has Symptom: Visible veins.
Rosacea has Symptom: Swollen bumps.
Rosacea has Symptom: Burning sensation.
Rosacea has Symptom: Eye problems.
Rosacea has Symptom: Enlarged nose.
Rosacea has Cause: Sun or wind.
Rosacea has Cause: Hot drinks.
Rosacea has Cause: Spicy foods.
Rosacea has Cause: Alcohol.
Rosacea has Cause: Very hot and cold temperatures.
Rosacea has Cause: Emotional stress.
Rosacea has Cause: Exercise.
Rosacea has Cause: Drugs that dilate blood vessels, including some blood pressure medicines.
Rosacea has Cause: Some cosmetic, skin and hair care products.
Rosacea has Risk Factor: Have skin that burns easily in the sun.
Rosacea has Risk Factor: Are between the ages of 30 to 50 years.
Rosacea has Risk Factor: Have a history of smoking.
Rosacea has Risk Factor: Have a family member with rosacea.

Roseola has Symptom: If your child is exposed to someone with roseola and becomes infected with the virus, it will likely take 1 to 2 weeks for signs and symptoms of infection to appear. Or they may not appear at all. It's possible to become infected with roseola but not show any sign of it.

Roseola has Cause: Roseola is caused by a virus, usually human herpes virus 6 or sometimes human herpes virus 7. It is spread by contact with an infected person's saliva, such as when sharing a cup, or through the air, such as when a person with roseola coughs or sneezes. It can take about 9 to 10 days for symptoms to develop after exposure to an infected person.

Roseola has Risk Factor: The risk of roseola is highest in older infants. It is most common between 6 and 15 months. Older infants are at greatest risk of acquiring roseola because they haven't had time yet to develop their own antibodies against many viruses. Newborns are protected by antibodies received from their mothers during pregnancy. But this immunity decreases with time.
Roseola has Complication: Roseola is usually a mild disease, but it can cause complications.

Roseola has Preventio: There is no vaccine to prevent roseola. You can protect others by keeping home a child with fever until the fever has been gone for 24 hours. Then, even if a roseola rash is present the disease isn't contagious.
Rotator cuff injury has Symptom: Be described as a dull ache deep in the shoulder.
Rotator cuff injury has Symptom: Disturb sleep.
Rotator cuff injury has Symptom: Make it difficult to comb your hair or reach behind your back.
Rotator cuff injury has Symptom: Be accompanied by arm weakness.

Rotator cuff injury has Cause: Rotator cuff injuries are most often caused by progressive wear and tear of the tendon tissue over time. Repetitive overhead activity or prolonged bouts of heavy lifting can irritate or damage the tendon. The rotator cuff also can be injured in a single incident during falls or accidents.
Rotator cuff injury has Risk Factor: The risk of a rotator cuff injury increases with age. Rotator cuff tears are most common in people older than 50.
Rotator cuff injury has Risk Factor: Some occupations.
Rotator cuff injury has Risk Factor: Certain sports.
Rotator cuff injury has Risk Factor: Family history.
Rotator cuff injury has Complication: Without treatment, rotator cuff problems may lead to permanent loss of motion or weakness of the shoulder joint.
Rotavirus has Symptom: In adults, rotavirus infection doesn’t tend to causes symptoms or causes mild symptoms.

Rotavirus has Cause: Rotavirus passes from one person to another because it is present in stool. If a person has a rotavirus infection, the virus is in stools at least two days before symptoms start. It can be present in stools up to 10 days after symptoms start.

Rotavirus has Risk Factor: Rotavirus infections are most common in children under 5 years old. More-serious illness occurs in children under 3 years old. Infants under 3 months old usually don't get rotavirus infections.
Rotavirus has Complication: Dehydration
Rotavirus has Preventio: To prevent the spread of the virus, wash your hands with soap and water:

Rubella has Symptom: Some people have no symptoms. But if they do, symptoms of rubella most often appear 2 to 3 weeks after being exposed to the virus. Symptoms last about 1 to 5 days and may include:

Rubella has Cause: Rubella is caused by a virus that's passed from person to person. It can spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes. It also can spread through direct contact with infected mucus from the nose and throat. And it can be passed from pregnant people to their unborn children.
Rubella has Risk Factor: Risk factors for getting rubella include:

Rubella has Complication: Rubella is a mild infection. Some people assigned female at birth who have had rubella get arthritis in the fingers, wrists and knees. This most often lasts about a month. Rarely, rubella can cause swelling and irritation, called inflammation, of the brain.

Rubella has Preventio: The rubella vaccine most often is given as a combined measles-mumps-rubella vaccine, also called the MMR vaccine. A vaccine also may include the chickenpox vaccine, also called the varicella vaccine. It's called the MMRV vaccine.
Rumination syndrome has Symptom: Effortless regurgitation, typically within minutes of eating.
Rumination syndrome has Symptom: Belly pain or pressure relieved by regurgitation.
Rumination syndrome has Symptom: A feeling of fullness.
Rumination syndrome has Symptom: Nausea.
Rumination syndrome has Symptom: Losing weight without trying.
Rumination syndrome has Cause: The exact cause of rumination syndrome isn't clear.But it appears to be caused by an increase in abdominal pressure.
Rumination syndrome has Complication: Unhealthy weight loss.
Rumination syndrome has Complication: Malnutrition.
Rumination syndrome has Complication: Worn teeth.
Rumination syndrome has Complication: Bad breath.
Rumination syndrome has Complication: Embarrassment.
Rumination syndrome has Complication: Social isolation.
Ruptured eardrum (perforated eardrum) has Symptom: Symptoms of a ruptured eardrum may include:
Ruptured eardrum (perforated eardrum) has Cause: Causes of a ruptured, also called perforated, eardrum may include:
Ruptured eardrum (perforated eardrum) has Complication: The eardrum, also called tympanic membrane, has two main roles:
Ruptured eardrum (perforated eardrum) has Preventio: Follow these tips to avoid a ruptured eardrum:
Ruptured spleen has Symptom: Pain in the upper left stomach.
Ruptured spleen has Symptom: Tenderness when you touch the upper left stomach.
Ruptured spleen has Symptom: Left shoulder pain.
Ruptured spleen has Symptom: Confusion, lightheadedness or dizziness.
Ruptured spleen has Cause: Injury to the left side of the body.
Ruptured spleen has Cause: An enlarged spleen.

Ruptured spleen has Risk Factor: If the spleen is already enlarged due to infection or another cause, there is increased risk that the spleen might rupture. Contact sports that involve blows to the chest also increase the risk of a ruptured spleen.
Ruptured spleen has Complication: A ruptured spleen can cause life-threatening bleeding into your stomach cavity.

Ruptured spleen has Preventio: If you've been diagnosed with an enlarged spleen, ask your health care provider whether you need to avoid activities for several weeks that could cause it to rupture. These might include contact sports, heavy lifting and other activities that increase the risk of stomach trauma.
Sacral dimple has Symptom: A sacral dimple is an indentation or pit in the skin on the lower back. It's usually located just above the crease between the buttocks.
Sacral dimple has Cause: There are no known causes for a sacral dimple. It is a congenital condition, meaning it's present at birth.

Sacral dimple has Risk Factor: Risk factors for sacral dimples include being born with a spinal cord problem, such as tethered cord syndrome. In this condition the spinal cord doesn't hang free within the spinal canal. Sacral dimples also can be present in newborns without other health conditions.
Sacral dimple has Complication: Spina bifida.
Sacral dimple has Complication: Tethered cord syndrome.
Sacroiliitis has Symptom: Sleeping or sitting for a long time.
Sacroiliitis has Symptom: Standing a long time.
Sacroiliitis has Symptom: Having more weight on one leg than the other.
Sacroiliitis has Symptom: Stair climbing.
Sacroiliitis has Symptom: Running.
Sacroiliitis has Symptom: Taking large steps when moving forward.
Sacroiliitis has Cause: Injury.
Sacroiliitis has Cause: Arthritis.
Sacroiliitis has Cause: Pregnancy.
Sacroiliitis has Cause: Infection.
Sacroiliitis has Risk Factor: Certain conditions may increase the risk of swelling in the sacroiliac joints.

Sacroiliitis has Complication: Sacroiliitis can cause difficulty with certain actions, such as bending, lifting, staying in one position and rising from being seated. The ongoing pain of sacroiliitis can lead to depression and loss of sleep.
Salivary gland tumors has Symptom: A lump or swelling on or near the jaw or in the neck or mouth.
Salivary gland tumors has Symptom: Muscle weakness on one side of the face.
Salivary gland tumors has Symptom: Numbness in part of the face.
Salivary gland tumors has Symptom: Ongoing pain near a salivary gland.
Salivary gland tumors has Symptom: Trouble opening the mouth widely.
Salivary gland tumors has Symptom: Trouble swallowing.

Salivary gland tumors has Cause: The cause of many salivary gland tumors isn't known. Healthcare professionals have identified some things that raise the risk of salivary gland tumors. These include smoking and radiation therapy for cancer. Not everyone with a salivary gland tumor has these risk factors, though. More research is needed to find out exactly what causes these tumors.
Salivary gland tumors has Risk Factor: Though salivary gland tumors can happen at any age, they most often happen in older adults.
Salivary gland tumors has Risk Factor: Radiation exposure.
Salivary gland tumors has Risk Factor: Smoking tobacco.
Salivary gland tumors has Risk Factor: Viral infections.
Salivary gland tumors has Risk Factor: Workplace exposure to certain substances.

Salmonella infection has Symptom: Salmonella infection is usually caused by eating raw or undercooked meat, poultry, and eggs or egg products or by drinking unpasteurized milk. The incubation period — the time between exposure and illness — can be 6 hours to 6 days. Often, people who have salmonella infection think they have the stomach flu.

Salmonella infection has Cause: Salmonella bacteria live in the intestines of people, animals and birds. Most people are infected with salmonella by consuming food or water that has been contaminated by feces.
Salmonella infection has Risk Factor: Factors that may increase your risk of salmonella infection include:

Salmonella infection has Complication: Salmonella infection usually isn't life-threatening. However, in certain people — especially infants and young children, older adults, transplant recipients, pregnant women, and people with weakened immune systems — the development of complications can be dangerous.

Salmonella infection has Preventio: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) oversees and updates inspection, sampling and testing programs for poultry and meat. The purpose is to cut the number of salmonella infections in the United States.

Sarcoidosis has Symptom: Symptoms of sarcoidosis vary, depending on which organs are affected and how badly they're affected. Sarcoidosis sometimes develops slowly over time and causes symptoms that last for years. Other times, symptoms appear suddenly and then disappear just as quickly. Many people with sarcoidosis have no symptoms, so the condition is found only when a chest X-ray is done for another reason.

Sarcoidosis has Cause: The cause of sarcoidosis is not known. Experts think it results from a mix of genetic and environmental factors that cause the body's immune system to overreact to a substance it doesn't know.
Sarcoidosis has Risk Factor: Sarcoidosis can happen at any age, but often occurs between the ages of 20 and 60 years. Women are slightly more likely to develop the condition than are men.
Sarcoidosis has Risk Factor: Race.
Sarcoidosis has Risk Factor: Job or hobbies.
Sarcoidosis has Risk Factor: Family history.
Sarcoidosis has Complication: Lungs.
Sarcoidosis has Complication: Eyes.
Sarcoidosis has Complication: Kidneys.
Sarcoidosis has Complication: Heart.
Sarcoidosis has Complication: Nervous system.
Sarcoma has Symptom: A lump that can be felt through the skin that may or may not be painful.
Sarcoma has Symptom: Bone pain.
Sarcoma has Symptom: A bone that breaks with no clear cause, such as with a minor injury or no injury.
Sarcoma has Symptom: Belly pain.
Sarcoma has Symptom: Weight loss.
Sarcoma has Cause: It's not clear what causes sarcoma. This cancer starts as a growth of cells in the bones and soft tissues.
Sarcoma has Risk Factor: Inherited syndromes.
Sarcoma has Risk Factor: Radiation therapy for cancer.
Sarcoma has Risk Factor: Lymphedema.
Sarcoma has Risk Factor: Exposure to viruses.
Scabies has Symptom: Itching, often severe and usually worse at night
Scabies has Symptom: Thin, wavy tunnels made up of tiny blisters or bumps on the skin
Scabies has Cause: Scabies is caused by a tiny, eight-legged mite. The female mite burrows just under the skin and makes a tunnel where it lays eggs.
Scabies has Complication: Young children
Scabies has Complication: People with developmental disabilities
Scabies has Complication: People with weakened immune systems, such as those withHIVor lymphoma, or people who have had organ transplants
Scabies has Complication: People who are very sick, such as people in hospitals or nursing facilities
Scabies has Complication: Older people in nursing homes
Scabies has Preventio: Wash all clothes and linen.
Scabies has Preventio: Starve the mites.
Scabies has Preventio: Clean and vacuum.
Scarlet fever has Symptom: The signs and symptoms that give scarlet fever its name include:

Scarlet fever has Cause: Scarlet fever is caused by the same type of bacteria that causes strep throat — group A streptococcus (strep-toe-KOK-us), also called group A strep. In scarlet fever, the bacteria release a toxin that produces the rash and red tongue.

Scarlet fever has Risk Factor: Children 5 to 15 years of age are more likely than are other people to get scarlet fever. Scarlet fever germs spread more easily among people in close contact, such as family members, child-care groups or classmates.
Scarlet fever has Complication: If scarlet fever goes untreated, the bacteria may spread to the:
Scarlet fever has Preventio: There is no vaccine to prevent scarlet fever. The best ways to prevent scarlet fever are the same as the standard precautions against infections:
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Delusions — having false, fixed beliefs, despite facts showing that they're not true.
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Hallucinations, such as hearing voices or seeing things that others don't observe.
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Disorganized thinking and speech.
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Bizarre or unusual behavior.
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Symptoms of depression, such as feeling empty, sad or worthless.
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Periods of manic mood, with more energy and less need for sleep over several days, and behaviors that are out of character.
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Having a hard time functioning at work or school or in social situations.
Schizoaffective disorder has Symptom: Problems managing personal care, such as not looking clean and not taking care in how one looks.
Schizoaffective disorder has Cause: While it isn't known what causes schizoaffective disorder, genes that are passed down through families likely play a part.
Schizoaffective disorder has Risk Factor: Having a close blood relative, such as a parent or sibling, who has schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia or bipolar disorder.
Schizoaffective disorder has Risk Factor: Stressful events that may cause symptoms.
Schizoaffective disorder has Risk Factor: Taking mind-altering drugs, which may make symptoms worse when an underlying problem is present.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Suicide, suicide attempts and thoughts about suicide.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Social isolation.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Conflicts with others and within families.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Unemployment.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Anxiety disorders.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Alcohol or other substance misuse.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Health conditions, such as heart disease, stroke and obesity.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Being poor and not having a home.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Being assaulted.
Schizoaffective disorder has Complication: Aggressive episodes, though people with schizoaffective disorder are more likely to be assaulted rather than assault others.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: Want to be alone and do activities alone.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: Do not want or enjoy close relationships.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: Feel little if any desire for sexual relationships.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: Take pleasure in few activities, if any.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: Find it hard to express your emotions and react.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: May lack humor or not be interested in others. Or you may be cold toward others.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: May lack the drive that makes you want to reach goals.
Schizoid personality disorder has Symptom: Do not react to praise or criticism from others.

Schizoid personality disorder has Cause: Personality is the blend of thoughts, emotions and behaviors that makes you special. It's the way you view, understand and relate to the outside world. It's also how you see yourself. Personality forms when you're a child. It's shaped through a blend of your surroundings and genes passed down from your parents.
Schizoid personality disorder has Risk Factor: Having a parent or another relative who has schizoid personality disorder, schizotypal personality disorder or schizophrenia.
Schizoid personality disorder has Risk Factor: Having a parent who was cold, did not properly care for you and did not take action to help you emotionally.
Schizoid personality disorder has Complication: Schizotypal personality disorder or schizophrenia.
Schizoid personality disorder has Complication: Other personality disorders.
Schizoid personality disorder has Complication: Major depression.
Schizoid personality disorder has Complication: Anxiety disorders.
Schizophrenia has Symptom: Delusions.
Schizophrenia has Symptom: Hallucinations.
Schizophrenia has Symptom: Disorganized speech and thinking.
Schizophrenia has Symptom: Extremely disorganized or unusual motor behavior.
Schizophrenia has Symptom: Negative symptoms.
Schizophrenia has Cause: It isn't known what causes schizophrenia. But researchers believe that a mix of genetics, brain chemistry and environment can play a part.
Schizophrenia has Risk Factor: A family history of schizophrenia.
Schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Life experiences, such as living in poverty, stress or danger.

Schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Some pregnancy and birth issues, such as not getting enough nutrition before or after birth, low birth weight, or exposure to toxins or viruses before birth that may affect brain development.
Schizophrenia has Risk Factor: Taking mind-altering — also called psychoactive or psychotropic — drugs as a teen or young adult.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Suicide, suicide attempts and thoughts of suicide.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Anxiety disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder, also known as OCD.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Depression.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Misuse of alcohol or other drugs, including nicotine.

Schizophrenia has Complication: Money problems and homelessness.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Social isolation.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Health and medical problems.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Being victimized.
Schizophrenia has Complication: Aggressive or violent behavior, though people with schizophrenia are more likely to be assaulted rather than assault others.

Schizophrenia has Preventio: There's no sure way to prevent schizophrenia. But staying with your treatment plan can help stop symptoms from returning or getting worse. Researchers hope that learning more about risk factors for schizophrenia may lead to earlier diagnosis and treatment.

Schizotypal personality disorder has Symptom: Have flat emotions or have emotional responses that are limited or not proper socially.

Schizotypal personality disorder has Symptom: Have unusual thoughts, such as sensing an absent person's presence, or having illusions.
Schizotypal personality disorder has Symptom: Dress in odd ways, such as appearing messy or wearing oddly matched clothes.
Schizotypal personality disorder has Symptom: Speak in an odd way, such as vague or unusual patterns of speaking, or ramble oddly while speaking.

Schizotypal personality disorder has Complication: Anxiety.

Sciatica has Symptom: Sciatica pain can be almost anywhere along the nerve pathway. It's especially likely to follow a path from the low back to the buttock and the back of a thigh and calf.

Sciatica has Cause: Sciatica occurs when the nerve roots to the sciatic nerve become pinched. The cause is usually a herniated disk in the spine or an overgrowth of bone, sometimes called bone spurs, on the spinal bones. More rarely, a tumor can put pressure on the nerve.
Sciatica has Risk Factor: People ages 20 to 50 are most likely to have herniated disks. Bone spurs develop more commonly as people age.

Scleroderma has Risk Factor: Environmental triggers.
Scleroderma has Risk Factor: Immune system conditions.

Scoliosis has Symptom: One side of the back poking out when bending forward.

Scorpion sting has Symptom: Pain, which can be intense.
Scorpion sting has Symptom: Numbness and tingling.
Scorpion sting has Symptom: Slight swelling.
Scorpion sting has Symptom: Warmth.

Scorpion sting has Cause: A scorpion sting is caused by the stinger in a scorpion's tail. When a scorpion stings, its stinger can release venom. The venom contains a complex mix of toxins that affect the nervous system. These are called neurotoxins.

Scorpion sting has Risk Factor: Work, hike or camp where scorpions are.

Scorpion sting has Complication: The very old and the very young are most likely to die of untreated venomous scorpion stings. The cause is usually heart or lung failure that occurs some hours after the sting. Very few deaths from scorpion stings have been reported in the U.S.

Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) has Symptom: In most cases, seasonal affective disorder (SAD) symptoms appear during late fall or early winter and go away during the sunnier days of spring and summer. Less commonly, people with the opposite pattern have symptoms that begin in spring or summer. In either case, symptoms may start out mild and become more severe as the season progresses.
Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) has Cause: The specific cause of seasonal affective disorder remains unknown. Some factors that may come into play include:
Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) has Risk Factor: Seasonal affective disorder is diagnosed more often in women than in men. And SAD occurs more frequently in younger adults than in older adults.

Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) has Complication: Take signs and symptoms of seasonal affective disorder (SAD) seriously. As with other types of depression, SAD can get worse and lead to problems if it's not treated. These can include:

Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) has Preventio: There's no known way to prevent the development of Seasonal affective disorder (SAD). However, if you take steps early on to manage symptoms, you may be able to prevent them from getting worse over time. You may be able to head off serious changes in mood, appetite and energy levels, as you can predict the time of the year in which these symptoms may start. Treatment can help prevent complications, especially SAD if is diagnosed and treated before symptoms get bad.

Seborrheic keratosis has Risk Factor: The peak time for developing seborrheic keratoses is after your 50s. You're also more likely to have them if you have a family history of the condition.

Secondary hypertension has Complication: Secondary hypertension can worsen the underlying medical condition that's causing the high blood pressure. Without treatment, secondary hypertension can lead to other health problems, such as:

Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Repeated and intense distress when thinking about separation or when away from home or loved ones. This may include being clingy or having tantrums about separation that last longer or are more severe than other kids of the same age.
Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Constant, intense worry about losing a parent or other loved one to an illness, death, or a disaster or harm coming to them.
Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Constant worry that something bad will happen, such as being lost or kidnapped, causing separation from parents or other loved ones.
Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Not wanting to or refusing to be away from home because of fear of separation.
Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Not wanting to be home alone or somewhere without a parent or other loved one close by, if the child has reached an age where being alone might be expected.

Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Not wanting to or refusing to sleep away from home or to go to sleep without a parent or other loved one nearby, if the child has reached an age where these activities might be expected.
Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Repeated nightmares about separation.
Separation anxiety disorder has Symptom: Repeated complaints of headaches, stomachaches, or other symptoms during or before separation from a parent or other loved one.

Separation anxiety disorder has Cause: Sometimes, separation anxiety can be triggered by life stress that results in separation from a loved one. Examples include divorce of parents, changing schools, moving to a new location or a loved one's death. Genetics may play a role in separation anxiety becoming separation anxiety disorder.
Separation anxiety disorder has Risk Factor: Life stresses or loss that result in separation.
Separation anxiety disorder has Risk Factor: Family history.
Separation anxiety disorder has Risk Factor: Situational issues.
Separation anxiety disorder has Complication: Other anxiety disorders, such as generalized anxiety disorder, panic attacks, phobias, social anxiety disorder or agoraphobia.

Separation anxiety disorder has Complication: Depression.
Separation anxiety disorder has Preventio: Get professional advice as soon as possible
Separation anxiety disorder has Preventio: Follow the treatment plan

Sepsis has Symptom: Symptoms of sepsis may include:
Sepsis has Cause: Any type of infection can lead to sepsis. This includes bacterial, viral or fungal infections. Those that more commonly cause sepsis include infections of:
Sepsis has Risk Factor: Some factors that increase the risk infection will lead to sepsis include:

Sepsis has Complication: As sepsis worsens, vital organs, such as the brain, heart and kidneys, don't get as much blood as they should. Sepsis may cause atypical blood clotting. The resulting small clots or burst blood vessels may damage or destroy tissues.
Septic arthritis has Symptom: Septic arthritis typically causes extreme discomfort and difficulty using the affected joint. The joint could be swollen, red and warm, and you might have a fever.

Septic arthritis has Cause: Septic arthritis can be caused by bacterial, viral or fungal infections. Bacterial infection with Staphylococcus aureus (staph) is the most common cause. Staph commonly lives on even healthy skin.
Septic arthritis has Risk Factor: Risk factors for septic arthritis include:

Septic arthritis has Complication: If treatment is delayed, septic arthritis can lead to joint degeneration and permanent damage. If septic arthritis affects an artificial joint, complications may include joint loosening or dislocation.
Serotonin syndrome has Symptom: Serotonin syndrome symptoms usually occur within several hours of taking a new drug or increasing the dose of a drug you're already taking.
Serotonin syndrome has Cause: Excessive accumulation of serotonin in the body creates the symptoms of serotonin syndrome.
Serotonin syndrome has Risk Factor: Some people are more likely to be affected by the drugs and supplements that cause serotonin syndrome than are others, but the condition can occur in anyone.
Serotonin syndrome has Complication: Serotonin syndrome generally doesn't cause any problems once serotonin levels are back to their original levels.

Serotonin syndrome has Preventio: Taking more than one serotonin-related medication or increasing your dose of a serotonin-related medication increases your risk of serotonin syndrome. Know what medications you take and share a complete list of your medications with your doctor or pharmacist.
Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has Symptom: SARS usually starts with flu-like symptoms, including:

Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has Cause: SARS is caused by SARS-CoV-1, a strain of coronavirus. Coronaviruses are the family of viruses that also cause the common cold. A different strain of coronavirus, called SARS-CoV-2, causes COVID-19.

Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has Risk Factor: By and large, people at greatest risk of SARS are those who have had direct, close contact with someone who's infected. This includes healthcare workers and family members living with someone who has SARS.

Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has Complication: Many people with SARS get pneumonia. And sometimes, a machine called a ventilator is needed to help with breathing. SARS is fatal in some cases, often because the body can′t get enough oxygen or can′t remove enough carbon dioxide. This condition is called respiratory failure. SARS also can lead to heart and liver failure.

Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has Preventio: Researchers are working on various vaccines for SARS. But none has been tested in humans. If infections caused by the SARS virus happen again, follow some safety measures. The following tips are key if you care for someone who may have SARS:

Shellfish allergy has Cause: All food allergies are caused by an immune system overreaction. Your immune system identifies a harmless substance as being harmful. This substance is called an allergen. In shellfish allergy, your immune system mistakenly identifies a certain protein in shellfish as harmful. Your immune system is how your body protects itself, so it produces immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies to protect against this allergen. The next time you come in contact with the shellfish protein, these antibodies signal your immune system to release chemicals such as histamine into your bloodstream. This causes a reaction that leads to the symptoms of an allergic reaction.
Shellfish allergy has Risk Factor: You're at increased risk of developing shellfish allergy if allergies of any type are common in your family.
Shellfish allergy has Complication: Asthma
Shellfish allergy has Complication: Allergic reactions to very small amounts of shellfish (extreme sensitivity)
Shellfish allergy has Complication: History of food-induced anaphylaxis
Shellfish allergy has Complication: Strong family history of allergy

Shellfish allergy has Preventio: If you have shellfish allergy, the only way to avoid an allergic reaction is to avoid all shellfish and products that contain shellfish. Even trace amounts of shellfish can cause a severe reaction in some people.

Shigella infection has Preventio: Wash hands often. Use soap and water, and scrub for at least 20 seconds. This is key before you prepare or eat food, and before sexual activity. It's also important to wash after you use the bathroom or change a diaper.

Sickle cell anemia has Cause: Sickle cell anemia is caused by a change in the gene that tells the body to make hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is the iron-rich compound in red blood cells that allows these cells to carry oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body. The hemoglobin associated with sickle cell anemia causes red blood cells to become rigid, sticky and misshapen.

Sickle cell anemia has Risk Factor: For a baby to have sickle cell anemia, both parents must carry a sickle cell gene. In the United States, sickle cell anemia most commonly affects people of African, Mediterranean and Middle Eastern descent.

Sickle cell anemia has Preventio: If you carry the sickle cell trait, it can help to see a genetic counselor before you get pregnant. A counselor can help you understand your risk of having a child with sickle cell anemia. You also can learn about possible treatments, preventive measures and reproductive options.

Sleep disorders also can be grouped based on behaviors, problems with your natural sleep-wake cycles, breathing problems, difficulty sleeping or how sleepy you feel during the day.

Soft palate cancer has Cause: Soft palate cancer happens when cells on the soft palate develop changes in their DNA. A cell's DNA holds the instructions that tell a cell what to do. In healthy cells, the DNA gives instructions to grow and multiply at a set rate. The instructions tell the cells to die at a set time. In cancer cells, the changes give different instructions. The changes tell the cancer cells to make many more cells quickly. Cancer cells can keep living when healthy cells would die. This causes too many cells.

Spermatocele has Symptom: A spermatocele usually causes no signs or symptoms and might remain stable in size. If it becomes large enough, however, you might feel:

Spermatocele has Cause: The cause of spermatoceles is unknown. Spermatoceles might result from a blockage in one of the multiple tubes within the epididymis that transport and store sperm from the testicle.

Spermatocele has Risk Factor: There aren't many known risk factors for developing a spermatocele. Men whose mothers were given the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy to prevent miscarriage and other pregnancy complications appear to have a higher risk of spermatoceles. Use of this drug was stopped in 1971 due to concerns about an increased risk of rare vaginal cancer in women.
Spermatocele has Complication: A spermatocele is unlikely to cause complications.

Spermatocele has Preventio: Although there's no way to prevent a spermatocele, it's important for you to conduct scrotal self-exams at least monthly to detect changes, such as masses, in your scrotum. Any new mass in your scrotum should be evaluated promptly.

Spider bites has Symptom: Typically, a spider bite looks like any other bug bite — a red, inflamed, sometimes itchy or painful bump on your skin — and may even go unnoticed. Harmless spider bites usually don't produce any other symptoms.

Spider bites has Cause: Severe spider bite symptoms occur as a result of the venom that the spider injects. Symptom severity depends on the type of spider, the amount of venom injected and how sensitive your body is to the venom.

Spider bites has Risk Factor: Risk factors for spider bites include living in areas where spiders live and disturbing their natural habitat. Widow spiders and recluse spiders like warm climates and dark, dry places.
Spider bites has Complication: Rarely, a bite from a widow spider or recluse spider is deadly, particularly in small children.
Spider bites has Preventio: Spiders usually bite only in defense, when being trapped between your skin and another object.

Spina bifida has Symptom: Meningocele.
Spina bifida has Symptom: Myelomeningocele.

Spina bifida has Cause: The cause of spina bifida is not known. It's thought that a combination of genetic, nutritional and environmental risk factors causes the condition. This includes having a family history of neural tube defects and getting too little folate, also known as vitamin B-9, during pregnancy.
Spina bifida has Risk Factor: Too little folate in the pregnant person's body.
Spina bifida has Risk Factor: Family history of neural tube defects.
Spina bifida has Risk Factor: Some medicines.

Spina bifida has Complication: Whether skin covers the affected area.
Spina bifida has Complication: Which spinal nerves come out of the affected area of the spinal cord.

Spina bifida has Preventio: You can greatly reduce your risk of having a baby with spina bifida or other neural tube defects by taking folic acid supplements. Begin taking the supplements at least one month before becoming pregnant and continue taking them through the first trimester of pregnancy.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Symptom: Trouble walking or climbing stairs.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Symptom: Numbness, tingling or sudden pain in the legs.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Symptom: Weakness on one or both sides of the body.

Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Cause: The cause of spinal arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) isn't known. Most spinalAVMsare present at birth, known as congenital. But others may happen later in life.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Risk Factor: There are no known risk factors for spinal arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). The condition occurs equally in men and women.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Complication: Trouble moving.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Complication: Pain, tingling and numbness.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Complication: Damage to the spine.
Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Complication: Bulging blood vessel, known as an aneurysm.

Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) has Complication: Hemorrhage, which can speed up spinal cord damage.

Spinal cord tumor has Symptom: Pain near the spot where the tumor forms.
Spinal cord tumor has Symptom: Pain that feels worse at night.
Spinal cord tumor has Symptom: Pain that feels like it extends or shoots from the back to nearby areas.
Spinal cord tumor has Symptom: Pain that gets worse over time.

Spinal cord tumor has Cause: It's not clear what causes most spinal cord tumors. A spinal cord tumor starts as a growth of cells in or around the spinal cord. The spinal cord extends downward from the base of the brain. It's made up of nerve cells and groups of nerves that carry messages between the brain and the rest of the body. The bones of the spine surround and protect the spinal cord.
Spinal cord tumor has Risk Factor: Neurofibromatosis type 1.
Spinal cord tumor has Risk Factor: Neurofibromatosis type 2.
Spinal cord tumor has Risk Factor: Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

Spinal cord tumor has Complication: Spinal cord tumors can press on nerves. This may lead to a loss of movement or feeling. These changes typically affect parts of the body that are below the tumor. Changes might include weakness in the legs and difficulty walking. There might be changes in bowel and bladder functions.
Spinal headaches has Symptom: Dull, throbbing pain that varies in intensity from mild to very severe
Spinal headaches has Symptom: Pain that typically gets worse when you sit up or stand and decreases or goes away when you lie down

Spinal headaches has Cause: Spinal headaches are caused by leakage of spinal fluid through a puncture hole in the membrane (dura mater) that surrounds the spinal cord. This leakage decreases the pressure exerted by the spinal fluid on the brain and spinal cord, which leads to a headache.
Spinal headaches has Risk Factor: Being between the ages of 18 and 30
Spinal headaches has Risk Factor: Being female
Spinal headaches has Risk Factor: Being pregnant
Spinal headaches has Risk Factor: Having a history of frequent headaches

Spinal headaches has Risk Factor: Having a small body mass

Spinal stenosis has Cause: Spinal injuries.

This weakens the heart and may lead to a heart attack. A heart attack fromSCADis different from a heart attack caused by a buildup of fats, cholesterol and other substances in and on the artery walls. This condition is called atherosclerosis.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin has Cause: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin occurs when the squamous cells in the skin get changes in their DNA. Cells' DNA holds the instructions that tell cells what to do. The changes tell the squamous cells to multiply quickly. The cells continue living when healthy cells would die as part of their natural life cycle.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin has Complication: Occurs in a person with a weakened immune system. Examples of things that might cause a weakened immune system include having chronic leukemia or taking medicine to control the immune system after an organ transplant.

Staph infections has Symptom: Staph infection symptoms vary depending on where the infection is in the body and how serious it is.

Staph infections has Cause: Staph infections are caused by contact with staph bacteria or toxins from the bacteria. Staph bacteria can spread from person to person. Or you may touch something with the bacteria on it and then touch your body.

Staph infections has Risk Factor: A serious staph infection may be more likely for some people than others. For example, the risk goes up as you age. People with a weakened immune system are at higher risk. And skin diseases may raise the risk of staph infections.
Staph infections has Complication: Skin infections from staph bacteria often heal without complication, but some may leave a scar.
Staph infections has Preventio: You can lower the risk of staph infections by taking actions to keep the bacteria off your skin.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome has Cause: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a rare and unpredictable illness. Your health care provider may not be able to identify its exact cause, but usually the condition is triggered by medication, an infection or both. You may react to medication while you're using it or up to two weeks after you've stopped using it.
Stevens-Johnson syndrome has Risk Factor: Factors that increase your risk of developing Stevens-Johnson syndrome include:
Stevens-Johnson syndrome has Complication: Stevens-Johnson syndrome complications include:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome has Preventio: If you've had this condition, avoid the medication that triggered it.If you've had Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and your health care provider told you it was caused by a medication, avoid that drug and others like it. This is key to preventing a recurrence, which is usually more severe than the first episode and can be fatal.

Stomach cancer has Cause: It's not clear what causes stomach cancer. Experts believe most stomach cancers start when something hurts the inside lining of the stomach. Examples include having an infection in the stomach, having long-standing acid reflux and eating a lot of salty foods. Not everyone with these risk factors gets stomach cancer, though. So more research is needed to find out exactly what causes it.

Stomach cancer has Preventio: Eat plenty of fruits and vegetables.
Stomach cancer has Preventio: Reduce the amount of salty and smoked foods you eat.

Stomach cancer has Preventio: Tell your health care provider if stomach cancer runs in your family.

Strep throat has Cause: Strep throat is caused by infection with a bacterium known as Streptococcus pyogenes, also called group A streptococcus.

Strep throat has Complication: Strep throat can lead to serious complications. Antibiotic treatment reduces the risk.

Stress fractures has Symptom: At first, you might barely notice the pain from a stress fracture. But it tends to become worse if you do more of an activity that puts stress on the cracked bone. The tender feeling often starts at a certain spot and gets better during rest. You also might have swelling around the painful area.
Stress fractures has Cause: Stress fractures often happen when you increase the amount or intensity of an activity too fast.
Stress fractures has Risk Factor: Factors that can raise your risk of stress fractures include:

Stress fractures has Complication: Some stress fractures don't heal properly. That can cause long-term problems. It's important to not restart the activity that caused the stress fracture too soon. Doing so could put you at higher risk of larger stress fractures that may be harder to heal.
Stress fractures has Preventio: Simple steps can help you prevent stress fractures.

Stress incontinence has Cause: Stress incontinence happens when certain muscles and other tissues linked to urinating weaken. These include the muscles that support the urethra, called the pelvic floor muscles, and the muscles that control the release of urine, called the urinary sphincter.

Stress incontinence has Risk Factor: Physical changes that happen with age, such as muscles getting weaker, may make you more likely to get stress incontinence. But some stress incontinence can happen at any age.

Stress incontinence has Complication: Emotional upset.
Stress incontinence has Complication: Mixed urinary incontinence.

Your level of the hormone cortisol also might play a role. Cortisol is a hormone produced by the adrenal glands. It weakens elastic fibers in the skin.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage has Risk Factor: Having a first-degree relative with a brain aneurysm.
